messages.content: **1. Introduction**
Bernard Zie wakes up in his cot in the Gadfly camp. It’s early.
He yawns loudly. “…Mrgh.”
“I hate when you do that.” A voice elsewhere in the room mutters.
Without looking up from his stupor, he responds to the familiar voice. “Eh?”
“The yawning. It’s annoying. Makes me want to do it, but I can’t.”
“Really? I’d have figured you can pretty much… do any sort of sound.”

“Well, yeah. It’s not about the sound.” He makes a yawning noise to accentuate his point. “But there’s nothing tactile, no relieving sensation that motivates it in the first place. No throat for that.”
“How the hell do you even know there’s that kinda sensation? I sure as hell haven’t been talkin with ya about *yawns*.” Bern does it again.
“Because *I* can infer basic and obvious things.”

He lets the insult slide. “No yawns. Poor thing. Well, *I* can’t tank 50 arrows to the chest, so I guess we’re even.” Bern sits up a little to see his roommate.

**FURNACE ENGINE MODEL-SQ1959275-108**, more commonly abbreviated to a different moniker, stood there as stone-faced as ever. Or metal-faced. Distractingly, he has opted to equip a shirt far too small for him, one which clearly endured hardship fitting over the shape of his head. Bern laughs at this. “Hehe. It’s not a good look, I’ll be real.”
“So I guess today is the day you fuck everything up. One of many, in all fairness.”
Bern scoffs. “It’s just a mundane bit of fearmongering. Feels like we haven’t done that in forever.” He finally steps out of bed.
“Stand on one leg.” Furn demands.
“What?”
“Your left leg. Put all your weight on it.”
Bern stammers nervously. “I don’t know what you’re…”
“You’ve not dealt with whatever this is since Eric’s not been available. Your movements suggest it’s flared up without being healed or treated. You can’t do it, can you?”

Bern takes his right foot off the floor, and promptly falls over. “Okay, sure! But I hardly anticipate having to do *that* today.” He stares up at the ceiling once more, delaying his ascent to a standing position.
“That isn’t the point, and you know it.”

“I’m redeeming it, alright? You promised a while back, week or something, that you owed me one nag-free BeFurn shenanigan. Cashing that privilege in. I want to do this. I’m going stir crazy.” He sits up.
“I don’t remember agreeing to that.” The golem mutters.
“Bull! You remember everything. Don’t try to trick me.”
“…Will you at least try to keep a distance from any action?” Furn resigns himself to bargaining, making it a foregone conclusion that the runt will get his way.
“Long as you keep a distance from that wardrobe, mate.”
“Jackass.”

Ready to face the day, Bern slowly walks out of his room. The day in question is, of course, 917/49/1. It seems time has become rather muddled, so I feel it’s important to clarify at every different point.

He spots his comrade, Horatius Kyodu, across the hall. “Hey, was I supposed to do something with old HK?” He whispers.

Forgive the narrative dissonance. There is obviously no ambiguity here, since this is the precursor to a constant; something already known to definitively occur (#theseus).
“Yes. The meeting. Spreading that information is the literal only responsibility you were given today.” Furn stares ahead.

“Oh, yeah! I remember, obviously.”

Bern walks to Horatius in a manner made to seem like he just happened to be passing by. "Ah, morning Horat. I think the boss wanted to talk to you about something? Also, could you confirm to Furn that he looks like shit? This obviously doesn't function as… uh, a disguise? Man."

They nod in silent agreement to Bern, acknowledging both his statements. They then turn to the golem. "I'm told you look like shit. Thoughts on this? …It's not like I'm in any position to judge, anyway."
Furn cannot change in expression in any way, but the pain in his soul can be felt. “Never mind. It was a dumb idea.”

“You look fine just as yourself.” Bern mutters.
 “Anyway. Two of us are heading out to cause minor property damage. Advertisement, you know. Wress asked for you. I passed the message I was supposed t’ on. Seeya.”
The two walk out, and having grabbed a few supplies, start their trek through the forests and plains of Burdlt.
“You could have waited for a response.” Furn points out, discarding the clothing.
“Ehhh, who cares. Horatius is a lot smarter than you, got the gist of what I needed to say quick.”
“It’s courtesy, not practicality.” Furn idly replenishes his fuel with material picked up in the camp. “You’ve seemed awfully eager to end interactions with them lately.”
“I got no clue what you mean. It’s Horatius’s own fault for how unresponsive and unemotional… uh, Horatius is.”
“Do you really struggle with the pronoun thing that much?” Furn asks this more as idle curiosity than anything accusatory.
“Hey, I dunno! It’s them, yeah, but… I can’t say ‘how emotional they is’, can I? Just don’t sound right.”
“Are. It would be ‘they are’.”
Bern rolls his eyes. “Uh, I’m pretty sure he’s only one guy.”

“You mean *they’s* only one guy. No, wait, I…”

Bern snickers.
“Your ignorance has gotten me all turned around. They’re.”
Bern swats the air dismissively. “Whatever! I just don’t get what the big deal is.”
“Ambiguity.”

“What does that even *mean*? Look, I don’t even give a rat's ass if somebody’s one of the birds or one of the bees. Greeting for my friends and beating for my enemies, I say. Wouldn’t even really care if I found someone was lying about it, prob’ly. But can’t ya just keep your story straight and pick one?”
“Is this a joke? Are you not aware of the irony here?” Furn stares blankly at him.
Bern cannot understand what is being implied, but can understand he’s being insulted. “Shut your trap, man.”

Furn steps on a slime, and stops walking to attempt to wipe the unpleasant remnants off of his foot. “I won’t fight your fundamental principles, but you of all people should at least be able to *understand*. How much smoother do you think your life would be if you were willing to lie and say you were a girl?”
Bernard Zie stops walking. Perhaps to not get ahead of his slower companion. Perhaps for another reason.

The machine shifts conversational gears. “Bernard, I am not trying to insult you, or even demand you change. But you will probably be better off at least understanding the fact that you possess a large amount of irrational attachments.” Furn bridges the short distance between the two of them.
“…It’s weird when you say Bernard. Cut that out. Feels like I’m being scolded. So, what, I have an irrational attachment to… being a man? To gender?”

“From my perspective, nearly all organics do, really. I greatly respect that about Horatius.” Bern smirks. He’s made fun of it enough that he’s fairly confident Furn doing the thing where he describes living things the way a supervillain would is an intentional attempt at humor. 

Furn continues walking after catching up. It’s a lot less rude for him to do that, given the disparity in their average paces. “That isn’t what I mean, though. It may have been an issue in the past, but it’s entirely harmless to you these days. I’m talking about the irrational attachment you hold towards suffering.”
“Oh, what the hell! What do you even *mean* by that?” Bern is knocked out of his idleness and quickly catches up.
“You take an extraneous amount of risks—“
“Because it works! To win the game, you gotta have a stake in it.”

“—even to seemingly no added benefit. This applies not just to split-second tactical decisions, but also your long-term lifestyle.” Furn continues to gaze into the direction they travel, even as his comrade tries to meet his eyes.
“I don’t like when you get like this. If you’re gonna roast me, you need to put energy into it!” He pouts, looking quite childish.
“This is the other thing I worried about. I had assumed, having largely been conditioned on social interaction by you, that our brand of mutual antagonism was healthy in a relationship dynamic.”
“That’s a pretty queer way to say it for someone unconcerned with gender.”

“Shut up. …But I wonder if that’s wrong, and I’ve been passively enabling an unhealthy habit of yours. I don’t think I’d be able to change even if I wanted, though.” Furn slowly vents smoke out of himself, simmering in thought. “I am not ‘roasting’ you, I am trying to be of assistance to you because you are my friend.”

“Look, I still don’t get what it is you’re saying, but I’m only okay with you trashtalking me because it gives me license to do the same. And my ‘dangerous lifestyle’, much as it might bother you, is because I believe in this movement.”
Bern crosses his arms defiantly.
“I confronted Eric the other day.”
Bern furrows his brow. “Huh?”

“From what I had seen… Your condition has barely improved at all.” Furn keeps moving at a steady pace, allowing him to mostly match Bern, meandering and caught off guard by the conversation. “I pressed him on it. The man’s absurdly easy to intimidate. On top of being a coward, the potential for blackmail is ridiculously high. He admitted that he’s basically been doing nothing but placebo procedures for ‘treating’ your leg, taking gratitude and favors for nothing.”
“WHAT!” Bern is outraged. “That bastard! I’m here suffering, and he sits there in his stupid phony clinic holding back from-“

“You misunderstand.” Bern stares with a questioning expression, demanding the ensuing elaboration. “He is an insufferable bastard, but he makes every attempt to abide by the creed of a healer. He hasn’t been giving effective treatment to your leg because no such treatment exists.”
“…Huh? Is it really… that complicated of a wound…?” He trails off.
Furn considers how to proceed, and opts to simply state his next set of words at a normal, matter-of-fact pace.
“It’s not. It’s nothing. There’s nothing wrong with your leg, Bern.”

Both of the two are quiet for a few seconds. Bern starts to laugh slowly. The golem grunts, internalizing that this will indeed be a difficult topic.
“There’s evidence that something happened in the past, of course. But everything has sealed itself up and healed. There is absolutely nothing that would cause your legs to function less than a normal person’s.”
“Very funny! Geez, you had me going for a while there! Such an elaborate set-up for screwing with me…”
“Yes, it would be an asinine waste of effort for that end. Bern, are you aware that nobody other than Wress and myself seems to think you have a limp?”
He scoffs at the implication. “I try to minimize my struggles in front of others so I’m not a bother.”
“I have watched the way it often seems to completely vanish during fighting.”
“Adrenaline.”
“Not even fighting. Whenever you’re occupied doing anything.”
Bern throws his hands up in exasperation. “Why do you even care? Your ridiculous theory is, what, that… I’m faking an injury for sympathy? When I—“

“Yes, we just went over your attempts to minimize it. I don’t think you’re engaging in any sort of conscious deception. You are not a bad person, Bernard Zie. You are earnest, and kindhearted, to a fault. That is not what I’m saying.”

“Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa.” Bern shakes his hands in front of his chest defensively. “I am not crazy, alright? I *know* what’s happening with my own body. Who are you to say I’m wrong about that? What, because Eric fuckin’ Dextrum couldn’t find a problem? Y’know, the guy who is only here because he flunked out of being a legit healer? No, alright. You’re reading too far into things.”

“I am not calling you crazy. Though I have no extensive medical knowledge, I trust you truly do experience chronic pain in that area. I’m merely proposing that it is a psychosomatic affliction.” Furn watches as the half-elf rushes to intercept his path forward, walking backwards while facing him.
“Oh, of course! Totally sane. Just something about me being ‘psycho’. I mean, do you think I’m an idiot as well? That I wouldn’t notice that?”

“I do think you’re an idiot, but that’s not relevant.”

Not looking where he’s going, Bern trips on a rock and falls over. He screams incredibly loudly.

Furn looks down in pity. “…You’re correct. It’s nothing but a bizarre theory with inconclusive evidence. I’ll drop the subject.”

“We ain’t… not finished talking about this, alright?” In one smooth motion of rotation, Bern springs back up onto his feet. “I don’t want our synergy to be affected by whatever nonsense you’re thinking of me.”
“…Okay.”
The two are silent the rest of the way.

Eventually, they reach their destination. This is the city named “Ballyhood”, which has evaded mention in favor of the mention of its province, Burdlt.

This tends to be because MBMJ feels a closer attachment to the wider area, having not been raised in Ballyhood. That is the reason for that, and also the name is very dumb.

Bern and Furn loiter near the outskirts of the city, hidden among the foliage.

The fairy-boy is unusually attached to nature, and does not entirely revel in the idea of what they’re about to do. But causing fear is important for the sake of the greater goals of the organization, and a plant is considered a lot more permissible to destroy than a place full of people.

Furn sets a small fire on the ground, controlling his output carefully. The two are still not comfortable with each other again.

As the grass burns up, the flame dies out. Furn tries again elsewhere.

Bern thinks to himself. *I wonder if this even works. Do people recognize us as a recurring threat? Maybe the authorities are trying to cover this up. If they’re not, though, it ought to be good, yeah?*
*In the most immediate term, we need to place pressure on the Burdlt chieftain McVahon to respect our power in the event of a larger scale conflict. Furn’s able to create a highly visible level of chaos for minimal effort and casualties.*
*I guess it’s ironic. They can’t call our bluff; for things to work, we need to make sure people think the worst of us, that the lack of deaths caused by us so far is just luck.*
*My one regret is that we end up having to target poorer areas, a lot of the time. If positioning wasn’t a factor, we’d be better off ruining some rich prick’s garden. But you don’t make the perfect the enemy of the good. It’s a matter of—*
“Hey!” Bern yells out. “What are you doing?!”
“Fire.” Furn answers.
“What the *fuck*?” Bern gestures toward the efforts of his friend. The inferno is incredibly close to a civilian center.
“It needs to be believable.” The fire spreads to a nearby building that starts evacuating seconds later. It exponentially, almost explosively, grows in strength.
“Not that believable! Is that—is that a fuckin’ *bar*?” He stares at the collapsing building. The fire spreads further.
“Should I stop…?” Furn is still moving around to find somewhere to burn that will create a more visible result.
“What?! Yes, you…”
The two are interrupted by a loud, boisterous arrival. A masked man dressed in the most absurd clothes imaginable sizes the two of them up.

"Halt! Unfortunately for you, tis I, Mr. Big Man Jr., and I am here to put an end to this. I will not permit any further tomfoolery. The brawny, veiny hand of justice has arrived. Put your hands above your head."

See? Is this not a more satisfying connection when proper context is given? Before, it was a nearly unnoticeable non-sequitur, but now, a web of connections becomes apparent. This is exactly the kind of comprehensiveness the project exists to facilitate. This is useful. This is necessary. It is, perhaps, “peak”.
"Fuck." Bern expected the authorities eventually, but not… this. Neither comply. The legal authority here is dubious.

The Fire Services are loudly contacted by a bystander, and presumably on their way.

Consequently, the Big Man can either deal with the fire or deal with the firestarters. It is not a hard choice for him.

Mr. Big Man Jr rushes forward to Bernard Zie. "I'm sure you have a valid reason for this act of public malfeasance in your heads, but the poor community of Burdlt does not deserve this pyromaniac thuggery." In true wrestler fashion, he attempts to grapple the elfish human.

The humanish elf is too slippery, and spins out of the way, ambiently generating plant matter (He can do this.).

“Yeah, I guess they don't!" Bern responds to the provocation, and glares at his golem ally.

*Time for this joker to enter a world of hurt!* He snaps his fingers, casting a spell. Nothing happens. He groans.

Furn vaguely mumbles. “We need to present a unified front. Base violence necessary for change.” It’s quiet enough so that their foe cannot hear it, but it’s not even clear that Bern hears. Furn turns towards the wrestler and lumbers toward him. Within the context of combat, the amusing quirk of this mechanical slowness becomes a serious problem.

Perhaps more complicated circumstances would warrant explicit illustrations, but I think the physical positions of all relevant parties are clear here. MBMJ - B ————————— F. The furnace is the furthest.

MBMJ attempts to grapple the elf again. This time, Bern doesn’t even move, distracted trying to parse what his ally said. MBMJ misses the mark and falls over. Let no one say he lacks resolve, however; he is back on his feet sooner than it is possible to take advantage of this failure.

*We’ve done enough, alright?* He implicitly responds to his partner in a manner that cannot actually be heard. Zie spreads his hands out, causing the sky in the vicinity to become cloudy. Man Junior is struck by lightning, yet this barely even fazes him.

Furn continues making his way to the two of them.
MBMJ cries out. "G-gragh!!! I'm going... Mango mode!!!!!!!!!"

*What? What the fuck did he just say? Mang—*

The third time is fortuitous for this participant. Bern is grappled and at his mercy.

Mr. Big Man Jr. simply shoves the opponent onto his back, doing little more than inconvenience. “Mango successfully activated.”

Bern does not understand what is going on. He stands back up. It begins to rain.

Furn has nearly entered an effective range, but MBMJ dashes away from him. The Sisyphean pursuit may never succeed. The hero of Burdlt attempts to grab Bern at the same time, but is unable to quite execute such a tricky bit of multitasking, only shoving him once again.

Bern sneezes. This spreads pollen everywhere. He then gets up and is immediately grabbed by the golem. The golem in question swings a fist at MBMJ, but misses.

Furn groans at his woefully low level of dexterity and punches a nearby tree, setting it on fire. 
The flower boy stews in annoyance within the clutches of his tumultuous friend. "Furn, we're wasting our fucking time here! Forget the Baby-Crippler wannabe, we need to leave *now*!" He has no investment in this fight. Which seems a pity. That such a pivotal endeavor for the vigilante would be a regrettable experience for him.

I just know you’re reading this, is the point. What else do you have to do?

Suddenly, a new arrival enters the area. He looks nothing like someone specialized in putting out fires, nor does he resemble the stereotypical appearance of an ally of the wrestler or the rebel. The old man looks very out of place. Though none of the others present would know this or even have the context to understand why it matters, the man happens to be Joseph R Biden, current president of the United States of America.

His relevance to the story of The Antarctica Project is actually pretty mundane once you throw away your biases and understand how magic functions. But regardless. (I will have less out-of-universe notes further on once everything is established, rest assured.)
Taking an optimistic approach, MBMJ speaks to the newcomer. "Hello senior citizen! In what direction is your soul arrow pointing?"
The old man gives a smile that seems less than friendly. "Don't make this harder than it needs to be, kid."

"My geriatric gentleman, I take that as a threat. And I'll have you know that regardless of what you present to me, I don't take too kindly to threats. I'm sure you've heard of me. Mr. Big Man Jr.. Winner of the Royal Rumble. But what you'll know about the ring, well. I'll have you know. I'm going to light upon your brain like a supernova, radiating energy across your cerebrum fields and turning all the No's in your head into Yes's. Look at you all. Lighting fires. Foolish, really. Fire isn't special. Everyone has the fire, but what makes a champion is knowing when to ignite the spark."

The two prior opponents of MBMJ stare blankly at this speech.

Mr. Big Man Jr. casts Thunderwave, affecting everyone in a 15 foot radius. "This is lesson one in a forty-five course sequence in kicking your asses!!!!!"

Furn isn't remotely fazed by this. Biden is shaken, but stands his ground.

He materializes a blade of light and swings at MBMJ rapidly. His aim is a lethal blow, though he isn’t able to seal the deal.

Joe turns towards the half-elf. Though nothing about his assignment mentioned Bernard Zie, he had a vague intuition that this random kid was important.

The kid in question yells obscenities and fills the air with thorns, damaging everyone. Furn intakes a significant amount of the spread plant matter and begins to heat up.

The authorities are approaching, and just in time. The last attack of Bern has reached MBMJ’s limit, as he collapses to the ground. Biden is shot by a member of the guard and prevented from landing a killing blow.

Apologies for redundancy. Perhaps it would’ve been nicer for observers if the sections of overlap were skipped, but a recap seems harmless. No later chapter contains intersection for quite some time, so it’s a minor problem. Returning to what MBMJ did not witness, Furn is able to use this overload in organic fuel to escape, rocketing away faster than any living thing could manage. By the time he slows to a crawl, the two are no longer visible from the city.
“What a disaster.” Furn performs a debriefing on this latest operation.
“You don’t get to complain! That was all your fault!” Bern wriggles out of his grip.
“Probably.”

“…” Bern has no response. He was expecting some argument over culpability. *That*, he could have handled.

The tension between them remains. It remains for the entire trek back to base.

Wress Hifele is outside to greet them. Furn slips away for some brief maintenance as Bern chats his informal superior up.

“So how did it go? The… thing you were doing.” Wress, sitting on a log, whittles a stick into a weaponizable point, a meaningless activity given doing it implicitly requires a knife.
“Fuckin’ terrible.” Bern spits on the ground, then remembers he’s talking to his leader. “But I don’t think it’ll have any consequences past a waste of our time and energy.”
“Were you seen?” The tiefling avoids eye contact.
“Uh, not by the fed, we left before that… but some people saw us, yes.”
“That’s probably the best middle ground. Notoriety without proof.” He looks over at Bern. “What did you do, exactly?”
“I didn’t do anything!” Bern blurts out defensively, stewing in rage. “The scrap heap went and set a pub or something ablaze.”
“Isn’t that the idea?”
“No!” Bern protests. “I mean, it’s similar, but we’re miscreants, not… like…”
“Terrorists?” Wress asks. “We are, though. Many people are going to die because of us.”

Bern sweats nervously. 
*What the hell is up with this guy? Biggest dweeb around, but you breach the right topic and he’s suddenly a mob boss.*
“I mean, accidents happen, this one is just… super preventable. We’ve done this kinda thing before safely. While still freaking people out!”
“Okay.” Wress forfeits the point, still unconvinced. “This is your own project. I can’t claim to know all about it.”

He finishes whittling and stabs the makeshift skewer into the ground. “I’m not asking you to give up on your principles, or your noble ideals. I’d like to minimize how many lives are ruined by allying with me. I’m just wondering if you’ve chosen the right area. By actively arousing suspicion and attention.”

“Oh, come on. You’re not my mother, so quit acting like it. I love the thrill of the fight. That’s a completely different thing from indiscriminately ending folks who don’t even know what’s going on.”

The loudest footsteps of anyone to ever walk prevent the arrival of another voice from being a surprise.

“A life is a life.” Furn returns. “One could consider those who oppose revolution clueless and unaware of what’s going on.”
“Hi, Furn.” Wress waves. He smiles: 😃
“Yes. Hello.”
“That’s pedant shit and you know it.” Bern sticks his tongue out at the newcomer.
“Wait, I’m just understanding now… are you also against doing this? But you’re part of it, right?” Wress questions Furn.
“I would not say anything that extreme. I am concerned about the specifics of how it’s done. I’m neutral on the activity itself.”
“Then why do you go through with it?” Wress forces the root issue into the open.
“Because Bern wants to.” He answers without hesitation, with the slight annoyance of someone who knows this answer will not end the exchange.

“That’s not really an… I guess I still don’t really understand you two. This antagonistic symbiosis. How do you even know one another? Furn is an enigma unto himself.”
Bern snorts at the overly wordy phrasing.
“Quiet.” Furn admonishes him. An interaction repeated perpetually. “He doesn’t like bringing up his past, Wress.”
“I see. I’m sorry, I understand. I won’t push the issue.”
“That is why instead I will be the one to talk about it at length.”
“Oh, that’s great.” Wress replies.
Furn nods. “Great.” This is great.
“Fuck you!!!” Bern Zie screeches.

Enduring cries of exasperation and drubbing, Furn elaborates. “Bernard Zie saved my life. …No, even that is underselling it. It would not be an exaggeration to say I am only really ‘alive’ thanks to his intervention. Were it not for him going against his own self-interest to hide me away, I would surely have been nothing but a novelty; a slave designed for menial labor.” Bern’s hassling slows down, having a hard time keeping up the motivation while being praised.

“Because of this, I am obliged to him. I know Bern and how to interact with him more than anything, really, so I’m stuck with him out of habit anyway. As for him, Bern also feels I saved him. He’s stuck letting me stay around for the same reason. I would not be the best person to speak on that aspect.”

Bern accepts his cue to talk, but does not explain anything. “It’s not about feeling. Even more literally than what you think I’ve done, I would be dead if it weren’t for you. That’s just a fact.” He’s quieter than his typical level of energy.
Wress nods. “I guess I understand the general sentiments. That wasn’t exactly ‘at length’, though. You just briefly summarized half the story.”
Furn clasps his hands together. “Yes. I only ever intended to do so. My antagonistic phrasing to imply otherwise? It was a ‘joke’.”
“Oooohhh. I see. Haha.” Wress smiles.
Everyone spends a few seconds silently appreciating Furn’s joke, and the way it centered around being rude.
“I shouldn’t pry, yeah. …anyway. We’re having a meeting in the central tent. I’ll be over in a moment, but please make your way there.” Wress stares vaguely at the sky.

“Sure. Whatever.” Bern walks over rapidly, taking a seat in the agreed upon location.

He idly plays with his hair, seemingly the first one here. He’s been doing this thing lately of putting a flower in it, which really livens up his whole vibe, he thinks. 

Furn enters shortly after, taking a seat next to Bern. He looks away.
“…I’m sorry.”
“Eh?” Bern isn’t sure he heard correctly.
“I said I apologize.” Though technically a lie, he accurately reiterated the spirit of his remark.
“For what?”
“I don’t… really know. But you’re obviously upset with me in a more fundamental sense.” Furn looks down in contemplation and/or shame.
“If you don’t know what you did, how on ovans green arctica can it be an apology? Makes no sense.”

“I can make inferences. Regardless of my intent, I think what I said this morning made you feel like I was denying or overriding your personhood. Considering all of the effort you alone have taken to respect my autonomy as a rational sentient being, I owe you the same.”
“Don’t make this a weird thing. I didn’t actually care, you know.” Already not looking at Furn, he turns even further away from doing so. Bernard Zie is not a creature of subtlety.
Now, apparently, is the time to talk about this. “It’s just a load of rubbish, and that ticked me off. Why would I choose to be slower or in pain?”
“I have never claimed it was a choice.”
Bern’s practically tearing his hair out. “Then what the hell is it?! I tried, you know. The whole walk I tried to convince myself it was all in my head, and it only made things worse.”
“You shouldn’t…” Furn begins another admonishment of his reckless other half’s approach to things. But he stops, and says something much more unusual. “Why do you vilify weakness?”
“Uh, what?”

Furn gazes at his own body. “Before you became accustomed to it, you were in awe of my ‘strength’. Even through my many deficiencies on a practical level of combat, my ability to tank damage made me incredible in your eyes.”
Bern shuts his eyes, half-blushing. “I was a dumb kid, you’re embarrassing me.”
“Even now, you hate the idea of being held back by anything. And yet you also hate not putting yourself in harm’s way.”
“I do what I have to do. What *we* have to do, to survive. You think anywhere else would take us?” The orphan fugitive points accusatorially at the crime against nature.
“Do you think Wress would cast you out for not going off on your own arbitrarily?”
Bern clicks his tongue. “I mean, maybe! He wants to seem all wise and understanding as a leader, but he’ll cut off dead weight if he needs to.”
“What about Horatius? They only pitch in sporadically, when it suits them. Wress certainly doesn’t want to throw them to the wolves.”
Bern exhales loudly. “Yeah, well, I don’t have the advantage of Wress being in love with me.”
“What?” Furn finally gets Bern to meet his gaze.
“Look, pal, just trust me on this one.” He smirks. “The guy can play the part of a stoic strategic mastermind, willing to sacrifice anything, but his heart’s an open book.”
“I never would have guessed.” Furn stares at the young man, visible conversing with some newer recruits outside the tent. “Isn’t he… I mean, I never thought Wress would be…”

“Homosexual? That’s the thing, though! It don’t even matter if he is or not. Either way, he’d be able to convince himself Horatius was what he was looking for! Someone who’s crafted, uh, their entire life for that to be possible.”

“Wow.” In an occurrence so rare as to merit historical documentation (though not really, this is a humorous exaggeration), Furn is impressed by the perception and intelligence of Bernard Zie. “So is it like… a thing?”
“No, he’s a coward socially. No hate to him, but it’s true. And I don’t think Horatius is really interested in that kind of thing.”
“We really are like kin. I should ditch you. They’d be way more my style.”
“Ha, what, and be Horatius And Furn? No shot. Doesn’t rhyme at all. Horrible branding.” His spirits are significantly higher now. “It is a bit of a shame, though.”
“What is?”

“Y’know. A shame for the world at large. Horatius not having a stake in that kinda game. I’m not sure if you’ve noticed, but the guy’s quite the catch. Whatever motivates presenting that way, it’s very, uh… *bishonen*.” Bern holds up his hands pronouncing the last word.
Furn pretends to know what that last word was. “I can’t say I’ve pondered this, but I suppose I can see it.”
Bern leans back. “You ever find love, Furn? Some particularly sensual barrel or anvil?”
“Fuck off. But no. I don’t have the parts that make you want that. Even if I did, consider the ethical implications.” Furn stops talking.
“….Uh, okay, I’m considering them. Can you say them?” Bern narrows his eyes, confused.
“I mean, let’s say Wress, yes? He’s essentially twice my age.”
“I guess?”
“But at the same time, my soul, what powers my being — its mental maturity could be twice his age for all I know.”

“Does it really contribute to your maturity if you can’t remember it? Feels unfair to count. Wasn’t really ‘you’.” Bern puts his finger to his chin, pondering the definition of pedophilia as it would pertain to his close friend.
“Absolutely. At least partially. I was ‘born’ already knowing how to talk and certain basic facts.”

“Well, whatever.” Bern shrugs. “No problem if you don’t want it, but I think it’d be silly if you barred yourself off from love just because of these technicalities. Anyone who isn’t deluded can intuit when a relationship is sketchy, and you’re obviously not a baby or senile. I think you’d be cute with someone you fancied.”
“Em, thanks, I guess? But again. Not interested.” Furn glances all around them.

Bern lets out an awkward chuckle/giggle, sounding forced and yet also genuine. “This is my proof, though. I barely even understand what you meant, but it’s obvious to me that I don’t vitrify weakness or whatever. I’m totally comfortable being vulnerable at the right times. I’m here gossipping about romance with you. My whole aesthetic and combat is themed around *flowers*. I garden and cook and knit—“
“*Tried* to knit.” Furn corrects, but doesn’t slow Bern down at all.

“And I’m always open to listen to people’s problems and feelings, and I’m… I mean, fuck, Furn, isn’t this obvious? Feel awkward saying it directly, but like. I’m the dude who looks and dresses like a girl. That’s practically the first thing people learn about me. And it’s not some secret shame! I’m fuckin’ proud to be the guy I am!”
Furn slowly considers how to word his response. “I know. But why are you telling me this?”
“What? …Because you…”
“It sounds like you’re listing attributes about yourself that are stereotypically feminine. Do you think that’s equivalent to weakness?”

“I don’t know! I mean, yes? Yeah. You’re asking weird questions. Why, is that wrong?”
He shifts uncomfortably in his seat.
“I’m pretty sure the new recruit girl kicked your ass the other day.” Furn lightly pokes him.

“I’m not saying all women are weak, obviously! I just went over how I’m all sorts of stuff even though I’m a man. It’s just an average, and not one I’d use to go assuming stuff about how to treat someone personally.”
Wress wanders into the tent. “Hey, have either of you guys seen Eric?”
“No, we have not fucking seen Eric!” Bern, on edge and intensely focused, lashes out, giving the man a death glare.
“Ok. Um. Sorry.” He leaves.
The two are quiet for a bit. Both stare ahead at nothing in particular.
Furn breaks the silence. “Are you… what was the word…. transsexual?”
“No.”
Furn turns rather quickly (by his standards) to face Bern. “That was almost instant. I thought for sure you would need me to clarify what that meant.”

“I’m familiar with what you’re talking about when it’s not boring stuff where I don’t care.” Bern focuses his attention on a little bit of moss that has formed in the crack of the wooden bench. “Of course I’d thought of it. My dad did, first. Back before he had given up on figuring out what was up with me.”
Furn decides not to interject. He’d learned it’s best not to push his luck when Bern brings up his family, and the other half of this didn’t seem to have much room for error either.

“Gave it some thought and… no, it made no sense. Just seemed like I was getting shoved into a different box. Like, what, there’s something wrong and alien about me because of shallow BS? People wanted me to be solved. But I’m not some tortured girl or deluded male. I like my name! I like the words people use to describe me! I like having a dick!!” Furn makes a *shush* gesture while shoving Bern over. The two are no longer alone in this tent as people filter in, and at least one eyebrow-raised glance is given.
“Owowow. But the real point is that I like doing what seems right to me. You don’t need to be dissected in an asylum for that.”
Furn grunts with an ambiguous level of approval/disapproval. “Yeah, I… would not trust anyone in this province on mental health. Maybe anywhere, though.”
“I was lucky. Dad had that whole progressive ideology about everything.”
“Earth, yeah. I recall.” Furn leaves it at that.
Wress finally takes his place at the center of attention. He says some half-hearted bits of filler while more people make their way in. Horatius arrives, glancing repeatedly around themself.

Wress notices Horatius and waves.

He speaks up. "Could you not find Baby Crippler, then?"

Horatius grimaces, and then frowns, then smirks, then erases all of the previously listed. Their expression breaks down, seemingly trying to fake multiple emotions at once. They breathe heavily, staring down slightly. Wress shrugs. “That’s fine.”. He takes this as some unusual mood. “Anyway, Jorge…” Wress goes off towards some other business, not really understanding what the deal is.
But Bern does. He’s never seen it from this perspective, but he knows what this is. He walks slowly, so as not to cause further stress, and places a hand on Horatius’s shoulder.
“Horatius? Something up?” Wress finally notices this is a substantially out-of-the-ordinary occurrence.

Ignoring him, Bern speaks softly, as if trying to avoid startling some sort of small animal. "Are you okay? Deep breaths only make things worse if you're forcing them. Try visualizing a space that makes you feel comfortable."

Horatius seems to at least register these words, and closes their eyes. Their mood still seems dreadful, but their breathing slowly steadies.

Horatius regains themself, and looks at Bern with an awkward mixture of indignation, embarrassment, and gratitude.

"...Sorry," they say to no one in particular, now holding their head with one hand.
Bern smiles. "It's okay. I know." An unspoken understanding of some kind is forged.

Wress is vaguely upset by some or all aspects of what transpired within the last two minutes. He awkwardly forces a change in topic.

"...And nobody's seen Eric. Damn." He returns to business.

Now that Horatius has more or less adjusted to their surroundings again, they opt to be a bit more helpful. "I... did actually meet with Baby Crippler, by the way. But he said he had higher priorities or something. I tried to persuade him, but he seemed set in his decision, so I left. And, well, when I was walking back here... there was someone who was. Following me. It was just one person... and I could have beaten them, but I... I hid. I lost them." Their expression betrays dissatisfaction with this turn of events. To Bern's eyes, at least.

"That was the right choice." Wress responds. "If an enemy is stalking you, they must've been confident they could take you on if it came to that. Maybe they were overly cocky about their own strength, but that's not a possibility worth risking. Their primary goal was probably to find out where we're stationed, and you thwarted that."

"I just- What are we supposed to do? Sure, as long as we keep hiding ourselves away, nobody is going to find us. Nothing can go wrong if they don't know we exist, but nothing is going to go right, either! We can just continue to isolate our existence from everyone else, for how long? For the rest of our lives? Until we die?"
Wress gets unusually giddy at Horatius' statement for what the actual contents of it are. "For only the next hour, really. We're going to-"

"Wait!"
Wress is interrupted.

Gazing at the source of the interjection, it is none other than Jorge. Jorge is an adept wielder of sorcery who will be important in the overall narrative, for reasons that will become apparent later.
"Somethings wrong, magic-ways."
He peers outside the tent.
"Uh oh."

The bulk of the group follows in Jorge’s footsteps.

The ground around the tent quickly cuts off to a sheer cliff in all direction, leaving it essentially a floating island in a purple void.

A smaller platform is suspended nearby; close enough to the tent that it can be reached in one step, but is still clearly separate from the one containing the tent. Further away, a menacing figure is standing on another floating chunk of earth. (Earth as in stone and soil, of course.)

The person outside the tent has their body fully shrouded, wearing leather armor with a cowl as well as a mask in the visage of a human. Surrounding their chest and abdomen is threads in a pattern that weaves across the body like so: :wyrdwyrd:
The figure stares silently. It’s a bit of an open secret who this person is, but for the sake of proper pacing, I will go forward as if they are truly a mysterious masked foe.
Horatius tries and fails to cast a fireball at this “Wyrd”. Throughout the following message, other attempts are made to use magic, but it is for naught. The rules of the space limit such an action.

In speech that sounds like two voices overlaid, words echo throughout the void.

"**My name is Wyrd.** I am he who acts as an enforcer of the karma that cannot be avoided."
Horatius answers this non-question, cleverly devising another alias. "A pleasure to meet you, Wyrd. My name is, uh. Nathan Strider. What the fuck are you doing here?”

"This is a magically constructed nested space of my own making, which abides by specific rules. A pre-condition for its proper functionality is giving an explanation of that very functionality. I value fairness, and doing things in the proper order. I would gain no satisfaction from some sort of disgusting 'sneak attack'."

Bern groans. "An ideologue. Great."
*What exactly is wrong with “dishonorable” attacks? You randomly sprung some trap on us to get us here…*
Wyrd continues, unreactive to anyone else's remarks. "I am here, yet not here. In truth…”

Wyrd continues talking for quite some time. Bern is stuck on this hypocrisy nobody bothered to bring up.
*I mean, is it “fair” because you've given us a chance to react? By that logic, a sneak attack is totally cool so long as I say “surprise” rather than killing you instantly.*

*What’s up with everything right now, actually? Everything about this dude is absurd. “Wyrd”? That’s fate, right? They’re similar concepts. It’s a huge ego trip to name yourself that. Well, unless I’m making assumptions. Like, maybe their parents really did name their son WYRD. Crazy people.*

In truth, no one has been named Wyrd at birth. No one relevant to this story, at least. The physical person that corresponds to this alias is presently occupied with a mundane socially obliged activity, soon to be startled by the activation of a previously placed trap, running quickly away from the view of others.

*I always thought it was silly. No one can ever really explain what they mean by it. Like, is our future set in stone? Absolutely not. Every claim of magic or hocus-pocus nonsense to tell the future is proven bunk every time. Whole world’s too complicated. You can’t account for every factor and for... like, the freedom used by all living things.*
"If you win, this will be avoided.”

*Huh? Wait, shit, is this important? I’ve been spending way too much time thinking to myself. Everyone says I don’t do that enough, though. Assholes, the lot of them. No matter what happens, I always bounce back! So what if I have to take a moment on some things when I'm faster than anyone where it counts?! Okay, wait this definitely is important. Something about ethics? Are we just supposed to talk to him? It really is impossible to take this dude seriously. Everyone seems like they think the mask thing is cool. It isn’t! It just shows you’re insecure. Baby Crippler does the same thing and I don’t get it. At least this guy I can imagine wanting to hide his identity. BC is like… dude, you wear the same thing in public! What are you expecting to happen???? I don’t know if people just assume it’s someone else in the same clothes or what. And that guy from earlier…*
“…the platform.”
“You get all that?” Furn whispers.
“Yeah, more or less.” Bern replies.
“Good. I think I’m going to step up to the challenge.”

Bern nods.

*…What the fuck does mango mode mean?! I’m still stuck on this. Why would he say this? Even as a ‘diss’ or something not meant to be taken literally, what could it possibly mean? It can’t be slang. I have to have heard of it before now, surely! And slang still has some kind of defined origin. Mango… man go… like, he’s gonna make me ‘go’? The man? Is this a threat? Wait, no, he did say his name. Like… Big Man. Or something. So is he the man? And he’s going? Thats weird though because the whole sentence is him saying he’s going this mode. So he’s going the state of him going? That’s like… self reference. Looping.*

*Or is it important that it’s a fruit? The fruit of your labor? Hard work is it’s own reward? Virtue is its own reward? I think mangoes are tropical, so does it have to do with beach? ‘Bitch’?*

*Aggghh!!! I don’t know. It never feels like I get any closer, no matter how much I flip it around in my head. I’ll have to try asking someone else.*

Wress is on the platform.

Nobody else seems comfortable moving for a bit, but Bern shrugs and trudges on after a brief pause. *I can just follow his lead.*

Furn follows. Jorge and Horatius are the last two to board.

The platform moves until it is a reasonable distance from Wyrd. 

"Horatius, how much, if anything, do you know about this fellow?" Wress asks.

Horatius makes an ambiguous expression. "I doubt I know any more than you. From what I've heard, he's killed a fair amount of guys in the past? That's really about it. Not exactly the most helpful information."

*Oh, right. That name HAS come up before.*
Bern remembers the vivid description of the bodies, grimacing.
"Yeah. I don't know much more. But I don't like his vibes. This might be a recurring problem for us." Wress focuses on the enemy. It seems everyone is focused. Everyone else.
Wyrd steps forward. "I am here... now. I can hear you. I cannot see you, but just hearing is enough."
Horatius looks around and cockily responds. "Good for you. So yeah, go ahead. Is childish idealism actually overrated?"

“I would not say so, Mr. Strider. Your folly is not very popular. But I digress.”

*Who is Strider???? Damn. I must have missed more than I thought.* Bern cusses under his breath, earning a half-glance from Furn.

The terrain shifts to have a translucent 3D grid. It aesthetically resembles an Arctican board game that is analogous — but not identical — to Earth’s “Chess”. All present instantly recognize Platagon from their reasonable Arctican background.

Wyrd has been waiting for this for some time, but had prepared a variety of distinct opening remarks to choose from. He ponders the first move.
*They’ve stepped up in terms of more minor infractions as of late. It would be good to start there. It’s not something I’m certain or even likely to win, but it will be a good stage to force them to reveal their tactics and angle.*
Technically, the original writing style I am emulating does not display the thoughts of characters that are not the 'main' one. But is there really any need to abide by this rule?
“Point 1. Your people have caused senseless property damage on a regular basis.” Wyrd summarizes the initial topic.
Bern winces. “Well…” *I guess it’d be rude to make a big deal of that again, right now. Don’t want to throw him under the carriage after we found some kind of resolution.*

The terrain inverts. It makes perfect sense what this means visually. It is the turn of the Gadflies.

Horatius seethes. It’s clear that particular argument didn’t sit well with them. "Property is replaceable; life isn't. Too often people have suffered under our government, driven into terrible circumstances seemingly just for existing, yet that same government turns a blind eye to their pleas. We need to leave a mark to make our voices heard *at all*." They convincingly pretend to have values.

The terrain re-inverts. The figurative ball is on Wyrd's side.

"Okay, but like, I didn't even *mean* for what happened today to--" Bern doesn’t successfully finish his sentence.
"That was good, but we should be more cautious going forward." Wress proposes a more democratic process of agreement on their responses from now on.
"...Yeah, fair enough. I wish I could just walk over there and punch him," Horatius mutters back to Wress.
Bern performs the signature facial expression that conveys "so true", a hallmark of Arctican culture, and really, an incredibly worthwhile inclusion for any one.

Wyrd shoots back. "The government has turned a blind eye towards nothing. The subdivisions of regional authority, the advisors, grassroots petitions, all serve the role of making His Majesty beholden to the desires of others. What hears the voices of no others is a barbaric militia."
*Too easy.* Wyrd considers the response juvenile. *Such an overemotional appeal based on anecdotal biases. Nathan Strider… hmm.*

An image of a Platagon “Fool’s Squech (sic)” metaphysically appears, serving as a metaphor. What a daring dream; to combine the intellectual play of conversation with the recognizable and blunt imagery of board games. It's clear what this means for the progression of the conflict. Wress curses under his breath. "Do we keep going on this point, or try to shift the topic?"

Horatius is getting heated. They and Wress confer for a bit while Bern half-listens. It’s become pretty clear who the protagonists of this encounter are.

Bern thinks about the protagonist.

*What exactly is the deal with Horatius? I’ve felt a vague sense of sorrow… elation... empathy or envy… maybe just a complete apathy towards everything. No one else has ever been quite so difficult to figure out. That’s what they want, I guess. Is it lonely? Being unknown.*

Now is the time for worldbuilding.

The Gadflies, named after a colloquial meaning of the word referring to a philosophical pest that forces you to stay on your toes and question assumptions, are an illegal group. They exist entirely outside of the confines of the law. Some members are essentially career criminals. And many of the older members — Baby Crippler, Richard O’Shay, Umbert, their mole working in the capital — simply got into this “line of work” due to the actions of the group’s former leader, Tebar Hifele. Endlessly charismatic, and able to walk the line between existence within and without the law (thanks to the help of a good lawyer), he brought many otherwise ordinary people to the cause.

But anyone younger than around 30 who decided to run with them? There was almost always a story there.

It was a necessity for Bern, or so he claimed. He was an orphan with stolen government property, and his father already had a lot of enemies in the capital while alive. Where he went, Furn followed.

Wress essentially inherited a spot. His father had high hopes for him, and when that man became no more, there were confident expectations from all the eyes around him. He was born for this. It was a duty he relished, that he crafted his personality and sense of self around.

Eric Dextrum? That guy was just too stubborn. A rich kid given every resource to succeed, he flubbed an incredibly important operation as a novice cleric, leaving the patient worse off than they started. This bought him exile and disbarment from official authorization, and he was lucky to get only that. But by passion for the craft or spite for the world, he wanted to heal people anyway. He turned to groups with much lower standards.

Jorge, another notable person, didn’t talk much about himself. But it was clear from the types of things he did talk about that he had ideological reasons for wanting to join the Gadflies. He abandoned something of a middle class life because of those reasons.

Only Horatius never seemed to betray anything. Bern had his own guesses, and Wress seemed to know based on conversations Bern had overheard. But he’d never risk directly asking.

Horatius shifts back towards Wyrd. "Making oneself open to hear others is meaningless if one doesn't *listen*. Merely presenting the *opportunity* to help isn't enough without taking meaningful action to *do* so, and I know better than anyone the government doesn't have the spine for that. Our group, however, does."

Wyrd falters in his stance. “You… know better than anyone…?” *What specifically does that mean? It wouldn’t be some kind of…*

His side cracks. “S-Shit! I mean… That… counted as my communication with the opposition. A complete non-response. …The first point is yours.”

“I can confirm. The spatial integrity has weakened.” Jorge, though a thoughtful and introspective person, is finding himself outmatched in this time constrained discussion board. He opts to support his allies with the knowledge he does have.

Wress chuckles. “Nice. And it’s hardly a fair game if we’re only on the defensive, yeah?”

Wress points dramatically to the opposition. “Wyrd is a murderer who acts outside the law; a killer with delusions of grandeur unwilling to acknowledge the illegality of his own actions.”

He steps back. “Oh. I just did the thing I told you not to do, huh. Oops.”
Horatius smirks. "That was excellent, though." They cover their own mouth, embarrassed at the earnest expression of emotion.

Wyrd takes some time to respond to this one.

*It’s absurd, obviously. And none can know the full extent of my reasons. But this should be possible to refute even without compromising myself.*

*A life is a precious thing. It is… very difficult to recall one that has ended. Some would say impossible. But the enforcement of order and peace always necessitates the threat of violence be kept on standby. Not used, ideally. But very firmly there. Rehabilitation is a fine idea, but it is not always an option. Our courts often seem uninterested in enforcing ACTUAL justice. With a strong, righteously motivated central government able to keep lawmakers in line, this should be possible to remedy. But right now… that’s not exactly an immediate option. The only way to save anyone is to bypass this entirely. To allow bureaucracy to completely miss the actually significant action.*

*I am not a murderer. I only kill those who have firmly finalized their personal destiny. That is an enforcer, not a killer. Can one blame the blade itself that a warrior wields?*

*…No. I am a murderer. Denying that will get me nowhere. But I wasn’t the first. This world’s rules weren’t put into place by me.*

*Ah, I only have so many words, though. What’s the most important bit to summarize…?*

“I respect the law, but not to the extent of dogmatism. There are things the law is currently incapable of. That is why I am here.”

Bern again takes a passing interest in the debate. His thoughts are not slow, but scattered. He can’t exactly thrive in this sort of a format any more than the likes of Jorge. 
*Who cares about the law? It can be good in specific cases, but that doesn’t warrant “respect”. That’s dogmatism in itself. Laws are only worthwhile in being made by people. And law to apply to everyone under the control of one arbitrary man is near-worthless. Maybe there are leaders you could try to justify -- I doubt it, but maybe. The king isn't one of them. He's literally just some guy.*

Horatius responds with a comparison of Wyrd’s methods to their own. Wyrd stumbles back. “That’s… true. On a surface level, we are not entirely dissimilar. I concede the point.”

“But!” He raises the next topic. “I aim to supplement the law where it could use improvement. You seek to destroy all that exists with no concrete plan.”
Wress fumes. “No concrete… ghrk!” His life’s ambition was being denied in its entirety by someone more-or-less in cosplay.

Horatius takes initiative as the one who prompted a response. "Okay, sure. I do want to tear down those in power for the suffering they've caused, but is there anything inherently wrong with that? 'Supplementing the law' doesn't just mean elaborating on what works! It also needs to be saved from those who abuse it to do harm."
“…Thanks. I wouldn’t have been able to respond so effectively within the rules of this game.” Wress.

Bern adds an impolite aside. “He means he would’ve never shut up if he started talking about this.” Bern is then disapprovingly bopped on the shoulder by his metallic associate, which causes him to eat shit on the ground because of the comical weight difference.

*Ow.* It didn’t actually hurt that much, but Furn apparently underestimated his own strength. *I mean, am I wrong? Everyone was thinking it. Don’t think even Wress would deny it.* He turns over to not be staring at the ground, meeting the gaze of an apologetic-but-not-really Furn. Bern makes an obscene gesture. 
*Now I’m missing more of this. What’s going on? Some guy named Nathan Strider? Uh, okay, so Wyrd already went, and…*

Horatius is currently incredibly mad. Perhaps there are those who exist which would describe their state as ‘owned’. Bern starts paying attention again mid-rant. "Maybe some people do live happily right now. But I know that I DON'T! And I'm sure others feel the same! Just because some people can live happily, are we wrong to desire a better world for ourselves? Are we just a necessary sacrifice?!"
Nobody says anything for a bit. Wyrd considers the circumstances that led here, the scheme to ensnare rebels, the outburst of an anonymous child.

*...Necessary sacrifice.*
*Peculiar. Very peculiar.*

*The propaganda of guerillas and charlatans is easy to dismiss. They slander Aodh Praxis as a caricature of their own fears, as a unilateral obstacle for whatever petty issue they’ve staked lives on. His virtue goes unrecognized by those illiterate swine who’ve probably only ever read his name once.*

*It is more challenging to ignore without further consideration a portrayal of misguided attempts at doing good that only fail. Projection, I’d call it. But in any case, it would be absurd to pretend everything is fine all the time. Equally absurd, however, is denying any positives.*

*The truth is that this nation only truly started to spiral into ruin recently. It had been a prosperous empire, with the few aspects that could be improved in the process of reforming. It is within my lifetime… within the lifetimes of everyone here, even… that everything changed. That was when it became less ridiculous to characterize the state as well-intentioned but ineffective.*

*Where is the nobility that once stood strong above us all? This has given way to weakness. The pathetic incompetent in charge sits idly. Our country is under siege from all angles; and as one nearly entirely isolated, those angles are all originating from within.*
*I wish I had an answer.*

*I cannot say any of this. Though in the abstract the Gadflies as a whole are obviously… fucking scum… the worst of the worst, the downright dregs of society. No one would miss the annihilation of every single sycophantic teat-sucking coward to have been seduced by a lawyer or politician into betraying their own people, into losing all form as they descend into savagery. It would be a mercy to rid the world of that kind of person. Let them be spared the trouble of mourning one another. What, is that too far? Is it not charitable enough to say there are people beyond the point of any redemption, who have forfeited the title of a person? Ridiculous. An extremist position of submission to tyranny.*

*…But that may not describe all of these people here right now. At present, it is true that the situation can look dire. Perhaps some of these people only rationally recognize the same flaws I do, and have taken a misguided approach towards it. Then again, maybe that is the voice of my weakness. My… inherent disadvantage. The softness of my heart. Its dominion over reason. That which would have served domestic affairs better than the eyes of justice. I cannot let them know of that. Though my cause is impeccable, I myself am not, and it is not an option to fully reveal the superiority I possess from the truth. That would lead to the loss of a battle far more important than this one.*

*It is fine. If I can do anything well, it’s talk. Write and talk and write and talk. You were always great at not being active enough, hm? If only you had known your place and not flexed such an underdeveloped muscle. If only you hadn’t shirked what should have really mattered. If only you could earn the love of someone. If only you hadn’t tried to be happy. If only there were…*

*…Enough. The game.*

*Don’t address where they’re right. Address how they’re wrong.*

The vigilante with monarchist sympathies is able to think all of this before anyone speaks. Either because the silence is that long or due to something about time functioning in this space. 

Wyrd is the one who ultimately breaks the silence.
“…Yes. It cannot be denied. There are those left behind by a world that fails them. There always are. I know not what you went through, Nathan. But to deny the possibility that your grievances have a real basis simply because you are positioned as my opponent would be pathetic.”
*Just… a little more to finish this.*

“But the world *is* getting better! You have shut yourself off from experiencing this improvement through your own actions! The thoughtless cruelty of the noble bride system is being revised out of existence year by year. Racial limits on professions are entirely a thing of the past these days! And you would reject all of that, deny and defile it along with our past worth preserving, simply because—“ The other side of the field shatters, leaving Wyrd standing in a black void, his image stuttering and fading away. That was far above the length limit.

“Haha, nice. Trick them into overextending by feigning getting emotional. Classic crafty Horatius.” Jorge, failing to read a room, says this.

Horatius just stands there in silence. They place their hand against their face again, as though they are experiencing an exceptionally painful headache.

Wyrd is resigned to failure.

“If any of you have a death wish… boarding my platform will teleport you to me. Returning to the room you began in will bring you back to reality where you started. That is all.” Wyrd fully vanishes.

“...I’ve got a headache. I’m heading back in.” Bern mutters for only Furn to hear.

Furn turns to face him, but does not respond, and lingers with the others for a bit.

In truth, Bernard Zie just didn't want to deal with whatever denouement was going to follow a moment of vulnerability from various people -- especially Horatius. He was spent for the day, emotionally. It would be nice to just lie back and tend to his hobbies by himself. But he needed to at least see this obligation through, out of politeness.

His head did hurt, though.

*Did Furn really hit me that hard...? And after all that about second-guessing being rude to me. Not that I care, but jeez.*

*Pain is easy. This kind, at least. Still working on the other kind.*
His leg twitches. He makes his way inside the tent, and takes a seat, trying to squeeze whatever micron of comfort he can with his body's current attitude.

*I guess I do appreciate pain, in a sense. Maybe that's what Furn meant. But it's in the sense that everyone does.*

*Struggle is what makes us stronger. And there will always be situations that force us to be strong. So long as you don't go crazy, experiencing some hardship is only healthy.*

*Would Wress be as motivated as he was without the loss he suffered? I guess that's a bad example. Or a good example of the other half, that this can go too far. The only things Wress is emboldened to do are things that were going to be done with what he's lost. In no sense was that a justified sacrifice.*

*What about me? I mean, I love dad, obviously, but would this greater good business I'm doing now have happened without him? Probably not. Is that... man, this isn't something you can weigh. It's nonsense to think about. It sucks that my father is dead. Obviously.*

*Maybe that's why people turn to bullshit like 'Wyrd'. Some stuff just isn't worth thinking about but doesn't let you find a clear resolution. So bam, it happens because it does and its fine, whatever.*
Everyone else enters the tent, finally.
The entrance to the tent flutters open to show a grassy exterior, making it clear they've returned to reality.
"Are we fuckin finally ready to start?" Bern asks, planting his head onto the table in exasperation.
"We should be." Wress confirms the meeting will progress further towards its conclusion momentarily. He shuffles some papers left behind where he sat before the interruption.
Bern takes a deep breath. *I guess I should cut him a little slack. Nobody could’ve predicted that. We just…*
He decides to raise his head, to move his position back to normal. But before the signal can even reach his body… Bernard Zie ceases to exist.
__CHAPTER 1 - END__
**2. Questions**
Bernard Zie’s first thought was that they had been tricked. All of them.

The whole Wyrd debacle had only just ended, after all, and suspiciously at that. Perhaps once everyone’s guard was down, Wyrd activated some kind of… explosive? That would explain why he lost consciousness, why every part of him ached, why he was in… a hospital bed?

Bern strains to sit up.

“Hey! No, don’t do that. Not yet. You still have to recover.” An unfamiliar voice. Bern hazily turns towards it and, sure enough, does not recognize this person. “I’m… surprised to see you up, honestly.”
Bern asks the first of many questions on his mind. “Where… am I?”
“In the clinic. I don’t think your wounds are anything serious.”

He’d have to ask about wounds in a second, but…
“Who are you?”
“Yeah. Head got hit pretty hard, I guess. Or maybe you can’t see well? I’m not a doctor. Uh. It’s me, Eric Zeety.”
*That is the fakest sounding name I’ve ever heard.* It clearly wasn’t Dextrum, at least. That would have been a bit more understandable.

"I don’t… believe we’ve met. I—" He paused. Something felt off, and it wasn’t being wounded. Everything was a little… askew. Like someone had mixed up all his insides with a blender. They all still functioned and retained the necessary connections, but an underlying harmony has been fundamentally disrupted.
Actually, he didn’t feel *that* bad. It should still be possible to move…

*What… the fuck am I wearing?* Bern, as he slides out of the bed, catches a brief glance of the unfamiliar clothes he’s been fitted with, then turns back to stare at them after registering something was off.
“You don’t… Okay, what exactly do you mean by that?” Eric Zeety asked, confused.
It really wasn’t his style. *Bougie.* He hazily ran through possibilities. *Did the attack, like… damage my outfit? I guess they thought it would be polite to, uh…*
It was the jewelry, for some reason.
Not the body.
Bern noticed, with a slightest of perturbances in his weight distribution, that he was wearing earrings.
Did someone… put earrings on him? They’d have to pierce his ears first, for one.

Even in the most bizarre, niche circumstances; some kind of attack which injured him, burned all his clothes, and knocked him unconscious before he could even register it happened, preceded by him being taken for healing to a room he’s never seen to be tended to by a man he doesn’t know (coincidentally bearing the same first name as one he does), who saw fit to cover his shame… there is *no reason* anyone would do that.
Bern was incapable of rationalizing it. He never even attempted to do so. Any semblance of an internal monologue or something which can be simplified into one cuts off here.

And as Bernard Zie finally realizes a certain set of contradictory circumstances, a shift in his weight, in his field of view when looking down, we understand he was right. No one would ever do that to ‘Bernard Zie’s body’.

I may tend towards acknowledgement of physically verifiable material reality, but I think it would also be disingenuous to switch things like pronouns at this point, which is why I will not. It amounts to a technicality, when the existence of this “Alternative” is already tacit acknowledgment that the person in this body right now is the same person as the one in Bernard Zie’s body in 1. That it is the body of a woman is no more relevant than it being a different body at all.
As we were, then:
__***"FUUUUUSCCCKHHHYAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAGHHHGHHUUUUUGGHHHGGGHGGGH!!!!!!!!!!!!"***__

Bern lets out a primal, incomprehensible roar, a failed amalgamation of multiple words and non-words. As someone already unreliable at grasping even situations that *do* follow a logical progression, it was all he could do.

Someone else’s face contorts into a hideous expression, the body of a different person shaking. Its wrong hands coil as far as they can around its incorrect torso, following a disgusting arrangement of flesh and muscle as its unacceptable legs threaten to give out. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay. Not okay.

*Some kind of sick... joke....?*

“What… is this…?” He finally lets out an actual set of words, sputtered between agonized gasps.
“Um… you…” The other man in the room struggles to respond.

Bern slows his breathing a little. *No… even if… this is some torture mindgame… even if I’m already surrounded by the enemy and defeated… I will die standing before I even consider kneeling!*

He pivots to face directly towards the man, peculiarly colored unkempt hair covering half his(*) face as his pupils, the window to the soul, seem to vibrate out of his skull. Eric Zeety stares into the abyss of raw hatred, and is less than pleased with what he finds. He takes a step back, nervous.

"What did you do." Bernard Zie manages to speak this short sentence with complete calm. Someone seeing this isolated moment in time might think this a regular exchange between the two. But in context, Eric did not understand.
"W...hat? I brought you over to this..."
Adrenaline brings the capacities of man into overdrive.

"WHAT DID YOU DO?!"
Bernard Zie should not have been capable of moving so fast, woozy, off his balance, unprepared, in a completely new environment in every sense of the word.
But move he did. He slams the only possible target for his anxieties against the wall Eric had so graciously backed towards.
"I...." Eric considers his choices carefully.

Bern grabs him by the shoulders with both hands, on the verge of crushing him. "You.... you think you're clever? What's your source, huh? Been researching us...? Oh, that little fag ought to be easy pickings for information... a real public spectacle misfit! Hm????!"

Eric blinks many times in quick succession.
"Um. ...What are you fucking talking about?"

Bern grinds his very bones against the hard foundation of the building, having returned to shaking slightly. 
*My legs, they....*

 The thighs brush against one another.

"NGGAAAAHHH!" 
Bern stops focusing on pushing, and instead quickly adjusts his position to be grasping Eric's neck. "I want answers! You have five seconds to save your miserable life, alright!?"
"Huh?"
"Five!"
"I don't understand what you--"
"Four!"
"Look, just slow down, I'm sure we--"
"Three!"
"Fuck's sake, I can't die here, man!"
"Two!"
"Look, it's a good bit, Voreverl! You've spooked me! Now--"
Bernard Zie cannot take another sentence he is incapable of parsing, and seeks the more imminent satisfaction of slamming a fist against this man's face.

It's less of an impact than desired thanks to the less than ideal circumstances, and no wound is left, but it still should've hurt quite a bit.

Eric Zeety is furiously blushing with an inscrutable expression he is attempting to suppress.

Bern, disgusted, throws him on the ground. "Useless. It's obvious, isn't it?"
"This is a dream. Fine."
"Or nightmare. ...So all I have to do is wake myself up." He logically, debatably, pieces together something that resembles a solution.
"I don't tend to have ones where I'm aware...." Having accepted the current situation as not real, he paid no mind to idly talking out loud. Eric has decided not to stand up again for now.
"Usually it works when you die, though, right?"
Eric looks up. "Hey, um, don't do anything... I just would like to hear what you're going for right now."

Bern does not pay attention to him. "Is the door locked...?" He pulls the exit from this room open, confirming the contrary.

"Okay. Good, good. There has to be some object or place..."
He walks directly out the door, ignoring the wet floor sign in the hallway, and trips forward onto the already damaged skull he resides within.
Bernard Zie loses consciousness, in a comedic blunder to start a long series of such occurrences. Eric stares at his fallen comrade or whatever word would be used to describe them.

And he walks over to look down at the body. Or, I do. I prefer this perspective of narration, if it's all the same to you. 
"Damn." I say, looking at him.
