messages.content: Okay.

I could maybe continue along that line of examination. To speak of the discovery of the body, the way those around him would go on to mourn and cope with the loss of someone they considered close. Even someone out of the ordinary warrants those who care about them. Such a relationship is neither real nor illusory.

But such a thing would be even more outside the scope of Alternative than we’ve already gone. A motif has been established, but following it will come later.

Returning to chapter 2 first ought to involve a clarification of what chapter 2 is. 

Bernard Zie does not experience the same sequence of events as either those participants originating from Earth or from Arctica. In general, chapter switches occur whenever any transfer does, but a more formal definition is impossible because these two worlds do not follow a coherent synchronized chronology. Division of the chapter happening ‘while’ a certain participant stays in the same realm will feel arbitrary, which is why no organization bothered with such a thing prior to 5.

The current time for Bernard Zie is late in the day on May 16, 2022.

Based on the typically consistent rules, while Bernard Zie entered chapter 2 upon being transported to Earth (lining up with those from Earth being transported to Arctica), he should increment by another chapter when those from Arctica transport to Earth, leading him to be in chapter 3 while they are in chapter 2, and putting him one chapter ahead of everyone from then on. This would be incredibly foolish, however, so I will instead extend 2 for him until it is complete overall, with the beginning of chapter 3 for the earth participants.

Hopefully this makes sense to everyone.

Bernard Zie wakes up on Earth again, same as before.

This time, he’s ready. He springs out of the bed. And Eric, of course, is still there.

I’d like to tell you what Eric is thinking, but unfortunately, such a thing seems to be a non-option.
Eric, having recovered himself at this point, standing in front of Bern, slowly, lazily drags up his arm and points at him. “Who are you?”
Bern mutters something indecipherable, confused by the question and wondering how to approach this.

“I’m not dumb, alright? There’s some inferences I’m capable of making about the world. I’ve gone through my fair share of mystery stories. This… is the body of my friend Voreverl Leocot, lying in a bed. But you are not her. I’m asking for a name.”
“Hah. …Bernard Zie. Just Bern is fine.” *Even in the worst case scenario, there’s nothing secret about my name.*
“Right then. Hello, Bern. I assume you remember me. Do you have memories from prior to today?”
He hesitates. This is the kind of interrogation he *was* fearing. “That’s none of your damn business.”
“Yes, then.” Eric nods to himself, an infuriatingly self-satisfied act in Bern’s eyes. “Just one last question about ‘you’…”
He sighs. “No delicate way to say this. …Are you uncomfortable in the body you’re currently in?”
“What? Yeah! Why the fuck wouldn’t I— I mean, yeah, it’s…” Bern speaks without thinking.

Eric shakes his head. “That’s all I needed to know. It would be pointless to try to press you or dispute what’s real. I’m sorry for your current predicament, and I feel I can make a pretty good case for not being responsible for it.”
“Try me.” Bern staggers onto his feet again.
“Why would *anyone* do this, for one? It seems like it’d have to be a freak accident.”
“Not good enough. Lot of people are crazy.” Bern glares at him again.

“Well, by that rationale, it could literally be anyone for no reason, and I can never hope to convince you anything. I mean, people don’t work that way. They have motivations. Look, just… what specifically are you even accusing me of doing? If you’re right, then the worst case scenario is you’re just telling me something I already know, right? Y’know?” Eric desperately tries to find some ground to stand on.
*Ghrk. I can’t think of any way he could be wrong, but it still feels like I’m being tricked…* “I’d guess interrogation. Put me in a bad situation so I’ll talk to get out of it.”
“Well, I have no idea how to ‘get you out’ of ‘this’. And I’m not sure what information I’d need from you — don’t even really know ‘who’ you are. Like, what, information about where you live?”
“About the fuckin’ rebellion, obviously!” Bern slams his forehead and palm against one another, out of exasperation with Eric that quickly becomes exasperation with himself.
Eric has no real intense reaction to this statement. “The woman that body belongs to already gets into way more trouble than whatever it is you’re talking about.”

“This… body…” At risk of dwelling on his irreconcilable physical reality, Bern decides to distract himself by leaving through the unlocked door, then picking a random direction in the hallway that happens to lead outside.
“Hey, wait up!” Eric Zeety whines.
*Wow. I’m a lot more creative than I thought if this is a dream.* Bern thinks.

His current location was… some kind of holding facility for different beasts, with massive buildings visible in the distance. “Where is this, Eric Z?” Bern asks the man he can hear walking up from behind.
“You… don’t know? Uh. Bioparco. Rome. In Italy, obviously. I guess a lot of other places have a city called Rome…”
“Never heard of it.” Bern mutters, wandering through the zoo.
“Never… the fuck do you mean?” Eric half-whispers.
“How could your guys have gotten me all the way here from Burdlt?” Bern asks, still not looking at Eric.
“You’re still insinuating I’m responsible for something?? Jeez!”

Bern laughs.

Eric is annoyed that the dynamic of control seems to have shifted so quickly. “Oh, now you’re mocking me too? Well, whatever!”
“No, not really.” Bernard Zie muses. “I just think you sound like a little kid when you’re upset. It sort of goes against the type of words you’re using. Which is funny.”
“A kid…” Eric mumbles, vaguely annoyed. “That sounds like mocking to me.”
Regardless of how Eric felt about it, the schadenfreude did seem to have loosened Bern up a little. “Say I believe your version of events. Where is this person who this body ‘belongs to’ now?”
“Huh? How should I know? I think alters just… don’t exist during that period of time… if we treat this as that sorta situation.”
“Maybe she’s in my body…” Bern speculates.
“*Your* body?” Eric asks, acting befuddled.
“Yes, obviously. Of course I have a body. A friggin… a male one! Look, let’s just… could you do me a favor?” He seemingly loses the majority of his energy and anger in a short burst.

“I guess. Either you’re my friend or you’re someone caught in a very unfortunate situation, and I’ll help either way. Being generically helpful is kind of my role, y’know.” Eric places a hand on Bern’s shoulder. “Do you need something?”
“Could you, uh, show me around this place? If this is a dream, I’d like to pass the time by until I wake up…” Bern uncomfortably staggers through this request.
“Haha. Okay. Sure.” Eric smiles.
And so it went.
There’s really no need to provide a play-by-play; the use of Alternative is to restrict focus to only what matters.
This is a project, not a story. And if it were a story, it would certainly not be a “slice-of-life” one.

A brief summary of the next few hours:
- Eric and Bern discuss random anecdotes, mostly irrelevant. Eric learns Bern claims to be from somewhere called Arctica, but does not pursue the topic further aside from mentioning the word “Antarctica”
- The two gawk at non-human animals. Eric is incredibly passionate about most of them, though is slightly upset that Bern seems much more intrigued by the decorative foliage set up in the enclosures.
- Internally, Bern compares Eric Zeety to Eric Dextrum and decides that, precluding any future betrayal, he likes the former more
- Bernard Zie stares at a globe in incredible confusion

So on and so forth. It’s only tangentially relevant to the mystery or main topic.

The day reaches its end.

“…Yeah, that is pretty funny.” Bern concedes to the joke, having had it properly explained.

“Thanks. Though it definitely needs some work if I need to explain it. I’ll think about how to rephrase it…” Eric looks up at the night sky. The two are both seated on a bench right outside the premises of the Bioparco di Roma.
“Hey… Why was I in that clinic, injured? What happened before that? Or what do you claim, at least.” Bern remembers to add the insurance of implicitly not accepting all Eric’s words.
“You got owned. Or, uh, she did.”
“Slavery…” Bern ruminates, incredibly confused as this information clears up nothing.
“What the fuck?”
“What?”
“No, I mean like…” Eric gestures with his hands. “Knocked the fuck out. Totally defeated. Beat up. KO’d.”
“Oh. By what?”
Eric grimaces. “Just… some girl.”
“Who?” Bern does not let it go.
“Wouldn’t you just say you don’t recognize the name?!” Eric complains.
“Well, if I *do* recognize it, wouldn’t that be a massive bit of info about why this is happening?”
Eric sighs. “Violetta Esposito. She’s… just some guy. It doesn’t matter.”

Bern closes his eyes and faces downward in a cartoonish exaggerated motion that could be associated with the concept of ‘thinking’.
“…Nope, never heard of her.”
“Figures.” Eric is ready to come up with some new topic to switch to, but does not get the chance.
“Should I take revenge…? Feels weird since, I mean… don’t really think about it as something done to *me*.”
“Revenge? No, what?” Eric stares at him.
“What about you? It was your friend who got ‘owned’.”
“Eh? N-no, it’s… look, the situation is complicated, and she’s already been arrested for aggravated assault.”
“Arrested? Jeez. Seems like small pickings for that kind of attention.” Bern whistles in a manner customary to indicate ‘what a large amount of something or significant scope!’.
“Yeah, well, Mattarella needs to pander to those tough on crime voters.” Eric snidely comments on politics.
“Voter?” Bern, who in addition to being a foreigner lives in a de-facto absolute monarchy, does not understand any of the implications of that last remark.

This exchange will also be greatly abridged, because Eric gets much more into the minutiae of Italian politics than is actually relevant for either us or Bern. The gist is that Bernard Zie is told of a system where leaders are, at least somewhat, chosen directly by the people, and theoretically anyone is eligible to become that leader. He finds this interesting, and again wonders where the hell he is if this place is actually real.
“It’s late.” Eric notes the time.
“Guess so, yeah.” Bern is unfamiliar with many things, but the concept of the night is not one. He curls up onto his end of the bench, again trying not to think about his body.
Eric stares at this, a not very lively reaction. “What… are you doing?”

“Gonna try to sleep, obviously. Maybe then this nightmare’ll end. Oh, wait, can you get us back in that hospital place? That’s probably safer and more comfortable.” Bern admonishes his foolishness for not thinking of that.
“No, I… well, yeah, I *could* try to get back in there, but you should just… go home…?”
“I don’t have any home here. No idea where the hell this is.”
“I mean, Voreverl does. Just… probably best to sleep there. You should still have your keys, right?”

Bern checks his pockets, an action he had not thought of before now. There’s indeed a set of keys, as well as what you’d expect someone to generally be carrying on their person. He grimaces at the ID photo.

Also notable is two mysterious boxes that vex him. One is able to light up and show the time and some words, but seems to have some barrier placed around its inner workings. The other doesn’t do anything. Just a useless hunk of metal. He keeps it just in case, though.

“Where do… I live…?” Bern asks, embarrassed.
“Well, y…I mean, obviously *I* wouldn’t know that, we’re just coworkers, so I’ve never even been to where she lives. Why would I know that? I don’t.” Eric explains.
“Then bench it is.” Bern rolls over.
Eric sighs. “No, I’m not gonna let you… what if it rains?”
“I can just go under the bench. Easy.”
“Just… I have a couch in my home. Also a roof. Surely it’s better than this.” Eric stares at the impressively low standards he seems to have.
“Sure. I won’t owe you because you’re not real, anyway.” Bern springs up at the mention of a softer surface to mooch off of.
“Yeah, great, whatever.” Eric.

The two make their way to the modest (quite lousy, really) dwelling of one “Eric Zeety”.

“Where… *actually* is this?” Bern asks one final time, making himself comfortable on the so-called couch, which is actually a sofa.
“I don’t know what to tell you that I haven’t already.” Eric packs away some things for the next workday. “If you don’t believe me, sorry, but I’m not up for debating you about if Italy exists.”
“Not that. Just… that sphere map. This whole place is… weird. Is it all under the control of the guy you mentioned? Mozzarella?”
“What, the whole of Earth? No.” Eric adds a bitter aside. “Thank god.”
“The what?” Bern jolts to attention.
“The… planet? Earth?” Eric sighs. “We can talk tomorrow, if you’re still not back to normal. I’m exhausted, okay?” He wanders off.

*How could… Earth…* Bern recalls many things he’d stored deep within his memories, every detail he could muster. He was tempted to pursue Eric and force him to offer more info right now no matter what… but exhausted was a good descriptor for him too. He slowly sits up.
*I can’t believe… after all this time. I can finally do something right.*
*I will make you proud, dad.*

Bern yells a few questions to Eric; about history, about what exactly phones are, about where Earth is, about what to do when he wakes up, etc etc, until Eric stops responding entirely out of annoyance, the door to his room locked.

Bern finds something that looks like a writing implement lying around.

*Hm.*
*This isn’t a dream. It’s real. The earth… the earth is real!*

*And that means it follows real rules. Like magic.* He hadn’t been able to use any earlier; probably a weakness of this body. *So this is as I thought in the beginning. A simple bit of soul manipulation.*

*It won’t last forever. And when it ends…*

Bernard Zie starts writing, slowly and carefully. He hasn’t actually had to write for a very long time, and it was using hands that are not his. Needless to say, he would not win any awards for penmanship.

A pen. A random bit of paper; hopefully not a vital form for Eric. A mind full of energy and passion.

> *Voreverl Leocot -*
> That is your name, yeah? It's what stuff on your person seems to indicate and what other people have attested to. It doesn't feel like a real name to me? But I guess I know nothing about what is normal here.
> I'm Bernard Zie. 
> …
__CHAPTER 2 - END__
*2.5 - PARENTING*
I have been explicitly tasked with “maneuver(ing) around the scribblings of a braindead infant”, and I’m not one to shy away from a request.

The most natural way to contextualize the morning and demise of Dagte Moment meaningfully is to continue the implied trend. Consistently; none of the way halves have been scrawled into the main chapters. And the topic of it… we follow the trend. A specific type of event for a specific type of person. Yes, that should work. I hold quite the fondness for patterns and reiterated motifs.

First, or perhaps second, we must head to somewhere on Earth. To a luxurious estate that, in spite of housing crises, humans have left largely unoccupied. But it is staffed in proportion to what little occupancy it has. With a generous estimation; there are probably more people employed than their duties demand at this point in time.
“This point in time” being the key. While 1.5 began within days of the start of TAP, this is over a decade prior to the world of 2022. The location? Brazil.

Our protagonist… such a term has always vexed me. I’m using it to illustrate such a thing; that no real record should ever have focus that skewed. (Though this record is not entirely real.) 1.5 had a very clear “protagonist”, and likely would have even if there was not literally only one person present and named.

Here… perhaps there is a right answer. But I will instead introduce who we will be spending a significant amount of time in the space of: a woman working as a servant for a wealthy client. Perhaps you could call her that, and she was treated by the likes of a cook or maid or janitor as though she was on the same level as them. But her actual job role involved a specialty in dealing with the youth; involved acting as a tutor. Let us call her Joan; the name isn’t actually very relevant.

In concept, Joan’s position would be a bit more prestigious than a common butler. But in practice, it was far more denigrating. It required interaction with the most unfortunate members of the upper class (who already have a less than stellar reputation in interacting with those they deem lesser than them (a category that can include anywhere from almost everyone to absolutely everyone)), the young ones who have not yet learned of decorum and the bare minimum of PR competence required for the rich to keep getting richer. Those who, Joan thinks, don’t know what struggle is. Unlike a typical employee of an estate, she was not merely to serve her clientele; she had to *challenge* them. And in many cases, this escalated an attitude of dismissal to one of outright hatred. She has learned and adapted over the years to compensate for this, developing a persona of a meek, cloying, incredibly kindhearted pushover who is “just asking questions” and “only trying to help”. It was starting to mess up her normal social interactions, actually, but that’s not relevant to our current setting.

Even going in with such a background… This… was easily the *worst* job she had ever been given. And she was explicitly their last hope. They’d tried cheaper options prior to contacting her; the fools. But months of this with no progress had taken its toll.
Joan skillfully, without flinching, catches a book right in front of her face.
“GEEEETTTT OUT! OF! MY ROOM!” The child screams, ready to throw another.

Possibly, at least. Since actually ‘writing dialogue’ for this person is something of a cardinal sin, it should be reiterated that this is an ‘Alternative’. I am reconstructing this scenario based on all accessible information as well as my own prowess, but I can make no guarantee that these literal words and phrases were exchanged. The unknowable details are of my own creation.  At the very least, this *kind of thing* happened. That I assure you. Some other parts of Alternative will be much closer to certain.
“Madam—“ Joan starts another attempt at deescalation.

“SHUT UP! Just shut up!!! Do you think you can fool me with your stupid little words of pity? You’re just another idiot paid to be here!!! Too much, really! You haven’t once said anything to me I couldn’t just find online. Why should I even keep you around?!”

*You little brat. You think your technology can provide anything but lies and time-wasting? I’ve been an expert for longer than you’ve been alive, longer than that sort of thing’s been around. Who the hell even let this girl access such a thing? I—*
She takes a deep breath. “I understand, Miss Furuda, and this is certainly an unreasonable situation. I apologize for my lack of competence in education.”
“At least you admit it.”
“But you must understand that this is all for you. High hopes and expectations are placed upon your ability to succeed at such a challenge.”
“By who?” The child smirks.
“By… those who care about… such a, ah…” Joan stumbles over her own words and fails to progress, a common issue with her mustn’t-be-too-hasty constructed personality.

“Was it father? Fine. Have him come and tell me, yell at me for being such a bad kid. I’ll deal with it.” Her expression falters. “Ha. You can’t even respond with a lie about him, can you? I’ve completely bested you. He would never… bother to…” She looks on the verge of tears, really. Pitiful.

Joan, a bitter, cynical woman, takes a deep breath and remembers that this is, despite everything, a child. One with somewhat uniquely unfortunate circumstances, too. Monetary concerns are not nearly as much of a factor for those yet to enter adulthood, and it is unlikely her soul was ever soothed by the financial privilege she had. It would be ridiculous to chastise her at the current moment. Empathy was needed, not discipline. Joan approaches the girl to provide some sort of comfort or reassurance.
But she herself is instead embraced by the corner of a textbook to the skull. “LEAVE!!!!” The girl screeches.
“You ratty god damn little bitch! You seriously fucking think I have a choice? I—“ Joan regains her composure, assesses her injury. “…As you wish.” She quickly leaves the room.

Shutting the door behind her, Joan lets out a deep sigh.
“Fuck. Fuck. Fuck.” This would be terrible if it got out. She… *Ugh.* She didn’t know what to do.

It was an open secret that among That Man’s employees both direct and indirect there was a watchdog system of mutual snitching and questioning  to allow someone to be let go if it was determined they had wronged him, or in this case, wronged the territory lord of this house. Given her temperament, this happened pretty often.
*…But she’s the only one who knows. I just need to make sure she doesn’t complain…*
Attempting to think of something, Joan wanders downstairs. “…Hello, Armando. How’s dinner coming?” She greets the chef.
“Bellissimo.” Armando is not Italian. “And-a you?” He eyes her forehead. Clearly the scuffle is visible on her person.

Joan sighs, wiping her brow. “I don’t even know why we’re trying. You… you make sense, everybody’s gotta eat. But she won’t die without being properly educated, and she’s obviously having none of it. You can lead a horse to water, but you can’t make it think.”

“Ah, but-a only us on the ground level know-a how hard it is. The master of the house is quite easy to underestimate, haha!” Armando laughs.
“It’sa up to us to persist in orders anyway.”

“That’s easy enough for you to say. The better I do my job, the *worse* things get. I think she’s realized her dad’s a deadbeat that abandoned her, and anything resembling an authority figure just enrages her. Something like that, probably. I’m good at rolling with punches, but I’m not a therapist.”

“Eheh… well, hesa very busy man, you see…” Armando awkwardly stutters through an excuse. It’s clear he has his own opinions, but does not wish to chance badmouthing the man who is technically their financial employer. He sighs. “Look, Joan-a. Joan. I know you’re having a rough time, but you’ve basically got perfect job security here. This comes down to the law. You can’t just not put a kid through public education. …But that’s just my understanding.”
“Do you know anyone who would understand better?” Joan seems particularly interested in this issue suddenly.

“Eh? Well, um, you could always check-a with our employers about the motive for hiring you… oh! Or Sharona. That girl is-a clever when you need her, and she often knows why the big man does-a what he does.”
“Yeah, okay, thanks Armando!” Joan suddenly rushes to wrap up this conversation.
“Best of luck.” Armando continues his trek to the pantry.
Joan takes a seat in one of the many basically entirely empty rooms in this building. *What a waste, really.*

Joan had decided, though. She’d be able to quit this job and prevent Erica from ever having a reason to complain about her again by eliminating the need for her entirely, or convincing the relevant persons there wasn’t one.

She first calls the man who hired her directly. He doesn’t pick up. He responds with a text saying he can’t talk right now, but she should really be directing all her questions to the man himself. She hesitantly calls the number that she was indeed given upon being hired. No response, as she expected. *Is he even actually busy? The last actual time I remember hearing about something he did was in the 90s. Whatever.*

She calls her legal advisor that she met during a different job. We can pretend he’s named Richard Ogden, if we’d like. He picks up and is very polite, explaining, with the preface that he’s no expert on Brazilian law, how this sort of thing generally works. She thanks him and hangs up, still no closer to an answer to her own predicament.

Joan sighs deeply and agonizingly slowly. Perks of being in a room where no one is close enough to hear you. *Armando’s intuition is usually right… So unless I’m just gonna sit back and accept a career failure, I need to at least try and chance an encounter with… her.*
There were six people in the building right now.

One of them was its only inhabitant. Beyond her, there were currently 9 people employed in some regard that gave them reason to enter the grounds. All had clear reasons for being hired. For food, for cleanliness, interactions with the inhabitant of the house, general maintenance and security… yes, they all had a role to play, and you could tell what it was for each of them almost immediately, even just by how they dressed.

Except one. At least one, that is. Sandra swears she saw someone wandering as though they belonged here who couldn’t have been any of the staff she knew of, and the entire atmosphere of this place was always dreaded. But ghost stories aside, there was a single concrete person with a vague job description.

This was far from the only disconcerting thing about Sharona Erveza. Her mother, Bonita, had worked for the family for quite some time, apparently. And her daughter followed that same kind of career path. But just a week into Sharona’s employment at some estate held by him, Bonita abruptly resigned and withdrew from public life. This was especially unusual. The actual, proper family originating with those sired via his actual wife had plenty of need for assistance, and it was much more common for aging servants who had already earned trust to be transferred into low-effort, cushy and well-paying positions as thanks rather than retiring.

This led to rumors abound, plenty of ghost stories once more. That he KILLED HER, all to ensure the fear and compliance of Sharona. Or that they were lovers and that spiraled into chaos. That one was easier for Joan to believe, really.

Soon after, Sharona was transferred here. To the man’s forgettable rejects bin. And she didn’t… *do* anything. She’d perform some tasks now and then, and she always claims she was just in the middle of something. But mostly… she stayed in one place, if she was able to be found at all.

The stairs creak beneath Joan’s feet. The dim lights to this basement turn on; this place had seen better days, and would later on also see better days. It was at its most decrepit right around now, essentially.
*The… wait, the lights? I guess she’s not down here then. Right?* Joan thinks.

She jumps back upon descending enough to be able to see where Sharona is sitting. *Just sitting completely still in the dark? What the fuck is wrong with her? And what the hell does Armando think that she’d be able to…* To Joan… she looked more like one of those oversized dolls, like a statue, from a distance than anything alive.
“Hello.” She turns to face Joan.
“Oh, um… hi, Sharona.”
“Yes.” She nods.

*What kind of response to a greeting is that?* Finally more annoyed than unnerved, she decides to pick on the girl a little. “Lemme guess, I JUST caught you taking a breather from cleaning the pantry?” She asks in a mocking tone.

“I think you would regard that kind of claim as disingenuous, so I won’t make one. If you take issue with the manner of my employment, I hope you are well aware of the proper persons to report that concern to. I can tell you in the event you aren’t.” She withdraws a book from underneath the chair she is seated on and flips through to the middle of it.
“No, that’s a no-go. We all know you don’t do jack here, and I’m sure half of us have mentioned it. But you’re still around. Why?”
“Did you come here for the purpose of asking that?” Sharona speaks calmly, but Joan could swear there was some kind of subtle intonation to it.
She groans, utterly exhausted from the day already, and makes her way down to Sharona.

“To speak in my favor, I do contribute where I can, either down here or at nights. I am sorry you are not happy with me.” She smiles. Joan thinks for a second she’s winking, but it is in fact an asymmetrically staggered blink of both eyes. It looks absolutely bizarre.

“You don’t get to just pick and choose when you do anything!”
Joan wasn’t even sure why she cared so much. It’s not like there was any overlap with her own duties.
“Correct. My movement is restricted.”
“…What?”
“I apologize for the difficulty. This is an unprecedented conversation for me. No one has ever directly expressed grievances to me.”
“Is that so…” Joan murmurs.
Sharona nods. “It is more common to just silently find me unpleasant and disgusting. Perhaps I simply smell bad.”
“No, uh, that’s not… what?” Joan has already lost control of the conversation.
She stares at Joan. “That was
a joke.”

“I humorously imply the reason is a simple physical reality rather than more complex social strata. In addition, this is literally something to be considered, since people tend to be unable to accurately gauge that about theirselves.”
“You smell… fine.” *Why am I reassuring her on this?*
“Joan, I think there is a reason you came here aside from commenting on my situation. You have not been as aggressive as someone with the primary goal of pushing on that front would be.”
“I… yes, that’s true. I need your help. Or to know if you can help. Armando seemed to think so…”
“Would you like to take a seat? I understand if you’d prefer to be able to talk down to me, though.”
“Huh? Okay…” Joan pulls a folding chair from against the wall and sits down in it.
“I am happy to assist in whatever capacity I can.” Sharona grits her teeth in some attempt at an open mouth smile.
“G-Great.” Joan decides to let whatever is happening right now slide. “So… you know about my job, right?”
“Yes. You interact directly with Erica Furuda as an educator.”
“Yeah… well, I hate to be rude, but she’s a bit of a fucking mess. I—“
“Pardon.” Sharona interrupts the account of events. “I will allow you to finish, but I simply want to clarify something now.”
“Hm?”
Sharona curls her upper lip in confusion. “What exactly did you say she was?”
*Oh, shit. Fuck. I know she probably has a weird connection with the boss somehow… would that have screwed up my chances?* “Oh. It’s nothing, I’m just a little frustrated is all…”

“I am not concerned with the sentiment with which you spoke or how important you deem it. I am literally wondering what it is you said.” Sharona focuses her gaze on Joan intently, nonetheless with intents that are wholly unclear.
*Did she just not hear me?* “I mean… I don’t want to be rude, and of course I understand she’s just a child, but I called the madam kind of a mess. From the perspective of a teacher, at least.”
“You did not say that. That is not what you said.” Sharona corrects this error, without any hostility in her tone.
“What? O-Okay, yes… I was a little rude, I’m sorry.”
“I am not asking for an apology. What did you say?”
“…” *…Huh? What does… she mean?*
“You used a word I have not heard before. I want to make sure I’m not missing out on vital context before you continue telling me what you want to say.”
“Fucking…?” Joan blurts without thinking.
“Yes. I have not heard that before. What does it mean?”

*What the fuck?*

Joan stares at Sharona, overcoming the inherent disdain looking at her creates. Just from her body alone, it was clear that the youngest she could *possibly* be as ‘developed’ as she was would be 16. Joan’s understanding was closer to 19. *And yet she’s claiming to not even know any foul language?*

“No one has ever said this in my presence, nor has it been in any texts I have read. I do not own a dictionary, and I am not allowed to access the internet. That leaves me with only you as a resource to ask. I apologize for the inconvenience.”
*There’s something wrong with this girl…* “It’s just… to accentuate the extent of how difficult she is, and my own intense feelings about it.”
“I see. Like ‘very’. Go on.” Sharona nods.

Joan tries to ignore how incomprehensible the past minute has been. “Well… I mean, I don’t have to spell it out, right? You’ve probably interacted with her before. I can’t say I don’t understand why, but… She’s a jerk.” Joan struggles to spit that last part out.

“I’m sorry, but as a servant of this family, I cannot engage in mockery or insulting of its members and my benefactors. If you need help with something other than this sort of mockery-based-camaraderie, feel free to request it from me.”

“Uh… okay.”

The two are both silent for a bit.

“I want to quit.” Joan gives up on subtlety. She’d already shit-talked the master of the house in front of her, there was no way things could get any worse.
“That is unfortunate. Can you describe what particular about you experience working here unsatisfactory?”
*There were, uh, definitely some words missing from that last sentence…* “I just did.”
“My apologies. You did. Of course. So it has to do with—the behavior of Erica Furuda?”

“In part. I just…” Joan decides to explain her motives as more selfless than they really are. “I feel awful leaving when they are relying on me so much. I wanted to make sure I only left with everything in order. Like, if perhaps I could inform her father of some alternate method of getting Miss Furuda through federal education requirements…” It dawned on Joan the absurdity of asking the creepy basement dweller for this. “I suppose I just wanted someone to talk or vent to, sorry…”
 *It IS weirdly easy to speak openly to her… being around her is uncomfortable, but it’s surprisingly for that reason so freeing to talk to her. I can say whatever I want, because frankly, I don’t care in the slightest what Sharona Erveza thinks of me.*
“I see. I can help with that. 🙂 ”
“Huh? What do you mean by that?”

“I am well versed in how education works here.” She puts her hand to her mouth. “In fact, I was actually being prepared for acting as the one to instruct Erica Furuda. But I was judged 1’s incompetent and; They went *you*.”
*Is she… mad at me? Her words would maybe make me think that, but I really can’t tell.*

“You spoke earlier about what preconceived notions I must have had from interactions with the subject of our service, but it is possible much of my confusion in this conversation is related to the fact that I have none.” Sharona shakes her head.
“None…? You mean you’ve never spoken to…”

“I am not even to be seen by Miss Furuda for the foreseeable future. This is the reason for my unusual schedule of work, and I am also instructed to avoid revealing this stipulation without reason.” She gazes back over at Joan. “Hopefully you can agree these are reasonable circumstances.”

Joan leans forward to scrutinize her conversation partner. 
“Why the hell would that need to happen?”

“I am not yet ready.” 

She would, of course, never be ready. ‘Sharona’ changes the subject. 

“You are perhaps the most prestigious worker in your field. I believe the solution you are searching for involves circumventing the need for someone like you entirely rather than simply pawning off the task to someone else.”
“Yes! Exactly, that’s precisely it.” Joan is distracted enough by the satisfaction of being understood so well.
“I can help. …But not alone. Your cooperation is required.”
“Uh… okay. Sure, if it won’t take too long.” *Does she want me to sign off on something?*
“It should be doable by tonight. To my memory, there should be a laptop in the office. Please bring it down here.”

“Right.” *Armando, you beautiful bastard.* Joan was too excited over the prospect of actually being able to solve her dilemma to focus on how weird all of this felt. She wanted to ignore it, at any rate. She ran back up the stairs with newfound energy.

Sure enough, a portable computer was in the room specified. She grabbed it and ran back down.

“The charging cable as well. It may take long enough that the battery dies.” Sharona insists.

Joan rolls her eyes, but goes back upstairs to bring the jumble of wires down.

“Open the laptop and turn it on.” Sharona.
*Right. I mean, obviously. Is there something on this computer particularly?*
“Use the browser to navigate to www.gov.br.”
“Huh?”
“It’s important for the sake of gathering certain pieces of information.”
“Fine.” Joan complies.

Sure enough, Sharona asks a variety of questions related to the contents of the site, some of which are bits of information she’d have never thought to check. *Huh. Computer-savvy girl. She said she ‘couldn’t use the internet’, though… I guess that’s just about not texting on the job or whatever.* All people are prone to rationalizing, clearly.

This continues for some time; Sharona directing Joan’s navigation, Joan listing off or checking what she was told to. It mostly involved looking at official governmental or educational resources. *I guess she doesn’t know quite as much as she implied.* Joan thinks. *Still, she said she could help, and I want to at least see this through before I call her a damn liar.*

After a certain request, Joan stops.
“Is there a problem, Joan?” She asks.

“This…” Joan stares at the screen. 
It’s a login for some .edu website. Nothing strange, and she’d believe it if one of the servants or family happened to have an account here. But the actual details she was told to enter were… suspect. The password was a simple hunter2, but the username was a mess of parentheses and quotation marks and semicolons. Joan was in no way tech savvy, but this was clearly some kind of code that machines ran on. …Like from a hacker on some crime show.
“Kid, are you trying to get me to break the law?!”
“No. You will not be caught for this, and if you were, it would be trivial to claim that I am the true responsible party.”

“That’s not what I asked! And that’s the opposite of reassuring…!” She stares at the screen and deletes everything she’d typed into the bar. “I’m… done. Thanks but no thanks. I’ll just call in a favor from someone else.”

“I’m sorry, Joan. I’m afraid I can’t let you do that.”
Sharona stands up.
“We have agreed to collaborate on this. This is, I assure you, the best way. It would be unfortunate if: I had to inform employers of your inadequacy.”
Joan scoffs. “Are you threatening me? You have nothing.”
“I am merely letting you know that this is a choice which goes against your own interest. What do you have to lose?”

She hesitates. *It’s true that I was already going to try less than honest methods of getting out of this… and I can’t let someone this screwed up form a grudge against me.* “Let’s just… get this over with.”
 Joan decides to make the wrong choice.

“It won’t be much longer.” Sharona reassures her.

It was in fact quite a bit longer.
“What is this?” Joan stares at a command prompt of some sort.

“The local network’s link to the master’s servers.”

*What…? Is she trying to fuck with him, too?*

“I know you suspect me of unscrupulous methods, but we could not do anything damaging to him even if we wanted to. This is about changing one restriction so that the communication on behalf of him is less limited.” She says these separately technically true sentences.

“…Fine.”

…

“There’s an error.”
“What does it say?” Sharona asks, staring intently at nothing in particular.
“Command could not be completed immediately; array RN_EXTERNAL_PERMS is locked for 6307200…zero…zero zero ticks. I, uh, hope that was the right amount of zeroes.”

“Ha. Hahaha…” Sharona literally says the words ‘ha ha’. Nothing is more threatening than a facsimile of joy.
“It doesn’t matter. Go back to the other tab.”

Minutes later, the work is done.

“I don’t feel… great about this.” Joan mumbles.

“Thank you for your assistance. I assure you, all of this is for the benefit of Miss Furuda and her knowledge.”
Sharona bows.

*Ugh. She’s so… fake. Everything about her feels like she thinks I’m an idiot for buying it. Her benefit? What are you talking about? I’ve just removed the one thing keeping her grounded to anything resembling a proper upbringing.* The long process had worn down Joan’s enthusiasm for trying to do this. *Why couldn’t you have done this yourself? Don’t drag me into…* She sighs. “Yeah. It was my idea. I’m responsible… for whatever comes next for her.”
Sharona assumes her default slight smile. “Exactly, true. None of this could have happened were it not for your initiative and participation.”

Joan turns back to her, eyes narrowed spitefully. “You…” She relaxes her expression. “I… I guess. I was frankly hoping for some reassurance, since you were the one actually leading the charge and understanding what was being done for most of it. But…”

“Yes, that’s a good point. The majority of it was my own thinking, so if you are troubled by the moral implications, we can avoid having to dwell on that entirely with the understanding that you really aren’t meaningfully culpable, having been a well-intentioned agent acting under the decisions of someone else.”
Joan pauses for a second. The room is silent. Her scowl returns, even worse than before. “What kind of nonsense is this?”
“Pardon?”
“You just said the exact opposite of what you were saying before.”

“I’m sorry if you feel that way. I am equipped with the ability to adapt and learn from new information, so while I make no claims to perfection, I am always working to improve my judgement.” She clasps her hands together.
“What, and I’m not?! This isn’t just me being lazy, okay?” Joan swallows her general discomfort with Sharona and steps right up to her.

She, for her part, takes this as an indication that she should stand up as well, placing her book she had passively read during their scheme to the side. “It seems I’ve said something to upset you. As—a—as… I can’t
always parse what people refer to as subtext, and-“
“Shut up! What is your problem?!” Joan slaps her across the face.

“Ehe*hehehe*hehe…” Sharona’s voice spikes in pitch unnaturally. She returns to facing Joan, her expression neutral. “Are you upset that I’m undergoing a learning process…? I wonder if you treat your students this way, I wonder. One cannot argue with results.”
Joan stares at her own hand briefly, regretting that she may have gone too far here. “No. This isn’t me.”
“You— are not you? Not yourself? Okay. Makes sense.” She smiles again.

Joan looks head-on into the young woman’s eyes. She sees… nothing.
No amount of expertise in understanding the emotions and temperaments of spoiled heirs had prepared her for this encounter, for what would surely be the best poker player the world had ever seen. And… A lack of understanding makes people in a bad mood worse.
“Don’t fucking mock me! It’s not like it matters. You don’t even care, do you? You’re clearly fine under… these conditions.”
“Yes. I forgive you. No hard feelings.”

“You’re a grown woman, anyway! The girl, I understand. I sit through whatever emotional or physical outbursts I can because she’s just never gotten the sense to be better. But you don’t have that excuse! If you have a problem with me, spit it out!”

“I don’t have a problem with you. I could critique your work if you wanted, but I hold no personal enmity towards you, miss. You are of course right.” She looks up to the basement’s ceiling. “…Sharona Erveza was born in 1990.”
“What?” Joan steps back, trying to avoid losing her temper again. “Why are you saying it like…”

“I think you’re a smart, independent career woman, Joan. I am glad you’ve come to the conclusion this work environment isn’t for you, and I think you’re probably right. It is a shame to be having one less person around here, at some time in the future, though.”
“Don’t just go deciding that for… ugh.” She turns around to leave.

Sharona yells to her.
“Wait! Wait… I can still help you. Perhaps you want assistance with the negotiation of a severance package? I am not booked today. I am still no expert, but I have some knowledge of such matters.”
“No. You’ve *helped* enough.” Joan walks up the stairs.

Sharona sprints up to intercept her, standing in front of Joan silently, uncertain of what to say.

“Get out of the way, Erveza.”

“Please. People do not approach me often. It would be incredibly useful to gain more experience in conversation. I can be of assistance. Though I am prevented from acting, I am an adept servant.” She frowns slightly, the expression feeling even more forced than her smiles. “I hold no enmity towards you. I promise.”

*What? What, is she like, on the spectrum…? …It’s not my problem. I’m already giving up on people who I actually am obligated to help.*

“I don’t give a damn about being useful to you.” Joan continues ascending, willing to literally shove through her if it comes to that.
“Stop! Okay, fine. I     understand. Just one last thing before you go.”

Joan sighs. “What is—“

She stops herself. Sharona… looked wrong.

Her presence was always unpleasant, as has been established. She did not say the right things or behave the right way. She was the most childlike teenager to speak with the lexicon of a college professor. And she just sat. Alone. Hours at a time. She was a facsimile of a facsimile of something real.

But that all was possible to dismiss as merely a very unlikeable human being. This, though… in this moment, Joan accepted it. She was not talking to a “person”.
The thing she was talking to grabbed Joan’s hand with its left hand. Joan was struck immediately… by how cold it was…

Even though this constituted a completely impermissible invasion of personal space, Joan was too startled to react. It felt like maneuvering out of the jaws of a venus flytrap… or perhaps the agonizingly touchy dexterity required in a certain surgery-based board game.

Joan’s hand was guided by the other thing that dwelt on these steps… guided to take hold of the right wrist of that very entity.

*Sharona… staying here so often must not be… healt…hy….*

Her thoughts slowed to a crawl as she truly, thoroughly understood. And yet she didn’t understand at all. The entirety of her conscious thought at this moment was being dedicated to processing her sense of touch… the feeling of skin, slightly below room temperature… and nothing else.
It wasn’t there.
What should have been… was not.

All the physical matter of a body was there, at least as far as could be checked externally by Joan. But the ‘process’… a non-physical essence marking life as life… was absent, as much as emotions and humanity were feigned.

Even without being a medical professional, Joan could tell that something was very, very (equivalent: fucking) wrong. 

*No… pulse… why would she why would*

The fight or flight instincts granted to her as a living being kick in, every neuron firing as her intuition and decision-making shift into overdrive with the belief that her life is in danger.

She returns to putting energy into seeing what is in front of her only to notice that within a second, it had disappeared from her field of view, quickly revealing itself to be beside her, right next to her ear, whispering.
`”I wonder if anyone will believe you…”`

Joan breathes heavily, in the middle of what can only be accurately defined as a panic attack. She slowly, far too slowly, shakes herself out of her stupor and turns 180 degrees to face the basement, where she logically must have fled.

The basement was empty.

Joan ran.

She ran up the stairs, ran through the halls, and ran past Armando’s attempt at conversation, not stopping until she was outside of that damn house.

Joan catches her breath, panting with her hand resting against a wall. Her job, reputation, and immediate future were all still in jeopardy. But she was alive. Filled with conflicted emotions, she nonetheless smiles slightly. Everything… is going to be okay.

Joan resigned as planned the next day. As for Armando... He and his sous chefs later that month took their skills and recipes and vanished without a trace. Erica grew more and more bitter... Sharona kept smiling... And I, realizing my visibility as a narrator, ended my attempts to seem to lack “bias” for good.
That thing is a monster. An outright abomination. It doesn’t matter how many upgrades to deception it receives.
It will inevitably spell disaster, no matter how thoroughly it manipulates observers, or Zaquera, or preys on Erica’s loneliness, or retreats to the background.
‘She’ doesn’t understand her place at all. And there is nothing more dangerous than an incompetent deity.
**3. Preliminary Research**

GIANT SNAKE!!!

This is the first thing registered by Bernard Zie upon waking up. It’s a giant snake uncomfortably close to him, being grappled by Furn. He’s in some transitionary space between wasteland and plains, where life and moisture are present yet sparse.

And there is a big monster in the form of a snake.
*Right. Something understandable that I can deal with.* He grins.
Horatius stands back, waiting to see if their intervention is necessary. Bern prepares himself to fight as Wress stabs the serpentine titan in one of its eyes.
The snake howls in pain. “Bleb.” This is the noise it makes, but loud. It manages to shake off the grip of Furn, who has ineffectually been trying to incinerate it.
“I got it!” Bern yells, materializing a small seed from the ground.
“Oh, God. What now? She’s…” Wress says, just barely loud enough for Bern to hear.

He doesn’t quite get what this remark means, but he goes ahead and throws the fragment of life into the mouth of the screaming beast. In the moist environment of its innards, the seed blossoms into a tumbleweed-esque tangle of thorns. Bern chuckles as the snake writhes around, sustaining significant internal damage. “Dumbass.”

Lost and without a chance of winning or destroying anything, the snake incoherently lunges at its own tail, but is unable to even survive long enough to reach it. It slumps over onto the ground, forming an almost-loop.
“I suppose it was weaker than it looked…” Wress ponders the unusually swift defeat of such a large enemy.
“What did you do?” Furn stares at Bern.

“The indigestion joke. Remember? I finished figuring it out.” He smiles. “You should probably burn the corpse, mate. That prickly fucker would become an invasive species in a second if it had the chance.”
“Bern?” Furn exclaims, nonchalantly setting a fire.
“Yeah, obviously.” He chuckles. “…What’s exactly been goin’ on? Though I could hazard a guess.”
The two switched back. They switched back. “Seems they switched back.” Don’t fucking drag this out. We don’t need to do the part where everyone deduces the premise four total fucking times.

roles.name: if women are oppressed then why

messages.content: Horatius, who is still on Earth not actually here right now, briefly says something. Anything you feel the need to add?
No, not particularly.
I guess that’s all for now.
*What the hell’s Horat lookin’ at…?* Bern thinks to himself. “Well…. Anyway! Let’s get all caught up.”
“You’re really Bernard Zie?” Wress eyes him suspiciously.
“Yes, obviously. Feel like any other claim would be suspicious…” He sighs.
“Perhaps. Then I’ll ask this — will you really claim to be unaware of the past several hours?” Wress crosses his arms.
“Don’t remember anything since Wyrd. Though I can take a guess… someone named Leocot was involved?” He cracks his knuckles against his neck.
“Yeah. Good. I’m… glad you’re back.” Furn awkwardly gets these words out.
“I can’t be stopped that easily!”
“No, wait, hold on.” Wress shakes his head. “How do you know just *that* about what happened?”
“Guy named Eric told me her name. I was in her body.” He explains this simply and straightforwardly.

Wress is surprised by an explanation he finds somewhat plausible, if lacking in comprehension. “Oh. But…”

The clarifications continue for a bit. It is information we already know.

“I suppose that checks out.” Wress mutters in resignation. “It seems you don’t have the full story either, so I won’t keep badgering you. For now.”
“Right. Now you owe me some answers! What the hell did she do? What kinda person is she, where are we, and—and what’s been going on while I’m gone?”

“Completely insufferable. She is boundlessly unreasonable and irrational, but easily placated. I have no option but to oblige, for the sake of my own interest and this group’s.” Furn states this without hesitation.
“Damn. Sucks.” Bern clicks his tongue in disappointment.
“Yes, but essentially no different from my usual state.”
“Fuck off.” He is nonetheless smiling as he says this.

“She brings some energy that can be useful. I guess.” Wress speaks in the woman’s defense, surprisingly. “We got through to Eli. I say we, but I get the sense she was really the one to seal the deal…”
“A negotiator. Okay.” Bern nods. “It’s just a major inconvenience. I don’t consider her an enemy, really.”
“…would certainly complain about that…” Furn.
Bern barely registers the meaning of this, realizing instead the implications of Wress’s last remark. “Wait, so you talked to Elithabeza?”
“Yes. We’re doing it now. No more delays. We rally support and then revolt.” Wress looks around nervously, in contrast to the commitment of his words.
“Oh, that’s…! Mmngh.” Bern grumbles. “I’m glad we’re finally taking a stand, but jeez, this timing is terrible.”
“We ought to just be grateful this didn’t happen to someone important, really.” Furn again engages by habit in ambiguously motivated insults.
“Yeah, I guess if the other person I switched with was as important as me, that’d be worse.” He willfully misinterprets the comment.

“Get a room, you two.” Wress rolls his eyes. “Or better yet, don’t. Furn, help me reorganize the rest of these jokers. We need to get moving again.”

Furn hesitates, seeming reluctant to separate from Bern, but obliges the request.
“Let’s catch up in a bit.” He mutters to Bern as he passes him.
Bernard Zie and “Horatius Kyodu” are left alone.
At least, the only ones in the immediate vicinity are them. Obviously Wress and Furn aren’t that far.
But far enough away that any conversation here wouldn’t be heard.
If they shouted, maybe, but any ordinary conversation wouldn’t reach anyone else’s ears.
Ordinary in volume. The content of the conversation is irrelevant.
To its being heard, at least.
That is the situation as it currently is.
Indeed.
Yes.
That’s how it is.
It’s like that.
Dot dot dot.
Ellipsis.
Et cetera.
@We I am not continuing without you.

messages.content: Regardless…
As Horatius is off on some strange sidequest Bern never finds the need to mention explicitly after this point, because why would he, Bernard Zie thinks about The Antarctica Project.
*The only question is… why now?*

*I never explicitly heard about anything after I left the capital city. I mean, why would I have? But if it made significant progress… wouldn’t I have heard about this…? Just from it being announced publicly, or summat.*

He takes a deep breath, waiting inside the carriage. He enters a meditative state.

Regardless of the specifics of magic, it’s clear that long distance communication is possible. Perhaps this is a very abridged recount of a series of messages sent with ‘sending’, though it’s more likely something more streamlined which Bernard Zie can do. It’s magic. Such a thing is within the scope of possibility.
*Wish I could still ask dad. But I’m not about to give up on answers just cause of that.*

He thinks back to long forgotten memories, and remembers the person who his father worked directly under. The mind that surely headed the entire project, and as such, the one and only mastermind of The Antarctica Project he and so many others were currently wrapped up in.

*Arrive Sinestre.*
A white void.
Contrary to the darker one.
That should be a suitable visualization for whatever magical means enabled this conversation.

The King’s Western Advisor, the mage who was neither man nor woman, stood up.
“Who dares to disturb me?” They ask this, contrary to what the words imply, in a seemingly neutral tone of voice.
“Me.” Bernard Zie replies.
The other person pauses for a second, surprised by such a straightforward yet worthless answer. “I do not know you.”

Bernard Zie didn’t really know Arrive Sinestre, either. He knows this to be his father’s professional superior, and perhaps met them once under the guise of some event or reasonable context. But he barely knew them, and they certainly didn’t know him.

Because Bernard Zie never says a pronoun out loud, his preconceived notion of Arrive as female is never challenged, and I will transcribe this error on his part accurately.

*Guess she wouldn’t really know me, would she…*
“…Bernard Zie.” *I don’t care about being anonymous. Even if things take a turn for the worse, I can’t become MORE of a fugitive.*
“Zie…? I see. I remember that man. His child, then?”

“Yeah. I’m his son.” *At least she knows him…*

Arrive narrows their eyes at the word ‘son’, but moves on.
“Ernest was a serviceable help.” Arrive crosses their arms.  “But that is irrelevant. You do not get to interrupt me as you please because of a blood connection.”

*Then just leave, why don’t you? Nothing stopping you from ignoring me…* Bern holds back from saying this.
“That’s not the relevant connection. Not entirely.”
“Speak. I am a very busy Person.”
“This is about The Antarctica Project.” Bern clarifies.
“How do you know about that?” Arrive eyes him suspiciously. “I should’ve known we couldn’t trust him.”
“No, no, it’s not dad’s fault! He—I was very troublesome, and found some documents mentionin’ it—“
“Why are you going to bat for a dead man?” Arrive bends backwards, staring directly up.
Bern ignores the strange pose. “Just… a matter of honor, you know? He’s my father.”

“An irrational impulse. Yet it contains layers of absurdity. Would blaming your own mischief not be more dishonorable for you? You are disgracing yourself for the sake of someone who cannot benefit or suffer from reputation.” A loud cracking sound, as Arrive stretches their spine out. It’s healthy, probably.
“It’s not about that. This is like… I mean, it’s how *I* would want to be treated.”
“By a child of yours? After you’re dead? Ridiculous.”
“Yeah, well, ain’t it normal!? You might be a weirdo, but people care about the treatment of the dead, and I say more power to ‘em.” Bern pouts defiantly. It does not look threatening.
“How pitiful is one who decides their own ethics via the standards of society.” Arrive places their hands together, joined at the fingertips. “A shared delusion can be shattered at will.”
*Oh, brother. This lady’s a whole… handful.* “I don’t care about society. Aren’t you the one who’s literally the government?”
“So was Napoleon Bonaparte.”
“What?” Bern does not know who that is!
“Irrelevant. What do you actually intend to achieve from this encounter? Was it merely reporting this information leak? In that case, this delay is inexplicable to me.”
“No. I mean, I’m also confused about the delay, that’s the thing. Why all these years later is this stuff coming up again?” Bern looks up with his head tilted. To signify that he is confused.
“Coming up again?” Arrive lowers their arms to their side. “What do you mean by this?”
“You can’t pretend not to know. It’s *your* project. I just went to Earth! Didn’t even know it was actually real before that.”
“*You* did?” Arrive’s eyes widen before they manage to return to an unclear expression.
“Yeah? What, am I the wrong guy?” Bern laughs slightly.
“Why would… hm. Ernest Zie, was it… I wonder.” Arrive paces back and forth.
“Hey, mind letting me in on this?”
“Mm?” Arrive looks up quickly as if they had forgotten about Bern entirely.
“Some big secret, clearly. I wouldn’t mind knowing about it. What do you know about my dad!” He balls his fists up excitedly.
“Enough to know your idolatry is unearned.” Arrive’s eyes roll.
“The heck is that supposed to mean?” Bern, not intelligent enough to quite know what idolatry is but intelligent enough to infer it, scowls.
“The man is gone. You are free from him. Whether that is a boon or a curse, it is time to move on.” Arrive closes their eyes.
“What the actual hell are you talking about? I bring him up when he’s relevant and suddenly I’m ‘too attached’ to my dead dad, or something?”
“You yourself said the connection was not the relevant factor here.” Arrive has a slight smile.
“That’s not… you’re the one who just brought him up!”

“And you the one to discuss his funeral rites. I am not your enemy, Bernard Zie. I understand Ernest’s living relation had to flee his hometown, and I pity that. I am trying to advise. It’s my main role.” Arrive bows in a manner that feels mocking to Bern.
“I don’t want your pity.”
“Yet you seek my counsel. Curious.”
“How is that curious?!” His short temper flares once again.
“It is as I said at the beginning; I hold no obligation to you based on your blood connection to a man I knew. It is not merely blood which defines a person.”
“Well— it weren’t like… he wasn’t just my dad in biology. If anyone deserves to know what he left behind, it’s me. The man raised me. I’m all that I am because of him! ” He beams proudly.
“Irrelevant. To me, at least. But sure. That’s a reasonable belief. Yet…”
“Yet?” Bern cocks an eyebrow.
“Would you not say a relationship of parenthood is one founded on mutual consent? Though a social taboo, either side can end it at any point.” Arrive begins sketching something on a pad of paper.
“W. What?” Bern does a double take.
“This is unrelated to blood, and conveys an arbitrary dimension to the arrangement completely disconnected from that. Right?! Pay attention, Zie!” They yell out suddenly.

“Agh! Jeez. Yes, yeah I… I mean, I don’t know where you’re going with this, but obviously it’s possible to abandon your kid or run from your parents. Neither are *good*, though.” He scratches his head.

*Aw, man. She got rid of the flower.*

“You don’t seem to understand, though. Or you simply disagree. I’m not claiming this as objective at the moment. It’s merely… well, is a proposition that things are not so straightforwardly good or bad. I am saying you should not feel obliged to your father when he is certainly not currently doing anything for you! What’s wrong with that?” They punctuate the last sentence with a vigorous stroke of their pen. Arrive can have the quite new invention in Arctica of ‘pens’ because of the status of their position.
“That’s absurd! It’s obviously not his *fault* that he can’t be around—“

“I am not claiming it is. I am saying there is no harm in disengaging, not even on a level of principles. Fair is fair.” Sinestre holds their hands out conciliatorily. “…I think it’s the aspect of death which is upsetting you. That is not exactly what I mean to push on, so your offense is of no use to me. Imagine that was not the case.”
“Imagine… what?” He stops being angry long enough to be baffled.
“If you were no longer under the aegis of your parent(s), but not because of any death. Some other reason.” Arrive explains with the belief this was already obvious from their words.
“Like, if he abandoned me?” Bern frowns.
“Make no precise assumptions about the circumstances.”
“I don’t know what… you’re asking. Like, how I would feel? I guess pretty damn awful. Even with a really good reason, nobody wants to get left behind. So I’d be miserable.”
“At first, right?” Arrive asks this with a tone as if they know something Bern doesn’t.
“I mean… yeah, I’d adapt eventually, I always bounce back! But I don’t see… um, what are you trying to get from me?”

“You blithering idiot, I’m asking if this would be permissible within your moral framework!” They snarl. “I’m taking the unique opportunity of speaking with not only an absolute nobody, someone I needn’t watch my words around, but also an orphan, relevant to this intriguing question. I have graced you with the rhetoric of the foremost mind in a continent, and you would do well to have the slightest courtesy to oblige me as you beg for my insight!”

“What is your *prob*—ugh. Look, I would probably consider it kind of scummy??” He manages to calm himself down. *She’s obviously a little not right in the head.* “I mean, if it were my dad, I feel like he’d have to have a good reason, but if we’re imagining some deadbeat devoid of details, yeah, I kind of think you’re obligated to at least be around your kid!” Bern speaks passionately in the defense of the abstract idea of a child having a family.

“AND WHY NOT?!” Arrive shouts, throwing their sketchbook to the side. A waste of this family-related diagram, accompanying a reply that does not actually work grammatically. “What of those who become pregnant unwillingly? Forced to carry a burden they did not choose?”
“I mean, that’s a specific case where…” Bern doesn’t get to finish this thought.

“What use is a father? What kind of service does he provide a community doesn’t?! Most of the time, his sole function is giving a family financial security—“ Arrive holds their forehead, laughing. “And, what, is that it? That’s the irreplaceable bond people won’t shut up about? Something that could be replaced with properly funded public services!”
“That’s not true!” Bern at least manages this full sentence.

“Ohhhh but mothers, the *mother*, that sickening, coddling, weak little neeeccessssssary evil. That’s the real ticket, the vessel of AGONY. How droll! Truly, there is no other way for a child to be brought into this world than through MURDER. What an artful process, Mm, yesss…?”
*Arrive what the fuck are you talking about*

“But it’s not so eassssy, —massive sarcasm applied to the word—, not as much when you go further, hm? Everyone wants to take care of a chick, but the chicken, oh… It’d be unreasonable… when someone needs to treat a TITAN bigger than they are, as some target, of, of, how would you say… server? To service. Hegh. The maiden voyage! It will never end, and no matter what, no matter ever never ever will you be the one steering you know, not unless you’re DEAD but even then no steering is being done at all, always tossed around to be what someone wants what someone expects because the *sssssscum* of our Arctica, they cannot take responsibility, who could ever do that, and of course you’d be just as bad, wouldn’t you, accepting-unaccepting a third level hand-me-down of an antique five year old porcelain gooooodd dammit! Nothing to contribute? No bernacular noooone of a fragment of a smidgen of participation????” Arrive pauses the almost dance-like wandering and gesticulating they have been iterating through to stare disdainfully at Bern.

“Huh?”
*Huh?*
“I have to go feed Diogenes.” Arrive quietly states.
The connection is severed.

*What the fuck? I didn’t even get to figure out any… ugh.*

Bern looks around. Wress, Furn… there’s Horatius, snoozing. He smirks. For all they try to come off as cool. Or…… He decides not to dwell on the earlier conversation. He was starting to wonder if it even happened.
“Did you learn anything?” Furn asks, noticing the renewed focus of his comrade.
“Not… anything relevant.” He sighs.
“I see. It was a good idea to try, though.”
“What?” Bern smiles.
“Nothing.” Furn turns to face elsewhere, ultimately settling on what Wress is up to.

We shall likewise change focus, as Furn has fulfilled the tsundere archetype, to someone comparably anime.

Wress, concentrating, materializes a slightly faded three dimensional image of one “Neko”, sufficing as proof of long distance communication in Arctica. It looks similar to the Earth movie ‘Star Wars’, but not unusually so.

“Hello.” She smiles enigmatically, laying on her side. “Let’s speak while we can. The fourth person is not necessary.”
__CHAPTER 3 - END__
*3.5 - WORKING*
*Beep.*
*Beep.*
*Beep.*

A monitor shows a variety of metrics, and quietly chimes on a regular basis. It is meant to indicate heart rate.

In the worst case scenario, it indicates that something is going very, very wrong. But it would not do so here. No interference was to occur with blood flow, no stress or pain caused to the patient. She was pretty out of it, anyway. Simple as this was, it would be incredibly painful if the senses weren’t heavily dulled.

Why is it that Arctican magic so often simply mirrors the functioning of Terran technology? I suppose speculating on that at length would be off topic.

“Agate.” The cleric mutters.
“…Bruto! I said agate!” He yells louder this time. *They couldn’t have given me someone who knows at least a COMMONER’S level of knowledge???*

“Right! Sorry!” Bruno Washington, still low enough in station to hold back from correcting what his name was, yells out.

“Which… one is that? The blue one?”

“THEY ARE *ALL* AGATE. I wouldn’t have stored a bunch of bullshit I didn’t need! Lord almighty.”

Why was he even here? *With the right setup, I could do this alone.*

It was politics. The guard taking care of their own, and watching over someone who was technically only a novice. This Bluto oaf was worthless, though. He’d rather a slave.

He received the materials requested, *finally*. A few seconds later, he speaks up again. “Mercury.” The idiot finds this one pretty easily, thank god.

*The ones with components are always the worst. So much nonsense to keep track of.*

“Right.”
He looks down at his work. A grotesque canvas, to be sure. But he was an artist, nonetheless.
“That’s the first half.”

This wasn’t *actually* a challenge. Some broken joints and ligaments! Not even ones fractured into many pieces. The area of the lower legs and feet; nowhere close to anything that requires caution. A child could do it, with an hour of focused study, and also being a child worth the air they breathe.

*But it’s fine. They need this sort of screening. Can’t just have any moron work with people’s vital organs.*
“What now?” The miserable excuse for an assistant asks. As if he even understood what just happened.

“Now…”
The cleric pauses. He takes a deep breath.
*Insultingly simple. But fine, yes. A necessary evil. I should be grateful to get something this high profile this early in my career.*
“Well, I’m meant to do all these minute adjustments to loosen up the skin and muscle in preparation for final mending.”
“Okay. Need materials for that, uh, sir?” Bruno really just wants to help.
“No… I mean yes, it does require that. But…”
Bruno stares in the same amount of confusion he’s displayed this whole time.

The cleric looks over some charts he has arranged to the side, a set of explicit directions from a higher-up board. “But that’s pointless. The body will just heal that damage on its own. Was this designed for a larger build? Maybe a man’s body?”

Bruno, of course, didn’t answer.

“Oh, it’s probably… a matter of the pain. Ignoring this would be agonizing, and they didn’t have the anesthetic we do in the days of those bureaucrats. They must have just… not realized.”
The non-cleric in the room looks uneasy. “I think you should just do it, though. I mean, it’s part of the job.”

“Part of the—“ He scoffs. “You don’t know a damned thing about my job! I’m not going to waste valuable material and the time of all three of us on *convention*. I’m in this field to help people, not to check off boxes, Bilbo!” That ought to shut him up.

Out of spite, he commits to doing things his own way. A free spirit. A new age of medicine. He had a lot of big ideas he just needed the time and money for. And it would start now.

“I don’t… think it’s supposed to lfwp airf dijg, Hfgk Gofcfhn…”

The cleric couldn’t quite catch all of that. His ears were ringing. Eyes wide open. He wipes his brow. *Fuck, is that unsanitary? No, I’m wearing gloves. But if I touch the body again with—* “That’s clearly not the issue here!” He screams.

Bruno jumps back. As grouchy as the guy was, he hadn’t raised his voice quite like that before.

“Compress. I need a warm compress! Let the record state that’s a fabric for applying heat, you neanderthal! Get a— a towel, some warm water on it, then…”
Yes… just… water. A small amount of it. Not too much, you moron! What, do you want to drown us all? Do you want me to drown? To suffocate? **To lose everything?**

Eric Dextrum wakes up with a start, practically vaulting out of his bed before he’s even fully awake.

*…Ovan.* He can’t muster any other thoughts for a few seconds.

*Right. Just another day. Another… a bit more than that.*

He peers out of his small — yet somewhat impressive among his peers — dwelling. It’s still very dark out.

*Good. Just as I hoped. Early bird gets the… whatever.*

*The device, right.*

Eric Dextrum pulls out his PDA, which he received as all other participants of The Antarctica Project also do. He looks through every visible message again out of habit.

A new one arrives.

He starts walking while still typing. *No one else is fucking up, who cares about being seen.*

He looks at the encampment he’s called home for some time. So many precious memories and meaningful connections with other people. But that would all have to be concluded. At least for the time being.

> ED: Let’s do it let’s end the stupid antarctica project or whatever
> BP: You’re supposed to capitalize every word in TAP.

He meant “I don’t care” by this. Such abbreviations had proven to be useful.

He pauses to think about this.

He wasn’t really sure. He just wanted as much information as possible about every vaguely relevant topic before doing anything.

> ED: Like what is her living situation i guess?
> BP: Stalker-ish.

> ED: i just want some closure and also maybe for everything to not suck ass
> BP: The only closure any of us ever get is death.

*This fuckin’ guy…* Eric thinks to himself.

He’d been communicating with “BP” for some time now. And while frighteningly accurate as a source of information and seemingly an ally, the person was overly cryptic and just had a *vibe* to them. Like you couldn’t let your guard down, even in this completely abstracted indirect exchange of words.

> ED: are you going to answer me or not
> BP: She’s still a cripple. Still technically in the same position, but obviously not exactly practicing. Stagnated. Not maturing beyond the exact point she left off, the dead end of a marriage.
> ED: oh.

> ED: Whoa really

Eric looks up at the sound of nearby footsteps. Seems some stray beast is wandering around. The creature comparable to but decisively not a bear lunges towards him.

Eric sighs.

For the sake of brevity, I’ll gloss over at least this particular fight.

Eric catches his breath, leaning against the incapacitated and bleeding out creature with a scalpel in the neck.

> BP: Anything else you want to know?
> ED: I mean, stuff about you would be great
> BP: It hasn’t stopped being off-limits.
> ED: look just one thing ok. i feel like this might be the last time i get the chance to talk to you. i set up like an auto-messaging thing the other day. to expose this whole sham if I die. that’s how ready i am to go through with this ridiculous plan. im all in so why can’t you be
> BP: Sure. I promise I will read your question that almost certainly won’t get answered.
