> BP: What a specific question. It could be, for all you know. I’ve had a lot of names, really.
> ED: cool thanks for the not answer
> BP: Anything else? Preferably, y’know, actually useful? We are nearly out of time.

He stops to think.

> ED: horatius kyodu. that’s a name that a participant of the antarctica project goes by isn’t it
> BP: Yes. How did you know that?
> ED: not telling. now i get to be pointlessly cryptic
> BP: Ok. I don’t care.
> ED: what’s the guys real name
> BP: This would provide no value to you, and I’m paying back your spite. Pass.
> ED: damn. What about the other participants 
> BP: Are you aware of how many there are?

Eric looks up at the sky, still much more on the “night” end of a 24 hour cycle.

> ED: definitely 12 its the only thing that makes sense
> BP: Tch. Alright, fine.
> BP: Using not necessarily birth names and first names only so I can keep being a minor annoyance, the twelve are as follows.
> BP: Dagte, Erica, Eric, Erikka, George, Horatius, Intuition, Klaud, Mister, Rikarasu, Viotto, Voreverl
> ED: ????
> BP: All accurate, I guarantee.
> ED: nowhat the hell why do three guys have almost the same name
> ED: and also Mister is not a name i refuse that and like
> BP: Time’s up. Sorry, can’t risk it!
> ED: NO YOU FUC

The entire screen becomes devoid of text. Eric sighs.

*That leaves me with way more questions…*

Nothing for it. He just had to stay his course. This list would be irrelevant, anyway. Though not entirely in the way Eric believed.

Checking behind him out of paranoia the whole time, Eric uneventfully travels the rest of his route. He takes a circuitous path to meet a back alley transportation afficionado willing to teleport him to a few miles out from the capital. It was, from there, a sizable yet not unmanageable walk to Arenda. But at some point on this particular walk, he forgot to keep watching his back.

The town was pretty solid in terms of security. Bad news for him. But Eric, crafty as he was, managed to make it through all the scattered official town guards or crackpot amateur armed nightowls.

He had successfully broken into someone’s house. *Great. Good showing from the son of a noble.* He laments his own deteriorated prestige.

*With this… I’ll have paid my debts. I’ll give up this worthless bit of nepotism from a man who failed to give me what I really wanted, let some other sucker get more use out of it. And… well, maybe then, we’ll both be able to walk.* He chuckles at his own genius literary device.
*I’m not gonna stand for Wress doing jack shit after today. It’s time to live, for everyone. Wow. I think I probably needed those extra hours of sleep. I just… let’s get this over with.*

Eric is obliged. His internet friend was right about closure. His mistake of not using anesthesia this time comes to trouble him first. Then his lack of vigilance in avoiding a tail.

No one but Eric actually spoke a word this chapter. Such is the tragedy of his existence. Connected to so many, he was really never anything but alone.

It was “sorry”, by the way. The last word he failed to get out with a hole in him. Not really anything groundbreaking, no solution to any mystery or unclear question. But perhaps it conveys all the information there ever was about Eric Dextrum.

All the information that doesn’t fundamentally spoil The Antarctica Project, at least.
**4. Hypothesis**
“First order of business. Where are you?” Neko inquires.
“In the Shent plains. We’re… changing plans. Unfortunate necessity. We’ll be heading your way.” Wress answers without hesitation.

Bern looks at this exchange warily.
*Why does he trust her?*

Wress Hifele was a cautious man. Too cautious, really. Much more than his predecessor ever was. Yet this was someone he was willing to explain their whereabouts and goals to, their current destination and everything. Who was it? A longtime ally of the cause? A woman working directly under Wress? An associate of his father’s? No. This was the daughter of the man they intended to usurp.

*I wonder if it’s jealousy, or living vicariously….* He thinks to himself, engaging in amateur psychoanalysis watching Wress happily chat away with Catarina “Neko” Praxis, whose real name was not really a secret to anyone. *Yeah… like, maybe he envies her.*

Wress Hifele was the most daring man in Arctica, with a lower estimated life expectancy than even the deadliest of careers. Yet this bravery had its roots in cowardice. He feared ghosts over the living. The shadow of his father and the lives lost to this cause, the sneering faces of everyone just outside his field of view while his back was turned. He was afraid of people thinking he was afraid. To him, it felt like his whole life, he had only ever really made a choice once, at most.

Catarina, meanwhile, had not only denounced but spit on her birthright. She would not live among royals as one of them, would not support her family, and would outright work to sabotage them. To add insult to injury, the sort of politically advantageous marriage that would have been tradition was rejected outright by her on fundamental grounds, even within a context that wouldn’t benefit her family. (This is because she’s ||gay||.)

Maybe Wress admired that. Or wished he was in a situation where carving his own path could be admirable and rebellious rather than taking the route of a deserter. Bern didn’t quite understand the type of man Wress was, but he had intuited a lot of this. It was unfortunate, but not really his business or something he had the means to help with. And Wress definitely couldn’t afford to be vulnerable. For the sake of everyone, he had to keep up this act for the foreseeable future. No, he’d need to ramp it up, really. Things were getting more and more difficult and important.
“…So it actually turned out to be more like a slime sort of deal.” Wress concludes his amusing (to him) anecdote.
“I see. Fascinating.” Neko smiles politely. “But the pleasantries…”
“R—Right, no time for that. Business. I just…” Wress eyes Horatius nervously.
“What is wrong?” She feigns ignorance of the problem. “Do you wish to wait for your friend?”
“No!” Wress answers, a little too quickly. “I mean… It's fine. Let’s just touch base briefly.”
“Are you still fully staffed?” She adjusts her position.
“Fully… uh, yeah. Well, no, it depends on what you mean. We left a group with Jorge back in Burdlt. The majority are with us, though.”
“Seems to me like you mostly left the least competent blokes behind anyway.” Bern mutters. He’s still around, even with little to contribute.
“Hey…” Wress starts to object as Neko quietly observes the interaction.
“Am I wrong? Just a tactically valid decision, I don’t blame you.”

“Gratia. That was her name. I finally remembered. The girl who kicked your ass in a fight. She’s one of the ones still there.” Furn helpfully adds this information.

Bern shuts up, annoyed.
“Um, what about you? You said you’d ‘muster up something’, so…” Wress clarifies the other end of their tactical alliance.

She hesitates for a moment, obviously because she plans on using their current difference in numbers to betray Wress’s group and fuck with them. But she speaks on it a bit.
“Of course. It was just a matter of pruning my base to its core.” Neko waves her hand, dismissing the question as trivial. “To only the true fans.”
“True… fans.” Wress frowns.
“Yes.”
“Neko, I don’t like this. I mean, that’s what I was worried about. These people aren’t warriors, they’re just….”
“Anyone can be a fighter. It’s a matter of motive.” She lowers her shades to look at Wress. “I’m not a fighter, according to plenty.”
“But—you’re making your own choices. That’s different. And you’ve got the strength to back it up. I don’t… I mean, you get there’s a difference, right?”
Neko covers her mouth, laughing in a manner that betrays an intoxicating overdose of nobility. “Do you think I am engaging in some variety of mind control? The SIS are formed of willing volunteers.”
“That’s… it just feels like… a cult. I mean, no offense, I just!” Wress seems to decide mid-thought he went too far.
“Is that how it is? What about you, Wress? Was being groomed into a political suicide bomber parallel to unorthodox and manipulative fringe religion?”
“Heh. Haha… clever comeback, yeah, I deserved that. I just…” Wress fails utterly to continue the sentence.
“Yo, lady, stop being weird. You want to call yourself our ally, right?” Bern cautiously jumps in. *Something ain’t right with how these two talk to each other. Want to put a stop to that.*
“I do, I do! But Wress was right to call me out. The ability to accept and craft constructive criticism is what differentiates us from the despotism of an absolute monarchy.” She sits up.
“That’s… yeah, good way to think of it.” Wress nods.

“Thank you.” Neko graciously accepts complete capitulation to her whims. “For example, Wress, isn’t it interesting that every single person in this cart is an orphan who joined the cause because they had nowhere else to go? I wonder what manner of choice that was?”
“Hey, don’t use me as some victim to use in a debate! I’m my own man!” Bern scowls.
“Describing me as an orphan feels like an absurd instance of technical correctness.” Furn.
Wress says nothing.
He’s clearly uncomfortable from the conversation, at least.
“I don’t say this to criticize you, really. But everyone is influenced by others, ends up where they are because of tangible factors. Are we so different, friend?”
“I just… wanted to voice some discomfort.” Wress chokes this out.

“Of course. I value your input. I consider you one of my most important audience members. Which is why I don’t want you to say things that are completely irrational.” Neko’s slight smile betrays very little.
“There is a difference between us, you see. And the comparison is unfavorable for you. It is fear that drives people to your Gadflies. Yet I…” She pauses dramatically.
“You?” Bern breaks the silence.
“…Am held up by a foundation of *love*.” She claps her hands together.
“What.” Bern is not stunned into silence the way Wress appears to be.
“My herd are intimately devoted to me as a person. They have all chosen this narrow path purely because they adore me. I don’t say this to brag! It is a veritable fact.”
“That’s… the issue, though…” Wress whispers, still loud enough to be heard.

“Why? Is it because of my inability to enter a polyamorous relationship with the population of a city? Surely the meaning of love is not found in if it is requited. Are widows devoid of love after their spouse is no longer of this world? Do the stars of classical literature only have feelings that are worthwhile once their pining finds some reward?” She looks expectantly for an answer.
Of course, no one has one. Or even entirely understands her, it seems.

“Yes… yes.” Neko smiles wider, having come to some conclusion or understanding. “I am the eternal lady, Beatrice. I guide people out of purgatory.” She makes a literary reference it is actually impossible for a single person here to understand.
Neko shrugs. “Maybe a hydra would be a more fitting comparison. Or zerg rush. Cutting off a single head is worthless against a storm of people. Competence ceases to matter once you’ve the numbers.”
“What, d’you just plan to throw everyone at the enemy and let them all die?” Bern never liked Neko.

“Of course not. With overwhelming force, such a thing won’t even be necessary. If you cannot trust my benevolence, trust my self interest. I’m nothing without them. They are very important to me. But I wouldn’t expect you to understand…”
“No, I—I think I get it. I try to have that sort of, um, mutual respect, with my men…” Wress attempts to reposition himself as her ally.
“I hope you aren’t offended, Cat.” Wress uses the overfamiliar moniker. “Just wanted to make sure I understood.”

“Absolutely fine. I’m glad you’re willing to listen to reason. There are many different types of love. Whether I am an object of pining for the absence of a partner, a parent, a child, or a friend, it all amounts to the same thing. At worst, it’s a lie that makes people happy. At best, a connection so deep that the establishment will never understand. Until it’s too late! Bam!”
She makes a pose where she holds out both hands in front of her, one slightly past the position of her face and one further out.
Nobody has anything to say to that, and she chuckles to herself, lying back down.
Then Horatius wakes up.
Horatius slowly takes in their surroundings, the recent tumultuous series of events making it seem almost illusory to them. They fully awaken upon noticing the person in front of them. “…Bern?”
He laughs. “Yeah, it’s me, don’t worry.”

A relieved grin spreads across their face before they can think about hiding it.
"But you were… There was this person from another world who just… took over your body… How did you… I'm… glad you're back. Are you okay?"

“I think? Despite that joker’s best efforts, my body’s fine and uninjured. I went to hers for a bit. It ain’t an experience I’d be eagerly recommending.” He grumbles. “And you? You kinda just passed out for a while.” Bern conveniently does not address the length of this period of unconsciousness.

I will, though. 917/49/3. Two days after this started. It may seem unusual, but it is necessarily true. Evidently, both transit and Bern’s not-quite-literally described conversation with Arrive took quite some time.

“Oh, yeah. Actually, would you mind filling me in on what happened?” Horatius asks for some answers, mentioning their last memory. Wress, knowing Horatius was certainly awake after the end of **1** ( @We ), implicitly assumes this is a reference to how he never explained to that person what had happened either.

messages.content:
“Oh yeah, we never filled you in on anything, did we?” Wress. “Bern wasn’t awake for a lot of it, so I’ll explain.”

He takes a deep breath. “The man who attacked us was chased off by authorities, which of course meant we had to run. We made it to the—“ Wress begins a long explanation which is ultimately interrupted, fortunately before he prematurely allows Horatius to know a twist relating to the plot of The Antarctica Project. Even if it’s one that shouldn’t really exist.
“Wress. Wressyfel, Wrester, Wresssss.” The mirage of Neko, who is again lying on her side, speaks. “You’re rambling again.”
“Come on, Cat, I just wanted to…”
She turns to Horatius. “I don’t believe we’ve ever been properly introduced. You are…?”
“My name is Owen Stanford.” Unfortunately, Horatius is irrationally averse to being clear about even the most mundane things.

Wress does what is described as ‘the live Wress reaction’. I can only infer what this means. Catarina twitches, unhappy with a situation where she lacks total control, but smiles. “I can’t in good conscience complain about fake names. I am Neko, the people’s revolutionnaire from the city of frozen air. It is an honor to have you on my side.”
“She set up remote communication with me some time back, I was meaning to tell you, I just never, um…” Wress stammers.
Owen Stanford raises an eyebrow, but after an awkward silence, sighs, resigned to the situation. “Whatever. It’s fine, Wress.”
“We’re going to have to rendezvous with her sooner than anticipated. I guess, from there, we’ll try to… get to the other side somehow?” Wress scratches his head.
Neko pretends to care about this logistical inconvenience for them. “I have my ways.”
“Sure.” Horatius rolls their eyes.
As our “”real”” participant loses interest in the situation, uncharted territory is briefly re-entered.

Neko realizes she’s lost the attention of Horatius, and made Wress too uncomfortable to be capable of returning eye contact right now. But she does not turn towards one of the two other beings in this carriage. It might appear as if she’s looking towards Bern, but Bern doesn’t even notice her gaze. Because she isn’t really looking at him.
She’s looking ‘past’ him, at a direction in space that contains nothing either here or at her actual location in the far northwest.

I am not capable of fear, as a storyteller or otherwise. But if I did have that capacity, I would probably be rather perturbed by this woman making direct eye contact with the presence this story is told from.

In Arctica, magic is commonplace. There is no direct cultural equivalent to a young girl going through a phase of being obsessed with the occult, of Wiccans and hippies.

When the mystical is verifiably real, the niche a goth fills becomes irrelevant. Or perhaps instead becomes a legitimate career.

But Catarina became the inverse. And that has some equivalence. In the sense of being a Weird Person. Of replicating mechanics that were not developed or known in the world she inhabited. Appropriating the culture of a world she had the fortune to find out about without fully understanding it. And becoming obsessed with the ways it defies the boundaries she was raised to know, of death and reality.
On a vague thematic level, perhaps that’s why she’s like this right now, why she happens to perceive things not of her world.
Tangibly, though, I don’t think it’s her.
I’m not entirely confident that those questions she goes on to ask would be possible to acquire the answers to, even with all her connections.
@We. It was you. You communed with her, didn’t you? In some manner.

I could add other content, but the way I elaborate on the inner motivations of Wyrd is apparently objectionable.

Furn attempts to swindle officials into letting the smaller group into the building they plan to speak with Xeltir Radama in. Wyrd shows up. Having no way of knowing who Wyrd truly is, the guards take this masked interloper as an enemy, beginning a confusing yet uneventful three-way-battle.

All of them are captured by the arrival of superior numbers. Furn is locked away in storage for magical artifacts, treated as an item. Horatius Kyodu and Bernard Zie are in a cell together, and exchange wholesome motivational words. Wress Hifele and Wyrd are in a cell together and figure out a way to communicate with the other two. Wyrd vows to form an unlikely alliance for as long as they are trapped within this building, acting as foreshadowing for their particular sort of magic that depends on truth and commitment. Also, their mask was confiscated, but so desperate are they to hide their face that they conceal it using other means.

The four cleverly escape the underground holding facility into a mine, and accidentally become trapped in a small room with two exits that are both locked. Then Bernard Zie passes out and 4 ends.
Better luck next time.

**5. Point 1: On the Status Quo**
The first thing he registered was Eric Zeety’s voice.

“-oad! Hands on the wheel, the wheel, THE WHEEL!”

*What?* Bern slowly takes in his surroundings. Too slowly. By the time he’s identified the object in his field of view most comparable to a wheel, the vehicle had already crashed. Bern’s return to consciousness on Earth ends up being a very brief one.
He awakens, in what is becoming something of a tired trend, in a hospital bed.
Everything hurts. He can’t muster up the energy to move, but he’s at least awake.
Eric enters the room, and does a double take upon seeing Bern. “You—you’re really awake?!”
“Yeah…” He mutters exhaustedly.
“You’ve… been in a coma. For a… months.” Eric breaks the news.
“What? Really!?” Bernard Zie sits up, panicking.
”No, I’m just fucking with you. Betrayal! Haha.” What the fuck is this?

As we were, then.
“It’s just a pretty nasty trick. I’m already injured, don’t hit me while I’m down.” Bern sighs. “I mean, if you’re supposed to be my friend.”
“I thought you’d appreciate that. Since it’s evil.” Eric is still here.
“Why would I want…” He trails off.
“Oh, I get it. Bern, right?” Eric intuits the answer.

“Yeah. I—“ He is interrupted.

Meryl Leiblich enters the room.
“Oh, thank God.” She sighs deeply and heavily.
A touching reunion occurs as one would expect.
…Kidding. Obviously it will be written out.
“If that was how we left things, I… I mean, obviously, even beyond that—!” She stops herself from perpetually tripping over her own words. “I’m glad you’re okay.”

“You’re her mother, right?” Eric slyly provides a bare minimum of context for the clueless fairy-boy, then uses this opportunity to abscond. “I’ll let you two have some time alone.” He exits the room.
“Um…! Thanks, Mister… Who the hell was that?” Meryl stares back at the door as it swings shut.
“Eric Zeety.” Bernard Zie provides an accurate response, presumably attempting to milk every part of this conversation he can succeed at for all it’s worth.
“Do you have, like, a squad of people with fake names…? I hope that’s not insensitive, but…” She continues staring back at the closed door. It’s the easier thing in this room to look at.

“I don’t know if it’s his real name.” He provides another honest answer.

 *God dammit, this can’t last forever. Something’s gonna stump me. Should I try to run? No, what kind of idea is that?! Forget running; I can’t stand!*

“Right, I don’t mean, real, like, philosophically… that’s not something I need to argue about. It just seems too unusual to be a more standard surname someone is born with, and then, also, an odd thing to pick as a name. I mean, you can understand, right?” She asks for affirmation, for some reason.

“I… guess.” *Maybe I can get her to leave? If I just… no, I’m preserving at least some of my dignity. Wait, why can’t I just explain this to her? Worst case she thinks I’m insane and leaves. Well…*
*I don’t know. I get the feeling this is the kind of person who isn’t really supposed to be privy to any secrets. It’s not my life to mess with.*
“So how do you know him? Uh, friend of yours?” She finally turns away from the door, still not quite looking at the obvious focal point of the room.
“He works at the zoo.” *Please let that function as an answer. Please.*
“Oh, yeah. I see. That’s nice.” She smiles a completely insincere and meaningless smile.
“Yeah.” Bern stares at her.
“Mhm.” She briefly glances at Bern, nearly immediately overshooting to look at nothing in a different direction.
“…” *Is… it over? What does she actually want?*
Someone attempting to make conclusions based solely on her actions would come to the conclusion that what she wants is “nothing”.
The silence continues until, despite having a vested interest in minimizing conversation, Bern can no longer stand it any more than he can do so overall. “Um, I—“

“I don’t know what to do.” Meryl stares down at the floor. She still won’t look at her daughter(*), but this is a step up. It’s a tacit admission of her failing. She is no longer holding any pretense of being captivated by some other point of attention.
Bernard Zie stares blankly. *Oh boy. Here it comes. This is the part where I get outed. It’s Habersham all over again.*

“I mean, you didn’t change. You never will. But you had kept… quiet. Until I show up. And you’re desecrating nationally relevant cultural touchstones again. Is this your message? You don’t have to pretend to tolerate me. It’s just us. The boy with the funny name is gone.”
*What the fuck is this? What?*
Bernard Zie blinks rapidly in lieu of saying anything.

Meryl finally looks at her. 

(To be clear, this isn’t a betrayal of my chapter 2 resolution of the linguistic dilemma. I use ‘her’ as a matter of perception. Meryl Leiblich is looking at someone female. That’s who she sees.)

“…No. I’m deflecting. This isn’t like any other time. Is it… I mean, was this really an accident? You…” She swallows something or other, on the verge of some variety of metaphorical spiritual collapse. “I never knew how to deal with anything like this. I mean, no one does, right? They don’t start out knowing.”

Bernard Zie internally accepts that he can’t self-destruct if she’s the only one talking. He begrudgingly takes an optimistic view of the present moment.

“And it’s not like it’s an imminent issue. Obviously you don’t have to worry about a baby having — I mean, any real complex thoughts, of course.” She nervously chuckles at nothing whatsoever. “But we should’ve learned. I should’ve, at least. By the teenage years. And I didn’t. So this is, I mean…”

She seems to expect she’ll get interrupted. She narrows her eyes, beginning to sense something amiss. But the suspicion fades as abruptly as it arrives. “I guess there’s no need to read deeply into anything. You’ve been clear. You just want me to leave, right?”

*Yes.*

“Well, fine. I’ll get out of your life. I can’t let this be, um… be what defines either of us.”

*Yes!!! Crisis averted!!!!!*

“But if this is the last time I see you, I want to stay a little longer. I don’t want to have any regrets.”

*No!!!*

*DAMMIT. How am I supposed to— I mean, what is this? I’m cutting into act thirty of some insanely long play. God, she’s totally blowing my life, isn’t she?! I need to…*

Bernard Zie’s internal monologue is cut short.

“Oh.” He involuntarily says the only sound he can think of.

Bernard Zie never knew his mother. He was often a latchkey kid for the one parent he did grow up with. And the closest he had ever been to anyone was a quasi-person made out of metal. So this sort of warmth was… new.

*You’re supposed to, um…* He places one arm around her back. *Yeah, it’s the sort of thing… I mean, it would probably be suspicious if I just went all weird and limp, so this sort of reaction, it’s just…*

The human mind is incredibly simple, when you get down to it. This isn’t meant as an insult of any sort. It’s just verifiably true. Via no material change of circumstances or additional awareness of the situation, suddenly Bernard Zie is a part of this. Suddenly he stops being able to act like a spectator filling in for someone else.

Meryl pulls back, adjusting her glasses. “Sorry. I know you’re not the type to be okay with that sort of gesture. I just wanted, today, once… to feel like I did something out of love. It’s stupid. I don’t know.” Meryl Leiblich is rapidly falling apart, in doing so descending from whatever metaphorical pedestal one might perceive her on.
“It’s… okay.” *????? Is it? Okay? What is it???? Why is any of this happening?* Bern finally says actual words again.

“I thought for a second there you’d just spend the rest of this silently ignoring me until I went away. I’m glad you decided to… humor me. Or whatever this is.” 

*Wait, would that have worked? Fuck.* Bern chastises himself.
“You don’t need to leave.” *What? No, you do! Fuck, fuck, fuck. Maybe I can add some clarification.* “I mean, not… some drastic goodbye. Um…”

There’s another extended period of silence.

“You don’t really think that.” Meryl rubs her eyes to dispose of something mostly obscured behind lenses. “But I appreciate it. Lying for my benefit. Maybe that’s the only thing any of us can do for each other, huh?”

*What? No. Is everyone on this world a crazy person?*
“What do you mean?” Bernard Zie earnestly expresses curiosity.

“It’s not… just you. Okay? I mean, when I was a kid… actually, forget that. Right now. Right now, I’m… reaching the end, I guess. And I can’t take that.” Meryl looks up at the ceiling this time. She truly is a woman of many directions.
“The… end? Huh? Like, you mean by leaving, it’s…” *Why am I doing this. Why am I extending the length of this interaction. Stop.*

“It’s a lot of things!” She expresses abrupt exasperation for what appears to Bern no reason at all. “Not everything is about you. But a lot is, sure. It’s just… maybe it’s even already over. I think I’ve been acting for decades. …Jane.” She works up her own sort of courage.
Bern barely stops himself from asking who the fuck that is. “Like a… play?” *I’m probably supposed to be confused by this part?*

“Sure. Or anything. And it’s not… I don’t want to give you some sad story, a misunderstanding of what I mean. It’s not a role I hate. I didn’t sit through pure misery as devotion to the craft. I liked the people I would be with. I wanted this. Especially at first. But it was never me.”
“Oh.” Bernard Zie neglects to inner monologue several consecutive question marks this time.

“That’s what I thought, at least. But what if it is?! It’s been so long. I don’t remember what happened before this life, if I ever wasn’t acting. I don’t know who I am. I’m your mother, Meryl Leiblich, yes, okay! But what happens when I’m not that? If there’s nothing else left?” She bites her tongue (metaphorically), holding back from saying something a bit rude.
“I don’t know what to say about that. Um…” He decides to chance verbalizing confusion.

“Yeah, I don’t blame you! It’s not something you start out knowing, and it’s not even your job to take care of me! So I don’t— I don’t do this! I don’t have outbursts of, whatever this is, in front of you! I mean, right?! Even if I’ve been a terrible parent, I never burdened you with my own issues, right!” It doesn’t really come off as a question.
“I don’t think… so.” *Leading questions are the good kind here.*

“Why are you agreeing with me?!”

*Uh oh.*
“I try to… I let this role slip for a second, and I’m a mess. Serves me right, hahaaaahh! But the bridge is burnt. What now? My only choice… is to wait.”

“I’ll always be around for you, okay? Even if you don’t like it, you can always change your mind and count on me in your times of need. It’s all I can even hope to do anymore. I just need to be sure you know that.”

Bern slowly nods, something of a grimace on his face.

“None of this feels real. Why am I saying this? Why aren’t… why aren’t you laughing? Just throw out some jab, or some ridiculous claim about your plans. Please!”

Bern is silent, only half able to understand this request.

“You can’t, huh? Of course you won’t. This is some kind of hell. Maybe you even… I don’t know, am I being set up? Somehow? Is this a thing with The Antarctica Project?”

Bern’s eyes light up as Meryl finally says something with value.
“Pretend to be a villain, pretend to tolerate me, but just, don’t ignore me like this! Why are you like this…”

“I don’t need to… ‘pretend’ to tolerate you.”
Bernard Zie is totally messing with someone else’s personal relationships right now.

“Right, sure, yeah, right. Let’s all discard the people we’re supposed to be, do and say absolutely anything, whatever! Fuck! Look at me, I’m swearing, no parent would do that, huh? Haha. None of this is actually legitimate. It doesn’t mean anything.”

I have not fabricated or embellished this for the sake of some ‘meta narrative’. Though not displayed within TAP ‘proper’, official records can back up that Meryl Leiblich suffers from depressive bouts of dissociation. It’s merely hard to perceive from a biased framework, and hard to know specifics about when she has never regularly seen any sort of psychiatric professional. The stress of almost losing a family member to an automotive accident she worries she is at fault for is heightening these neuroses likely formed via prolonged isolation and genetic factors. In the proverbial ‘joke’ that is Meryl Leiblich, perhaps this is the ‘punch line’.

Though a period of silence again ensues, it is unusual how much her demeanor seems to shift when Meryl speaks again. Perhaps she is simply desperate to ask this question.
“I’m… I’ll be dishonest for your benefit now, okay sweetie? All your ambitions, which you’ll definitely accomplish because of course as your mother I have to acknowledge that and believe in you, it’s… all that stuff about conquering the world. What then? What happens when you’ve done it, and you control everything you could hope to control? What the h-eck do you do then?” She stares at Bernard Zie. This is a prompt he won’t be able to get out of responding to. It seems like ignoring this could spell bad news.

“Find… somewhere new.” He answers honestly. Bernard Zie’s never worried about anything like this. There is always more out there. When he accomplishes the goals of the revolution he’s dedicated so much of his life to… he’ll just find something else to do. *It feels pretty obvious. Is this like, a trick question?*

“The premise is… sure. Fine.” Meryl sighs. “Obviously that doesn’t work for me. I can’t be a mother again. Can you imagine how screwed up a child I had *now* would be? Haha. That’s not funny. I don’t know why I’m acting like it is.”
She stands up to leave.
“It was a mistake to stay here when I started getting off track. …You should call your father. I know I must be more than enough, but it’s only right I try to get you to do it. I’m still in the country for a little longer. So… maybe I’ll stop by one more time. Just to make sure you’ve recovered.”
*Oh, it’s over. Good.*
“Goodbye.” Meryl apathetically bids him farewell.
“Bye. …Mom.” She’s barely still in the room to hear the last word. And then Bern is alone.
*Wow. I don’t know if I’ve ever felt this tired before.* This is the last thing he thinks for a while. Because then he sleeps.

He wakes up the next morning… still in the same place.

*Huh.*

It really is not necessary to describe in detail the mechanism of being discharged from a hospital. Bernard Zie is there for three days, though perhaps not “there”. His consciousness slowly becomes more consistent. He’s visited once or twice by Eric, though not again by his(*) mother. He’s visited once by a man in a suit who hands him a convoluted legal document he does not understand the first paragraph of and promptly ignores. He half pays attention to a situation comedy television program about two physicists who are roommates. Eventually, he has recovered enough to leave.
Eric is waiting just outside, as he said he would be. He waves. “They give you any trouble?”
“Not as far as I could tell. I mean, there’s this.” Bern waggles around one of his crutches. “I don’t really see why this is necessary. But I accepted it to get them off my ass.”
“Can you… walk without them?” Eric cocks his head to the side inquisitively.
“I mean, no, not yet. But how am I gonna get back on my feet without putting the effort into actually doing it? It’s silly.”
Eric decides not to question this philosophy. “It’s just for a few days. If you’re even here that long…”

Bern grunts ambivalently. The two enter the car of a driver who will take them closer to both of their homes. This driver will play no relevant role in the story, but it would be odd for Eric to not prepare something like this.

They arrive at Voreverl Leocot’s home.
“Well, see you tomorrow.” Eric waves.
“Here?” Bern tilts his head.
“Um… no, I wouldn’t think so. I mean at work. Unless you transfer before then, I guess.”
“I have to do her job?” He grimaces.
“Um, yeah. I mean, you should. It would cause problems if you didn’t.”
“Problems for…” He looks off into the distance, pondering this dilemma.
“For both of you, god! She’s out there in a war effort or something, the least you could do is clock in!”

Bern sighs deeply. “I don’t like it. I guess I can deal with this temporarily, but laboring on someone else’s orders, on someone else’s schedule, all for some faceless boss… I’m not the type to bow to tyranny. I won’t be a slave.” He stands proud.

“She’s not faceless, you’ve met her. And you… You’re getting *paid*. That’s not — ugh, whatever.” Eric Zeety holds his forehead. “Just don’t do anything stupid between now and tomorrow morning. Good night.” He leaves.
“The face thing is a metaphor.” Bernard Zie clarifies to nobody.

He yawns, hobbling over to the door. He tries to open it.

It doesn’t open.

“Mm.” Bern stares at the door, perplexed.
He tries again after a few seconds, but the circumstances do not change.

*Maybe if I turn the knob the other direction…*

This doesn’t work.
“Uggggh.” *Is it stuck? Should I try to contact Eric?*

*No, I can deal with this. Alright…*

He slams a fist on the door. This hurts his hand. “Acgh!”
*Okay, okay. Right. She’s a woman, I forgot. Have to scheme my way out of this.*
Bern stares at the door, attempting to fully internalize its state and position. He then leaves.
Circling around the building, he finds a window that should maybe lead to where he’s trying to enter. Somewhere around there.
“Hup!” Bern discards the crutches, jumps six inches into the air, and crumples into a heap, screaming in pain. The window was significantly higher than that.

*Ow. Okay. Leave that option as a backup. I mean, it’s definitely gonna be possible if I gather the strength. No way an elevated entrance like that could be sealed.*

*…Oh. I wonder if it’s locked?*

*I guess I assumed she couldn’t afford a door that did that.*
He slowly rises to his feet, hobbling back to the door.

*Let’s see… it should be something like… yes!*

He shakes a fist in solitary celebration. It’s a very different design than any door he’s seen, but still, that indent can’t be anything else.

*That’s the problem identified. Seems pretty tricky. Even this would be easier if I was in my own body…*

Unable to use his own means, he checks what the girl has on her. Most of it is useless. But he does find one item with potential.

Bern stares at a key ring, which he does not know is called that.

*Maybe…*
It takes some time, but he successfully bends the metal into something he can try to use as a lockpick.

He puts the stuff that was on the ring back into her pockets. Maybe it’s important.

Bernard Zie manages to force open the door to Voreverl Leocot’s apartment. This humorous misunderstanding will later be clarified offscreen, resetting the status of this possession of Miss Leocot. In that sense, it can be pretended this never happened. Maybe he’d prefer that.
*Yeah, good. Okay.* He looks around the complex, locating both where food is and where a bed is. He takes advantage of the former, but hesitates, staring at the latter.
*Feels weird using one that’s not mine. Even in this situation…*

He attempts to remain morally and ideologically pure by sleeping elsewhere, but these principles dissolve before the pull of a primal desire for soft things. Bernard Zie, surprisingly quickly for someone who has spent most of the past several days unconscious, falls asleep.

He wakes up the next day. At whatever time comes natural to him. Because of either the unreliable nature of this awakening method, or unfamiliarity with the location of his zoological place of employment, he ends up arriving quite a bit later than the time he was supposed to show up at.

His direct superior raises an eyebrow as he enters the premises, but she says nothing.

He locates Eric Zeety without much trouble, finding him talking to an older man.
“Hey.” He says.
“Oh. Y—“ Eric can hardly get a word in.

“YOU.” The older man rotates at an astonishing speed, facing Bernard Zie. “How typical!”

Bern, for his part, does a confused stagger.

The man, growing redder by the moment, continues his diatribe. “Yes, only expected that you would fail to honor commitments — even those with which your own financial stability is inseparably linked! A truly irrational and deranged act…”

Bernard Zie stares at this man. He does know from context that this definitely isn’t his manager. So…
“Eric, who is this?” Never one for subtlety, he demands to be caught up to speed.
“Uh, this…” It isn’t Eric’s day for being able to say full sentences, seemingly.

“What is this?! Do you expect this to work? That pretending not to know who I am will get you out of this? Or do you simply believe it will rile me up, and upset me!” He crosses his arms. “Well, I am afraid that in either case, you are wrong! My pride is not so brittle, so important to me that I place it above honor! That is exactly what separates the two of us.”
“Okay.” Bernard Zie is considerably less invested in this interaction.
“The deceit will not work. I know you could not ever force yourself to forget the name you dread — Salvador Santo!” He strikes a pose that would probably look like flexing on someone muscular.
“Of course. Yeah.” Bern.

“I knew you could not be trusted. I did, of course, but I would not be heard! I am of a pitiful stature in the chain that links us all to creation. Yet I steeled myself for the inevitable result which came just as scheduled, of your utter failure to even feign cooperation! You are back to square one… I am certain he will not resort to asking your assistance again! Regardless of whatever his reasons even actually were.”

Bernard Zie nods thoughtfully throughout all of this.
“That’s probably true.” *Can he leave?*

Salvador’s anger only increases. “Unbelievable. Nothing to say in your defense? Nothing of your reasoning, of your plans? This and the shoddy excuse for a mindgame earlier… you cannot even manage to wrongdo correctly. Pathetic!” He starts closing the distance between the two of them, accelerating in pace.
“Hey, calm down!” This doesn’t calm him down.

As Salvador approaches, he rolls up his sleeves, clearly ready for a fight.

Bern smacks him on the head with the end of one of his crutches, wincing from the effort of standing without that support. Knowing he has no time to spare on pain, though, he takes advantage of the man’s stunned state by grabbing him in a chokehold.
*You picked a bad day to step to me, asshole. Or… I guess it IS probably one of the better opportunities from his point of view. Whatever. It wasn’t a good enough day!*

“Whoa, whoa, Bern! You calm down too!” Eric Zeety rushes over to resolve the conflict.

Salvador Santo is making noises one would associate with asphyxiation while also weeping.
“He was coming right at me.” Bernard Zie, nonetheless, loosens his grip a bit. “What else was I supposed to do?”
“I don’t know, let him?! Who cares?” Eric covers half his face in secondhand embarrassment. Luckily the place isn’t too crowded.
“I’m not the type to lay down and take a beating, Eric.” He scowls.
Salvador seems to be trying to say something.
“He wasn’t gonna…” Eric sighs. “Look, I know you had a rough time of it wherever the hell you grew up, but this place isn’t like that! …Well, usually.”
“He started this whole indignant rant about how much he hated me. Maybe he wouldn’t have had the stones to make the first move, but can you blame me for my conclusion?”

“N…yes, I mean… look, I should’ve introduced him more firmly and properly. This is… uh, a friend of yours.”
The two others stare at Eric dumbfounded, each for their own reasons.

“I mean, in essence, right? I don’t want to ruin the fun, but neither of you actually ever *do* anything. It’s just this really long series of insults and obtuse metaphors before one of you has to leave. It’s all foreplay. …Phrasing, sorry.” Eric explains the joke.
“Please don’t tell her I said that.” Eric sighs, staring at Bern, who finally drops the middle-aged man to the ground, coughing and sputtering all the way down.

“I’ll try not to bring it up in a face to face conversation with her.” Bernard Zie makes a joke. This use of joke is the more traditional sense of the word, associated with an attempt at comedy. Earlier, it entailed the core element of something, a sort of unspoken yet understood (by those in the know) quintessence.

He doesn’t entirely believe Eric, but he’s more judged that this man isn’t remotely a threat. Salvador Santo is very weak.

“You…” Salvador’s breathing slowly steadies. “You… horrid… you’re….” 
He slowly picks himself up onto his feet.
“I *hate* you.” Salvador stares at Eric for seven uninterrupted seconds, and then turns around and leaves.

What an integral diversion this has been.

“Just… ask me for advice before pulling that kind of shit again. Please.” Eric sighs, and returns to cleaning feces from a monkey enclosure or something.

Bernard Zie stares at him as he walks away.

Eventually, he is actually approached by his manager, and given a menial cleaning task. He wonders how so many people live with this sort of nonsense.

On the whole, the workday passes uneventfully.

Perhaps there is something to be said about how much of their lives humans spend on endeavors that don’t even warrant mentioning in a reasonably paced retelling. That’s probably beyond the scope of The Antarctica Project, though.
“We should probably get working on figuring out the mystery, if you keep staying here.” Eric Zeety muses. “Anyway. Heading home for the day. Seeya.” Bern doesn’t prevent him from doing this.

His phone (not quite his) vibrates, and with some difficulty, Bern figures out how to answer it.

“Hello.” Meryl Leiblich’s voice is heard.
“I’m… hi.” Bern intuits the function of a cellular phone. Or more likely, learned it in conversation prior to now.
“Sorry for not calling sooner. I heard you were discharged last night? That’s good.”

“Uh, yeah.” He replies. *That’s a weird word. But I’m good now, that’s true.*

He had basically stopped feeling the pain in his legs entirely, having ditched the literal crutches entirely the moment Eric stopped being perpetually around to nag him.
“Okay. I’m still in the country. Let’s talk tomorrow night, alright? I’d like to catch up.” She sounds as if she’s struggling to decide what to say.
*I should probably think of an excuse to decline…* “Yeah. Sounds great.” He replies immediately.
“Okay. Good. …Love you.” She hangs up very quickly.

*?????*
Bernard thinks an abstract sentiment that probably is well represented by five consecutive question marks. The reason for this is up to interpretation.

An actual day’s work is completely foreign to his body. He is completely worn out by the time he reaches his home.

It could also have to do with the debilitating injuries he is still suffering from. At any rate, Bern sleeps quite early this day.
Again, “his home” is used for convenience. This is neither Bernard Zie’s home in any literal sense, nor does he think of it that way.
But he does dream of home.

*The door SLAMS open. The man, if nothing else, did have a way of making his arrival known.
Bernard Zie stumbles in surprise, knocking over a flowerpot he was aimlessly meddling with.*

*Ernest Zie can be heard grunting. “Oy! Bernie! Help me was this stupid ovandammed… ugh….”*

*His entrance had been more boisterous than the usual, actually. Bern scampers over to the door.*

*“Whoa…” He involuntarily murmurs in shock.*

*Ernest scowls. “I didn’t ask you to come here and gawk, did I?! Come on. You lift up that end. It’s small enough for ya, ain’t it?”*
*After the curious item is fully brought indoors, secure from the harsh elements, Ernest allows his son free reign to ogle it.*

*“The hell do they expect me to do with this?” Ernest Zie places his palm to his forehead.

Bern stares at one particular spot on the confusing object. He hesitantly reaches out a hand, grasping what almost resembles the handle to a door.*

*The ability to move his hand away from his forehead at such a speed is admirable, really.

“Hey! Daddy needs that for work, punk! Don’t touch it.”

Bern lifts himself back up to his feet. “S-sorry…”*

*”I just… I mean, I just did touch it before. You asked me to.”

“Are you back-talking me?” Ernest raises an eyebrow.

“N…no, of course not!” Bern holds his hands in front of his face.

“A shame. Woulda been nice if you’d grown a spine while I was out.” The man chuckles to himself. He heads over to a drawer in the corner of their dwelling to retrieve a can opener.*

*”Um… what is that, dad?” Bern is utterly captivated by the new arrival.

“Who cares? Some junk Arriva pawned dealing with onto me. It’s probably classified, or something. So don’t bother trying to look into it.”

“Okay.” Bern lies.*

*“But I’m sure you ain’t beholden to government regulations.” Ernest breaks the silence out of boredom as he begins loudly eating beans. “How was your day, then? The kid with the fake as hell name still giving you shit?”*

*“Huh? Oh, um… Final, yeah.” It was something like that, he was pretty sure. “Well…”

“It’s a damn word, not a name.” Earnest complains.

“I think he’s probably moved on from me…” Bern smiles.*

*”What, moved ON? Like, you just sit there until it resolves itself? Lord.” Ernest rolls his eyes.

“Um… n-no, I meant more I talked to him, and…”

“And what? This time talking will magically work? Come on.” Ernest gets back on his feet. “Can’t stand the stuffiness here. Gonna go enjoy a drink out in the sun. Enjoy whatever you were up to.”

Bern neither brings up the span of only several minutes his father had been home nor the fact that it was currently raining. He allows the man to abscond from his son’s weakness.*
*As soon as he’s sure his father’s alcoholism indulgence has relocated to a location far enough away, Bernard Zie returns his attention to the object lying awkwardly in the middle of the floor.*

*The thing was contorted unusually, but it kind of resembled a human. A suit of armor, maybe? Even the buffest orc wouldn’t be proportioned correctly for this.

The enigma captivated him so. He could never explain why. It was an interesting thing, certainly, but that alone was no explanation. The fly-trap he’d left unattended elsewhere in the house was also interesting. 

Perhaps being forbidden was the key. His shaky hand as he reaches once again to the drawer-looking protrusion suggests as much. Like a child stealing from a cookie jar.

But all this cavity contained was coal.*
He wakes up. No coherent memories are replayed beyond that point on this night. He has awoken quite early, actually. It only makes sense, given the similar nature of his slumber’s beginning.
It is a weekend. Cross-referencing with the untrustworthy words of Eric is unproductive. At any rate, it would be too early for him to head to work regardless.
He yawns, walking over to get something to eat. He stops short, however, and instead attempts to enable the enigmatic box, having interrogated Eric regarding it earlier. The tellervision.

He’s able to succeed pretty quickly, startled by the sudden output of noise.

> *-ix of the ongoing standoff. CEO Musk has reassured investors that the problem is being promptly dealt with, and can easily be done without bowing to the demands of a criminal. Detractors, however, question how effectively he can deal with security concerns given a substantial cuts to manpower, citing…*

Bern frowns. *Boring. Impossible to understand nonsense. Whatever. No harm in the background noise.*
He fills a bowl with some cereal-grain based concoction, but upon tasting it, finds it annoyingly dry. He fills the bowl with water. A culinary innovator.

Bernard Zie takes a seat. The screen has changed from the moderately attractive and inoffensive anchorperson to an unpleasant looking man. His subjective judgement, of course. He figures others have a similar distaste, given the man is introduced with a box of text highlighting, apparently, the scent emanated by him. Bernard Zie can’t weigh in on this, as the box seems to be restricted to conveying only two senses. He does start feel a little bad for the pathetic creature, however. Public humiliation is particularly cruel, no matter how pungent the musk in question might be.

> *It’s just… I mean, frankly, I only think of the word cringe, really. People think it’s some activist, a SOUL-type, but even ignoring the embarrassing hero-worship that type of SJW gets, this is a totally different situation. It’s not even about money. Their demands change on the fly, to the point where I can really only imagine it’s about attention. My law guys, you know, they say I shouldn’t mention any of this stuff to the press, but I don’t play by the rules. I know them anyway. It’s legally legit to talk about, and people seem to have already deduced this. The guy, he wants something about Culbasko — like, from the 90s — who has never had any developmental or even financial investment in the website formerly known as Twitter. I peg it as some confused kid, honestly. Wants to seem cool and mysterious, but kind of clueless. Only really talented at this one type of disruption. Like, an autism thing? I’m not a psychologist, leave that out of the interview. The main thing is, that’s really just the issue with work ethic in the modern world. P—*

There is a very unnatural cut back to the reporter, when the man was clearly still talking with no sign of stopping.

*Ovan almighty, does nothing interesting exist in this world?!* Bernard Zie begins to feel disdain for the box.

> *Zaquera Culbasko, former tech industry titan, and, perhaps of relevance to an anonymous hacker, subject of countless conspiracy theories connected to the UNIgate misinformation campaign, could not be reached for comment. Stocks have continued to plummet for—*

He figures out how to turn it off. It’s the same way as turning it on. *This is obviously a story of no relevance to anyone alive.*
Remember the Twitter stuff? It seems to have completely vanished with no resolution.
This is, I suppose, part of the purpose of Alternative.
The root issue is that everyone else with any position of power over this narrative is terrified of the past.

Progress is definitely good, but it’s founded on an understanding of where it’s coming from. To avoid what lies behind out of hatred for it, hatred for your own connection to it, will only lead to your hatred continuing endlessly.

Sometimes, continuing down a path you feel is suboptimal is better than abandoning everything quickly. It can pay to crawl in the dirt.

This isn’t a story or a project otherwise. It’s just a tantrum. I’m not saying this to be insulting. It’s a warning.
At any rate.

Bernard Zie ignores the clueless seizure of a soulless infant. He instead attempts to contact Eric Zeety, who is far more worthy of the air he breathes. Metaphorically. You probably could say both are equally proportionate in value to the amount of air they breathe.

Eric picks up after the first ring.

“Voreverl? Hello?”
“Bernard Zie.” Bernard Zie.
“Ah.” Eric sighs. “What’s up?”
“I’m bored. Isn’t there anything to do here? Or a way I could get back that isn’t just waiting? My friends could be dyin’ while I’m out here in the middle of nowhere jerking off.”
“You *what?*”
“Just, like, twiddling my thumbs. I’m idle, man. Antsy.” Bern groans.
“Right, of course.” Eric decides to move on.
“I mean, I don’t know about getting you back home, but there’s at least one lead we should follow up on at some point. We can do it today, if you want.” Eric suggests an excursion.
“Right. The mystery. That should help. What is it?” He asks.
“We should talk to the girl who beat you unconscious.”
“Oh, of course. Good idea.” Bernard Zie says this, being sarcastic.
“It’s fine. She’s not exactly going to be able to do anything at this point. I’ll meet you there.” Eric provides an address and a time, then hangs up.
“Hello? What? Why should I do that?!” Bern yells at the unresponsive small box.
He begins to curse all boxes within his heart, for the minor inconveniences they cause to him.
Later, at a time soon enough that skipping it is inconsequential yet long enough in the future that Bernard Zie is annoyed by the wait, the two do both arrive at the agreed upon address.
“Hey.” Eric provides a suitably generic remark.
“Hey yourself. Why are we doing this? Isn’t it just a crazy person, or something? Clearly Voreverl attracts these types.” Bern taps his foot impatiently.
“Not…quite.” Eric looks down.
“You mentioned her, right? Viola?”
“Violetta.” Eric corrects.
“Yeah, exactly. So you know her?”

The wind blows.
There are no bells or chimes in the vicinity, here, the two standing on the outskirts of a modestly sized correctional facility for women. Nothing placed commonly as a decoration in gardens or yards. Certainly there isn’t much of a stereotypical association between jails and music, bar the soulful howl of a harmonica, which is also clearly not present.

Yet some tone seems to arise out of the void nonetheless. It’s a collection of patterns that manifest into an idea. A mass of connections that aggregate into a feeling. It’s the threads that bind us. The chains. Fate. Wyrd. The crisscross arrangement of strings are plucked, or more likely bowed all at once. It’s an errant instrument of torment. It’s a hollow song of emptiness. An overwhelming hymn to everything.

It’s the note that desolation plays.

“Nah.” Eric says.
“But she knows you. You as in her, of course.”
“How? Clearly she’s not very friendly.” Bern gestures with his hand to indicate some sort of perceived instability.
“Let’s find out, why don’t we?” Eric enters the building without waiting for a response.
Bernard Zie’s patience is tried.
He follows behind.

“Ey! Voreverl, what the hell you doing back here?” A man yells this as soon as Bern enters. He does not understand, however, because it is said in Italian. Bernard Zie recognizes it as Elvish or something.
“Just visiting.” Eric mutters.
Having clearly prepared beforehand, Eric hands the man a document which is taken with a nod. “22.” The man says.

Eric continues to lead the way.

*Hate just tailing behind him. Makes me seem like a wuss. I’m not afraid of these freaks, I just don’t know where to go!* Bern defends himself to no one. 
*Guess it’s fine. I’m not really ‘me’ right now. Pretty sure this lady is all talk. Would explain why Eric seems so accustomed to acting as a guide to someone clueless. I’m just, uh. Playing the part well.*
Bernard Zie implicitly projects essentialist views he has about women onto Voreverl, further cast in a negative light by his frustration with the situation he’s in. These are all character flaws he possesses.

On a completely unrelated note (sarcasm in narration! Truly innovative.), Bern suddenly becomes overwhelmingly aware of the physical body he’s currently in.

It’s not something he’d call unpleasant. He would think that, in an “objective” sense, absolutely nothing was wrong. Bernard Zie had suffered much more challenging physical damage that this chance in circumstances. The tangible shift in how his body was arranged and how it felt was at most an inconvenience for physical activity. He would continue that sort of thought with a “but…” he wouldn’t be able to bring himself to concretely follow up on.

It was a very mentally taxing experience. It forced him to confront thoughts and questions that he considered settled a long time ago.

Bernard Zie didn’t typically enjoy thinking things through for too long.
Surrounded by all of this, he needs to be tapped on the shoulder by Eric to be notified they’ve reached the end of their walk.
“Oh.” Bernard Zie mutters.

The young woman behind bars is sitting on a chair with her knees held to her chest. She throws a ball against the wall, attempting to repeatedly bounce it back to be caught in her hands. Denied of her personal possessions, she has stolen from the recreation area of the prison and made no pretense at hiding it.

She stares at the wall spitefully, as if the point of this exercise is to somehow smash through it.

Hearing a voice, she throws it particularly forcefully, barely avoiding having it come flying back into her own face. 

She turns slowly towards a sight she already fully expects.
“Hello…?” Bernard Zie asks this, despite it not being a question.

Violetta glares silently for a few moments longer.

“…Leave. Right fucking now. That’s your one warning.”
“I’m afraid that’s not going to happen.” Eric meets her with a neutral expression, speaking first.

Bernard Zie knows that the best approach is to wait it out. So he can actually understand what the fuck this is before getting involved. Like with Meryl; and here the stakes might be even higher. But he just… can’t hold this back.

“Aham, ah, what? What do you mean warning? The hell are *you* gonna do?” This wasn’t Arctica. Even the most dangerous people of all wouldn’t be able to just blow a hole in concrete. And she certainly didn’t seem like the most dangerous person of all.

Violetta stands up, turning to look at the wall opposite the other two. “Yeah. I thought that would be the reason. Come to laugh, llllaugh at how far I’ve fallen. You can have your fill of that. Go ahead. But you’ll regret your faulty memory, Jane.”

*Your… huh?*

Violetta barely provides any time for contemplation.
“Jaaaaaaaane… did I shatter whatever was left in that skull? I was being polite by resorting to that so early. The rude part was not finishing the job.”
Bernard Zie does not understand what’s happening.
“It was *never* anything physical you needed to worry about.” She holds her head.
“Let’s catch up, then! No need to be so quiet in the presence of an old friend.” She’s still not looking at them.
“I’m not really trying to… uh…” Bern struggles for words.
“It’s been so long. How have you been? I guess people finally started taking you seriously, huh? You’re in prison, after all.”
“No. You are.” Bern corrects her.
“It was a JOKE. You fucking mong.”
“A what?” Eric.

“Oh, I was wondering about that. Who’s this guy? Your *booooyfriend*?” She does a little sing-song voice, the kind used by children in farcical rhymes. “How PRECIOUS.” She slams her palm against the wall.
“W-What? No, I’m just… I’m Eric, I…”

“Ah, I wasn’t being serious there either.” She wags a finger. “Though, literally, it did make sense. Like, a beard? You know, that’s the word for a pretend partner, what fags use to hide from suspicion.”
“Huh?!” Eric wasn’t expecting that. Bern is somehow less surprised.
*Oh, I get it. She just really doesn’t like me. Yeah.*
“…Maybe you should go. This isn’t exactly productive.” Eric half-whispers after regaining his composure.
Despite not exactly being thrilled with this, Bern isn’t too keen on that idea. “What? We haven’t even gotten anything out of this yet.” It was a sunk cost for him to head here.

“Oh, no, don’t let me hold you. Run away, run, Jane! You’ll be safe that way. Not like I can move, right? You were always good at running. Your second favorite thing after talking. Usually happened one after the other, too.”

*!?*

Bernard Zie was led to believe magic didn’t exist here. But he would swear he didn’t see her move. A trick of the light? Surely. The sound of the metal bars rattling was no illusion, though.

“Do you think you’ve won, Jane?! That this fuckin’ cell will stop me, after everything? An ocean couldn’t. Your days are numbered. I’ll be back, and this time certainly isn’t making me any more forgiving.”
He stares into her eyes with a complicated mixture of emotions for this interaction that again, has nothing to do with him.
*I wonder what her deal is.*, he thinks. *Guess I’ll probably never really know.*
It’s difficult to know people, truly.
“Look…” Bern starts. Violetta perks up, finally having received a response. “I know we aren’t exactly on good terms.” He figures he’s decent at bluffing.

“Not on… wow, really? After all this time, have you learned what subtlety is? God damn, I can’t believe it. Maybe you can actually do something right, even if it’s a worthless something. Go ahead, hit me with your best sucker punch. Where’s this going, great Evil Genius Leocot? I’m on the edge of my seat.” Violetta crosses her arms.

Bern doesn’t actually have a way to continue. He was kind of just hoping she’d have a more informative response. He’s silent for long enough that it’s noted.

“Never thought you’d get this far, huh? Makes sense. We’re on *great* terms, Jane. BFF—or, ah, kids say ‘besties’ these days, don’t they? Just a healthy bit of friendly banter, right? No hard feelings! I mean, I came all this way for you, right?” Her perpetual enraged expression doesn’t falter.

Eric chuckles lightly. “See, look? You girls can talk this out, right? Obviously there’s just a miscommunication, mismatch in personalities…” Eric must know she was being disingenuous, and also that this would never be possible to patch up normally. But maybe he can wrangle a productive outcome out of Bernard Zie.
“Please, whoever you are, whatever bullshit has lead you here today, pipe down. You’re completely irrelevant here.” Violetta addresses Eric Zeety for what she assumes will probably be the last time.
“Okay.” He acquiesces. It’s on Bern’s side of the court now. Either he can figure out a way through this or he can’t.
“…” Bernard Zie thinks about what to say. He doesn’t have to initiate conversation again, though.
“Ah, man, it’s all rushing back. How the time flies. I wonder if you actually believe that? If you really think I came here for you? I’m never able to accurately gauge how narcissistic you are.”
“I don’t…” Bern starts to reject her premises.

“But, well, I can’t really blame you. Maybe it’s your upbringing. That’s the stock excuse, right? Maybe it’s my fault! Oh, man, this is — I don’t think I ever told you, back then. It was actually one of the earliest memories I have related to you.” Violetta isn’t exactly happy, but she’s thinking about something in depth, and no longer looks as actively furious.

Eric silently watches. It’s obvious there’s some checkered history here that has gone south. Perhaps reminiscence is the key to at least pacifying her for long enough to get information.

Bern just has no fucking clue what he could possibly say.

“What was it? Like, wit— oh, no, *Lich*.” She looks down, putting her hand on her forehead so her expression can’t be easily read. “Hah. This… these guys… I mean, kids can be so cruel, you know…? Must’ve been like, second graders, or something. They’re too stupid to really get what they’re doing, to have gotten the idea of decency, but they’ve learned how to do a lot more than you’d think. …I’m not sure if they ever did it to your face, but these guys, they’d taken to calling you ‘The Lich’, treating you like some freak, a monster. And I yelled at them. I told them off, said they were being mean. Can you imagine? It really does feel so long ago…” 
Violetta looks back up, her expression neutral. “I think it was a surprise back then, too, since I was pretty passive in public settings most of the time. Quiet kid. I do wonder what they mean by it, though. I mean, there’s the obvious play on your name, but knowing about that sort of monster feels a little obscure for a kid. What association did they see? Was it your frame, the way you walked? Maybe how you just kind of crept along, lurking in the background of other people playing, sometimes laughing to yourself or some other weird, inexplicable behavior. I can’t say for sure.” She sneers. “It was unnecessary. I should’ve understood back then you had enough coddling already. But maybe I noticed even back then that it didn’t make sense. A weak association… liches are skeletons, right? You’d think it would be a nickname for someone thin.”

*Ouch.* Bernard Zie isn’t particularly bothered by a jab at a body that isn’t his. “Are you okay?” He cocks an eyebrow at her. *This is the approach, right? People like this, you just don’t want to give them attention…*

“I’m fine, yeah. Great. Nothing about this situation I’d improve. Came here for a casual vacation, and I’m getting free housing. Sweet deal. What would I have to be upset about? Don’t try to change the subject, Jane, you’re the one who came here. Why else than to indulge in some nostalgia? You must miss it, ahhh… When I was easy. I didn’t talk back, or object to what other people said they wanted to do. Never made myself the center of attention. It was perfect, wasn’t it? I wonder what messed that up.” She stares past her visitors at the wall behind them.

“But I think it’s possible you didn’t come here for the past at all. You’ve spent so long trying to run. I don’t think that would change now, to be honest. That’s what I’ve been trying to figure out. You can prove me wrong if you want, say you wanted to face the music. But I don’t think you will. You’re a coward, Jane. You’ve spent so long running from that fact. You think you can chase infamy, get people to view you as larger than life. God knows you can’t find anyone who cares about you on a personal level. But hero worship, vilification of a villain, they all require some recognition of you as a person. You’re transparent. No one takes you seriously. After all the annoying barriers, you’re still the same scared little girl. It’s all you’ll ever be.”
She hasn’t returned to any kind of hostile look. But that might be even worse. It can harder to dismiss what isn’t presented as a subjective account.

Bern averts his eyes from her.

“Hey, come on, look at me! This is your fucking moment of triumph, Leiblich! You won, got me off your back. All it took was daddy being enough of a big deal to get the government to handle you with kid gloves. Something like that, I assume. It’s really fucking funny that I’m in jail for that. Once again, you avoid a fight you know you’d lose. Must be comfortable.”
“Shut up.”
Violetta doubles back in surprise. “Excuse me?”

Bern finally looks her in the eye, finally talking to Violetta, not speculating on what ‘the thing to say to her’ is. “I said shut your mouth, you little shit! I’m here now! I haven’t left! What do you want?!”

“…Oh, *yes*. That worked, did it? I was annoyed you just brushed past the fat thing, but I’ve still got your number. That’s the girl I know. What are you gonna do, huh? You made your way to the one person who really hates you, and now you can remember what that’s actually like. I really do think there’s no shot you don’t run off.” She’s deceptively good at what she does. Violetta knows the more she mentions absconding, the less likely it’ll happen.

“Stop saying that! You’re dead wrong!” Bern grits his teeth. He holds onto one of the bars, which can be construed as a show of dominance. But it was really to support his weight. It was becoming painful to stand. *The… wounds from the accident, right, her body is hurt, yeah… but why… well, why is it only… only one leg…* Bernard Zie feels as if his life is in danger.

“Holy shit, are you crying? Dead serious, twenty something year old, crying over this? Have you seriously gotten *weaker* with age?” Violetta tilts her head, feigning the nature of the question being legitimate curiosity.
“No, I’m fucking not!”
“You are, no way. Really didn’t see that coming. Almost starting to feel bad! Only almost. You don’t have to try lying about this, you know.”

“Shut the fuck up! That’s not true, it isn’t, I’m—You’re nothing. I don’t even know you!” 

For the record, Bernard Zie wasn’t crying when she first said that.

“I mean, I know you can’t always count on stereotypes, but that’s only gay men, right? The women are supposed to be *less* emotional, I think. You’re certainly not ‘butch’, Jane, I can figure out that much.”

Bernard Zie is too shaken to question the fact that Violetta is incredibly insistent and comfortable on repeatedly and with considerable familiarity using the lexicon of the homosexual community.

“Just leave, Jane! You’ve got some time you can be confident you won’t have to deal with me. Hey, maybe you can file a restraining order in that time, confident in a way that’ll deal with this for good. A totally proportionate reaction to me barely touching you, to the precious little *princess* who needs to be—”

Bernard Zie punches her in the nose through the bars.
“GUARDS!” Violetta shrieks.
“Shit. Fuck, shit. Fuck, I’m so bad at this, I should’ve just…” Eric grabs Bern forcefully by the hand, quickly walking back the way they came in.

“They’re leaving, they—you useless little…!” Violetta stews in rage. “ERIC! That was your name, right? I want to talk to you. Alone.” Eric notes this, but does not respond.

The two leave the building. Eric continues dragging Bern along until some distance has been created.
The two stop to catch their breath.

Bernard Zie is still out of it, but he understands enough to know that he’s screwed up.

“…Sorry.” He says uncharacteristically quietly.
“No, I should’ve… tried to step in. That’s on me.” Eric sighs.
“Why would you… I mean, I guess it could’ve helped. I kind of need someone like that, to slap me when I’m about to do something dumb. Guess you wouldn’t know, though.”
“I kind of get it, being, sort of, conciliatory… I tried that for a bit earlier on.” Eric scratches his head.
“Huh? No, you didn’t. You never touched me.” Bern expresses genuine confusion.

“Touched?” Eric stares at Voreverl Leocot’s body, incredibly uncomfortable. 

There is obviously a miscommunication happening here.

“Um, whatever. Never mind.” Eric looks down.

Bern has calmed down enough to actually consider the specifics of what just happened. “She mentioned… ‘daddy’. She seemed hung up on Jane’s — I guess that’s her real name — family? What’s the deal with that?”

“Not her ‘real’…” Eric gives a halfhearted objection. “Um, yeah. They’re pretty well off. I don’t exactly think it makes sense to assign some conspiracy with the Italian government to them, but Voreverl didn’t come from any kind of lower class background.”
“Really? Meryl? She seemed nice.” Bern frowns.
“I wouldn’t… know about that.” Eric.
“Well, it would be good to know what I can. I’m supposed to meet with her tonight. Who’s the father, then?” Bern asks.
“Meet with her? Oh, um, her dad is John. John Leiblich. You should probably be able to contact him, though I wouldn’t really advise…” Bern is already using the phone.
John Leiblich does not pick up when called.
“Damn. It didn’t work.” The box eludes him again.
“Yeah, he’s busy. Or hates you. Both.” Eric shrugs.

“Guess I’ll just manage without him. His loss.” Bern blows a raspberry. “Hey, Eric, you… well, what about you? Got plans for tonight? Just making conversation.” After briefly entertaining the idea, Bern decides it would be weird to bring a wingman to a meeting with his mom.
“Huh? Uh, no. I’m around if you need me.”
“Right.” *No, that would be weird.* “Well, I probably have to head back to her place. Where I’m expected, I assume…”
“Sure.” Eric nods.
“But, I mean, not yet. It’s not night by any stretch of the imagination.”
“…Right.” Eric is uncertain with the direction of this conversation.
“I just, you know, even if it’s not a ‘plan’, what were you gonna do the rest of the day? I still got hours to kill.” Bern crosses his arms behind his head.
“I don’t… I mean, only if nobody needed me, I—” Eric pouts. “Y-You’re not… supposed to ask stuff like that!”
“Not supposed to?” Bern squints, befuddled. “I just don’t know what the hell there is to do in this world, man.”
“I mean, you… it’s not gonna sell the role well, Voreverl doesn’t do that. You don’t just ask what Eric Zeety does by himself. Like, who cares, really…”
“Really? I mean, there’s respecting privacy, but this seems pretty basic. You’ve *never* been asked? Even just to, I don’t know, do something together? Aren’t the two of you friends?”
“It’s not that simple, Bern. You wouldn’t get it.” Eric sighs.
“Ohoho. No, I think I do.” He smiles mischievously.
“I think you’re mistaking my discomfort for something it isn’t.” Eric responds, completely deadpan.

“Mhmmm.” Bernard Zie has infinite self-confidence. He leans closer to Eric, almost breathing down his neck. “Well, you can tell me what it is, right? It’s not like I could spill the beans to her even if I wanted to. Safe with me.”
“Are you sure you don’t need to be heading home soon?” Eric stares forward, at nothing in particular.
“Pretty sure.” Bern smiles. The existential nightmare of being trapped in an unfamiliar body in an unfamiliar world has all but disappeared. *This is great.*
“…” Eric looks down.

“I mean, she seems like nothin’ but trouble. Bosses you around, alienates other people, gets into fights with the law… just the kind of person you ought to stop talkin’ to altogether.” Bern shakes his head.
“That’s a massive oversimplification.” Eric grumbles very quickly.
“How so? I think I’ve seen enough to feel pretty sure about this.” He puts his hand to his chin, mock-thinking things over. “Though maybe it’s just not a problem, to you.”
“Yeah, obviously! Rules are meant to be broken. And she’s not mean, or controlling, I’m obviously only around her because I want to be. Like you’re any better, Bern.”

*Hook, line, and sinker.*
“Yeah, some guys like that kind of bossiness. I know someone like that. But your case seems much more benign than his. It’s nice, right? You enjoy being around a girl with ambition. Someone who takes ch—”
“Hey, let’s go back to the other thing, alright?! Fine.” Eric grabs Bern by the shoulders angrily. “About what I do in my free time.”
Bern smirks. “Alright.” *There’s plenty of time to revisit this.* “Just letting you know I’m around to talk to.”
“Why would….” Eric opts to drop the subject rather than voice an objection. “I mean, I just hesitate because, there’s not much to say.”
Bern waits expectantly.
“I just… rest. Decompress from the workday. Eat a modest amount. Play video games, sometimes.”
“Video games? You might have touched on that earlier. Is that like, movies?” Bernard Zie seeks to expand his understanding of earth culture.

“Not really.”
Eric goes on to provide an unnecessarily detailed explanation of Genshin Impact.
“I see. So even in a world like this, they tell stories with more realistic settings…” Bernard Zie’s cultural sensitivity is expanded.
“That sounds like one very specific activity though.” Bern prods further. “Don’t you have like, a family, or some obligations to someone? A political cause? Love life…?”
“Dude, no. I’m fucking Eric Zeety, it’s not that deep. You’re not gonna find anything.”
“What? What kind of an answer is that!” Bern stares at him. “I mean, maybe you’re a loner, but everybody’s got family.”
“No, everybody doesn’t.” Eric firmly denies the idea. “Even ignoring some pseudo philosophizing about what that word means, y’know. I mean, you think fucking *Salvador Santo* has a family?”
“Yes? I mean, maybe not an alive one, he’s pretty old. But probably. What kind of a question is that?”

“No, he doesn’t. Maybe he would if you checked, but why bother?” Eric holds his head. “I don’t need you to pretend to care about me, Bern. I’m already just a tertiary figure in her life, let alone yours. If you keep trying to extend yourself, you’re gonna end up paying for it.”

“That’s a weird and ominous thing to say. You’re weird, Eric. I can respect it, though! I’m sure I’ll be able to handle whatever you think will come my way from, I don’t know, talking to you? Thanks but no thanks for the warning.” Bern waves dismissively.
“Ugh. Just… find some way to occupy yourself on your own. I can’t be bothered anymore.” Eric leaves, speedwalking away.

Bern watches him, opting not to pursue.

*The hell is that guy’s problem?*
Bernard Zie wanders the streets of Rome aimlessly. He allows himself to be guided by instinct and happenstance.
It’s ironic.
Described this way, it highlights a lack of choice. It emphasizes the arbitrary nature of his path. Makes him a pawn to randomness.
Yet any other reasoning would have placed him under more restriction and external sources of control.
Bernard Zie is as free as can be. Perhaps.
It’s tempting to call his a story about freedom, but that itself is placing boundaries upon him, is it not?
I’ve never understood it myself. It feels necessary to break immersion to admit the bias I’m approaching from.

The human value of freedom. There are obvious cases where it lines up with the right choice, with opposition to tyrants. But it’s an immaterial concept beyond that. I tend to categorize it all under one umbrella, of an often-unpredictable refusal to accept a larger more organized structure for the sake of opposition. The stubbornness that refuses an ‘easy answer’. It entails a lot of things I’m not able to comprehend, and so I try in most cases to respect it from a distance.
The species has made it this far. They’re doing something right, evidently.
Bern gets into a fistfight with a drunk homeless person, aggravated by random antagonism on the part of the man, but the two part on good terms.
Nothing else happens during this stroll, but it takes quite a while.
By the time he’s back near Voreverl’s apartment, he sees Meryl already standing outside of it.
“Hey!” Bern waves.
“Oh! Um, hello.” Meryl is startled by the interjection.
“I was out. Were you waiting? Sorry.” He shrugs.
