“Oh, no, it’s my bad for being unclear with the time. I just assumed… I thought you wouldn’t, um…. anyway…!”

Bernard Zie just kind of stands there as she stammers through communication.

“There’s a good Italian place I saw a few blocks down… or, I guess in this context that’s redundant… should I just say, a place, or rather, a restaurant, since without describing any… I just, I haven’t eaten yet.”
“At all?” Bernard Zie is surprised. “It’s late.”

“Well, obviously I ate earlier today, I just meant…”

Bernard Zie waits for her to finish speaking.

“Look, are you coming, or not?!”

“Sure?” 
*A weird question. Unless she wasn’t asking. I don’t really know how filial piety or whatever operates around here. Eric apparently emerged fully formed from the abyss, so that didn’t really come up.*
“Good. That’s great.” Meryl Leiblich smiles, incredibly uncomfortable.

The two walk to a nearby establishment that serves trivially authentic local cuisine. It’s named after the proprietor, who is some man with an incredibly stereotypical name such as Giuseppe or Mario. While in a melting pot such as the United States, such a person would have a unique economic niche to fill as someone who truly FEELS Italian, here, no such incentive exists. This must therefore entail nothing but pure devotion to the craft motivating the man. A wise choice, truly.

Worldbuilding.

There’s an awkward lack of conversation back-and-forth as the two walk to the establishment. And as they enter. And as they are directed to a table, order drinks, so on and so forth.

Meryl can no longer stand it. 
“I give up. What is this?”
“Eh?” Bernard Zie is startled out of deep contemplation of what *spaghett* is.

“What are you doing here? I was glad you agreed to meet, but this isn’t you.”

Bernard Zie is mid-metaphorical-cardiac-arrest as Meryl continues. “I mean, come on. You always have something to say. You’d have berated me before or after accepting the invitation, or boast about nothing in particular as we walked over. But you’re just sitting there. Obviously waiting for something. The tension is killing me. Whatever you’re plotting, can you just get it over with so we can eat in peace?”

The first few days, Bern would have been stunned and confused into silence by this interaction. But over the last week or so, he has gained a sense of what type of person he’s ‘supposed’ to be on this world, and has been meaning to start actually trying to play the part when it becomes necessary.

*I guess I just still assumed it was only a public-facing act.* He takes a deep breath.

Bernard Zie tips over his glass of water, spilling it onto the tablecloth. “Ha. Gotcha.” This presents a very minor inconvenience.
“*Thank* you.” Meryl rolls her eyes.
She resignedly clears up the spill with a napkin. “It still feels unusual, though. You’re acting different.”

“I… almost died, recently.” Bernard Zie says an honest statement about his life that could possibly be honestly stated more often than not for him. “I mean, it’s gonna make me stop for at least a second, right?”
“I suppose. I’m sorry, I’m not trying to interrogate or berate you. I certainly don’t dislike you having time for me. I just… still don’t get you at all, I guess. Some parent…”
“You’re better than nothing.” Bern makes a confusing statement that merges completely distinct masked and unmasked sentiments.

Meryl sighs. “I haven’t talked to him in a while, actually. …Your father. He’s been out on a trip for quite a while, something of that Antarctica nonsense. That’s all turning out to be absolutely nothing, luckily. …It was… probably about you, the last time we spoke.”
*Weird change in topic.* Bern thinks. Even with his commitment to improving his fraud abilities, he still tends towards shorter responses. “…Me.”

“Yeah. He’s so… he’s still mad about the name thing.” She breaks up her sentence with quiet laughter. “I guess I understand why he feels that way, but it’s just way too… ugh. I mean, I wasn’t thrilled either. But I don’t think that was the principle from me. It’s just… can I be honest? I feel like we’ve been too at odds for me to ever even say this. I just… think it’s a terrible name.”
“You do?” Bern holds back from any immediate feigned reaction.

“Yes. Just… it feels very clunky to say, and… I mean, I don’t really know where it came from for you, but…” She looks to both sides, confirming there’s no one that close in the restaurant, then leans in and whispers. “I looked it up, and, Jane, it’s a sex thing. Vore is like, an internet pervert word. It’s about erotic cannibalism.”

*This girl is FUCKED.*
“Oh.” He doesn’t really have anything else to say to that.

“I guess that’s definitely the biggest issue. It’s nice that you named yourself after Verl. I mean, it’s silly, but the good kind. I think it’s cute.”

Bernard Zie has an incredibly complicated reaction to being called cute by someone (who isn’t even intentionally doing that to him (yet he also projects an ideal of motherhood onto)), which he tries to show externally as little as possible.

“See, look? I don’t… I don’t have a problem with you being your own person, with these quirky little fixations. I just…!” She sighs. “No, I’m sorry. I shouldn’t be giving you trouble for being willing to reach out to me.”
“Right. Don’t you do that.” Bern doesn’t care, but this girl is supposed to be rude, kind of?

“It won’t happen again. Tonight, at least. I can’t stop being who I am either.” She chuckles. “You know, when I was your age, university years — *god, I’m saying ‘when I was your age’ to someone, how the heck has* — anyway, I… I tried to get all my friends to call me MJ. Like, Michael Jackson. Or maybe Mary Jane? That’s weed slang. I didn’t ever touch the stuff, but I think I wanted to seem like someone who would. To be cool, in a way that doesn’t actually specifically commit to anything subversive. It was a very stupid little thing, a way of breaking out of the shadow of my childhood self. But it didn’t last any longer than my time at that school.”

Bern smiles, listening to this mildly amusing anecdote that involves drugs (which are funny).

“I think everyone overshoots their mark a little. It’s better than being trapped and never growing. It’s just about knowing how to, to sort of… be flexible, maybe. Know how to admit you’ve gone astray, and redirect. Some sort of pride tells you to keep digging your heels in, but that just keeps making things worse.”
Meryl takes a sip of wine.
“I think you probably have a guess as to what I’m referring to there, and I won’t deny it. But it’s also about me. I think… and, I mean, everyone around me was being so outrageous, I couldn’t just be the bigger man in the middle of all that—! I just… yeah. I didn’t do the best job. You were… as much as you got on my nerves, as terrible as some of your decisions might have been, they made me give up on you. That’s pretty bad in its own right.” She raises a glass. “A toast to calling it even?”
*I am going to absolutely fuck this up spectacularly.* Bernard Zie hates when people are complicated (humorous hyperbole).
“You can talk to me, you know. Even if you’ve decided to be a little more polite to me, it doesn’t mean you need to clam up.” Meryl stares at her imposter daughter concerned.
“I, uh, don’t know what to say. You’re kind of not leaving much room for…”
“Well, how have you been? What’s happened these last few days?”
“Oh, a lot.” Bern says. *Very little.*, he thinks.

“Who was that boy I saw you with? Beat me to visiting you somehow. Eric, right? He really is just a friend?” Meryl leaves an awkward pause that makes it clear she’s about to keep talking. “Also, are you gay? This just feels like the time to address that.”
Bernard Zie sweats bullets. This decision will have a drastic impact on the course of the story.
He doesn’t make it in time.

“That’s okay. We don’t have to talk about it. Just, if you are, know that it’s okay, and you can tell me.” She checks to both sides of their table once more. “He’s very particular about his image, and it was a very different time from now, you know, but I think you’re old enough that I can confide… I’m pretty sure John’s, um… well, if you tried this thing in court, I have less backing for him being attracted to women than men. It’s kind of been maddening having no one to tell that.”

Bernard Zie drinks water.
This conversation is rapidly spiraling out of control. Desperate for any semblance of familiarity, Bernard Zie takes initiative over the topic. “I visited a jail earlier today.”
“Oh. Um, why?”
“Well, this lady got arrested for beatin’ me up, and I wanted to know what the hell her problem was.”
“Jesus. Really? This was before the car accident?” Meryl is SHOCKED that the city of Rome could have such barbaric behavior.

“Uh, yeah.” 

The two are interrupted by a man requesting they order food, as is customary at most restaurants.

Once that’s over with, Meryl continues the conversation. “Well, did you… I mean, do you know what the ‘deal’ was?” She approaches the topic cautiously, uncertain if this is actually her daughter’s fault in any way.
“I guess I didn’t really find that out.” Bern sheepishly admits.
“Well, no sense dwelling on it. Most of the people behind crimes like that are just off their rocker.” She shakes her head disapprovingly of violent crime.
“Really? I wouldn’t say that, myself.” Bern objects.
“What? I mean, you’re the victim. Certainly you don’t think your assailant had a very good reason.”
“I don’t know about this case. I couldn’t figure it out, like I said. But people have their reasons, basically every time.”
“Sure, they literally do have reasons for their actions. Not a lot of them are just, completely insane. But I’m talking about *real* reasons, ones that are worth considering.”
Bern crosses his arms. “That’s a totally arbitrary distinction. How can you decide what reasons are ‘real’?”

Meryl does a double take. She hadn’t really taken her daughter to have… opinions, on anything that mattered. “It’s a lot of complicated factors. This is just morality, I’m talking about. Deciding which is which… That’s… what we have the law for.”
“Come on. Obviously the law isn’t the arbiter of right and wrong.”
She smiles. “I think… you’re a little biased, sweetie.”
Bern smirks. “So? That doesn’t make me wrong. You can’t seriously claim the two are the same.”
“Well… no. I didn’t claim that. There can be unjust laws. I’m not stupid. I’m just talking about the general idea behind the law.”
“Hah. But are you? I think it would be nice if that were the case, but it isn’t at all.” Bern speaks confidently about a society he has been in for a week.
“That laws are meant to reflect morality? That seems like it’s beyond debate, at least on a premise level.”

“You’re doing a lot of heavy lifting with the idea of a ‘premise’, there, ma. What does that mean? Obviously, it’s what *you* think laws should be, but are we talking about the actual people who started law as a concept? Or just in this country?”
“The concept. I think society is, ideally, constructed around encouraging people to do good.” Meryl.

“Well, we can’t very well ask those people. But I don’t think it makes sense to think of it that way. I’ll tell ya — most legal codes when you look back start with guidelines delineating property. That’s what a formal written rule set is really good at. It’s not nearly as good at right and wrong, at the messy world of human beings.” Bern shrugs, shaking his head dramatically.

“That’s just the unavoidable truth that words are imperfect, though. We all have… I’m forgetting the word, these sort of, quintessential thoughts? That can’t always be communicated. That doesn’t mean we just *give up* on doing anything as a people.”

“I’m not saying that! I’m saying that the idea of a central government resolving individual disputes based on documents written by old guys is completely antithetical to doing anything right. *That’s* giving up.”

The two are denying the fundamental reality espoused by the other with each and every response. And yet, they don’t seem hostile. Bernard Zie loves complaining about society. Meryl is brought back fondly to the starry-eyed debate club leader in high school.

As I understand is customary, it is only once they stop touching on personal life and begin discussing politics that dinner-table conversation with family becomes pleasant. (Joke.)

This conversation goes on for a long, *long* time. It’s only briefly interrupted by eating, and finally forced to conclude by the spiteful eyes of this establishment’s proprietor. It would be wholly irrelevant to The Antarctica Project to chronicle every single moment of the exchange.

Bernard Zie has a lingering anxiety that he’ll be outed as a fraud by the fact that he knows absolutely nothing about the government or judiciary of Italy, but as luck would have it, he shares this trait with Voreverl Leocot and Meryl Leiblich.

The two ultimately conclude that, while the current status quo is by no means ideal, this can’t act as proof itself of a failure inherent to the idea of legislative bodies. Both give credence to the idea that providing more power to local authorities could help different communities protect their own interests and give each case the attention it deserves, but they remain fiercely divided on the specifics, with Bern considering this an entirely necessary shift. He fervently disagrees with the more reform-based approach his faux-mother speaks towards, but respects her desire to avoid social unrest and violence. It suits a maternal figure, he thinks.

Bern thinks surprisingly little of it. Meryl thinks at the time that this is the night she’ll remember as when she finally got her daughter back. 

But they’re both wrong. This is a wholly new dynamic, a quite curious relationship between two people, beginning right here.

The next day is the birth of Bernard Zie’s dynamic with “being a gamer”. He contacts Eric Zeety, feeling they left off on a sour note, and the two spend most of the day trying to get Bernard Zie to use a computer.

This day will not be chronicled in extensive detail. Nor will the following day, or the day after that.
I get it now.
// I’ll format tangents of my own like this. Sorry, but this is just the only words of mine I know you read.
// I understand what you meant, I think. Why you were so vehemently against both telling Bernard Zie’s story and then against not doing so. I have reasonable confidence in my ability to handle both.
// To capture the nature of Bernard Zie without crushing the ambiguity that lets him be what he is in the limelight.
// Please look forward to it!
Our next point of focus doesn’t happen until over two weeks later, when Bern has finally become accustomed to this daily life…
It’s an average day.
Average by both the standards of this very out of the ordinary period of Bernard Zie’s existence, as well as the subset of those days where he doesn’t have to go to work.

Eric Zeety is seated within Voreverl Leocot’s home, currently playing the role of Bernard Zie’s home as a matter of convenience.

He’s ended up playing a more active role proportionally to time in Bern’s life than he has for Voreverl. Perhaps it relates to curiosity about the situation they’ve all been caught up in. Perhaps sympathy for his plight as a fish out of water. It may be an easier time interacting with a perceived member of the same sex, or it may be that Bern becomes restless incredibly quickly without someone to bounce off of.

Bernard Zie stares blankly at a credits sequence playing on a television that does not belong to anyone present.

“…”
“What?”

Eric turns to him.
“Huh?”
“What the fuck was that?! You said this was where it got good.”
Eric chuckles. “Uh, yeah. It is. This is basically where the whole thing peaks. We can stop now, if you want.”
“No, I can’t leave it off *there*!” Bern groans. “How is that not the worst story ever told?! I don’t get it!”
Eric shakes his head. “Yeah, you never get *anything*. I don’t know why we bother watching this when I just have to recap what’s happened every episode.”
Bern turns to Eric, making uncomfortable direct eye contact. “No, I got everything in this one! It just sucks!”
“How?”

Bernard Zie points a finger to his palm, gesturing unclearly as he rants. “So okay. The lingering thread is how this family is gonna want revenge on Walter. They show the whole process of them learning who he is, tracking him down. I sit through a bunch of scenes where *nothing happens* with these assholes, all at your promise it gets good I might add. And they never do or say anything, but that’s fine, sure — clearly they’re building up to make them good in a cool confrontation or whatever. So they break into his home… and then they change their minds, and they leave.”
“Yeah.” Eric smiles. “It’s so good.”
“*Howwwww*?” Bern whines. “I’ve seen everything you wanted me to see, right? Clearly I’m *supposed* to get it!”

“Look, you’re taking this all too seriously, is the problem.” Eric shrugs. “It never fucking mattered what these two were going to do. They don’t even have names. These are narrative dead ends. What, a prime time show is gonna have their jerkoff oh-so-complex lead die because of *The Cousins*? No, it was always a waste of time. This is just an insanely, beautifully honest way of subverting expectations to explain that.”
“My expectation was that it would be good.” Bern crosses his arms.

“That’s your mistake. That’s why this only works so far in. You know this is just a tedious endless cycle where Walter just does the same shit because of his pride. So this is basically taking the piss at it. If I had more faith I’d call this the whole point of the show, but even I can’t claim that with a straight face.”
“I still don’t even think you’re right about that.” Bern mutters.
“About what?”

“About ‘pride’!” Bern raises a hand skyward. “Whatever the fuck you mean when you keep saying that word. He’s refusing to enter a social fiefdom under sycophantic millionaires who cheated him out of a better life. Maybe it would be good for his family if he accepted it, but I can’t call that right overall.”
“You sure are describing motivations founded on pride, yeah.”
“No, I’m not!”
“Whatever.” Eric sips an energy drink with an absurd name he purchased in jest.
“Look, what’s the next one? Clearly I can’t trust your opinions. I bet it gets better later.” Bern holds onto hope, attempting to use his still rudimentary technological skills.
“You sure do place a lot of faith in this for no clear reason…” Eric muses.

“Everything sucks when you start it.” Bern clicks his tongue, having accidentally navigated to the main menu. “Unless it’s some impossible masterpiece. It’s always fucking boring when you have no reason to care — but you gotta push through, have some faith you’ll be glad you did at the end. I read books and shit, Eric. That’s why I’m not just some street rat and can use words like sycophantic fiefdom.”
“Congratulations.” Eric makes a mock ‘toast’ with the gamer fuel.
“I wasn’t looking for your approval!”
“You’re kinda built like Jesse, honestly.” Eric changes the subject.
“What? How?” Bern is equally baffled by the latest Eric opinion.
“Cause he’s gay.” Eric snickers.
“He is *so* explicitly heterosexual.” Bern grumbles, uninterested in addressing the other implied half of the statement.
“You wouldn’t get it.”
“You can’t just say that after every bit of nonsense you throw out!!!”
“Just give me the clicker. I’ll do it, if you want to go to the next one.” Eric sighs, putting down his beverage.
“No.” Bern refuses. “I need to figure this out for myself, if I want to be able to make it in this world.”

“If you— what? Look it—I don’t even know what you *did*, man, it auto plays the next one by *default*. You…”

Eric is interrupted by a very annoying and loud noise.

The noise stops.

Bern frowns. “What the hell was—”

It repeats again. It sounds like some kind of rapid banging, a recurring collision with a solid surface.

The thing keeps going, and once they understand the building isn’t going to collapse on them, the two search.

“Oh, I found it.” A minute or so later, Bernard Zie picks up a small device comparable to a smartphone, retrieved from a cabinet. The noise stops when he touches it.
“Your phone?” Eric asks.
“No, no, that’s still on me. This is… I don’t really know. It was there when I woke up. But it wouldn’t do anything. I forgot about it with everything else that happened.”
“I see.” Eric thinks to himself silently.

The device lights up.

> SOUL: TEST

It has some sort of interface for communicating by text. Bern shows it to Eric, who shrugs.

> VL: hi who are you

Bern takes a very long time to type this. He mutters to himself seeing the username he has been preceded by.

> SOUL: Who is this???

This one causes Bern to hesitate.

Should he continue to don the identity of Voreverl Leocot? Still, this might have something to do with his situation…! He could manage to get back home. Was this someone he could trust and communicate honestly with?

> VL: you first
> VL: say who you are

> SOUL: Disregard.

The PDA shuts off.
“FUCK!” Bern screams.
“Dammit. We can still get some valuable insight from this, though. S—” Eric is interrupted, as has happened many times.
“Get out… of here.” Bern whispers.
“Huh?”

“Get out of my house!!” He snaps.

Eric, not in the mood to dispute that this is neither his nor a house, quietly heads to the door.
“…See you tomorrow, then.” He leaves, in a manner uncomfortable for everyone present.
*Ugh. He’s so…*
*I guess he’s fine.*
*Why was I even mad…?*

*Is this… body messing with me? I swear I’m not usually like this. Maybe I am… but, no, I’m not! What does ‘like this’ even mean?! I’ve never been in any kind of situation like this, of course I’m gonna act different!*

He lies flesh not his on a mattress not his. A thief by trade.

*I wonder how everyone back home is holding up…*

Lying on his side with an arm under his head, a warm sensation on that arm alerts Bernard Zie for the first time that he is crying. He jumps up onto his feet, startled. It’s a maneuver that makes it seem like he just saw some wild animal break into the room.
“Shit.” He mutters out loud.

*I can’t let this keep up.*

He does not will it to end immediately.

*How fucking stupid must this look… oh, maybe that’ll motivate me to be able to…*

He heads to the bathroom, set on the mirror.

He stares at her face.

*W…why did I think this would…*

He sobs. *Stupid, stupid. Fucking idiot. Fuck. Doesn’t even make sense.* Bernard Zie flees back to the aforementioned bed.
He sits down on it.

*It’s okay.*

He takes a deep breath. He quiets himself, by any means necessary. He counts down from twenty. He tries to recall a pleasant memory. The last one makes things worse.
He examines his surroundings for anything to fixate on. His vision settles on the sky.
*You should’ve just killed me, then. This doesn’t do any good for anyone.* Bern thinks bitterly at a vague concept. He’s not even sure what his problem is right now.

He pulls out his phone, finger hovering over the call button.

“Sho… should…”

*No. I’m too… my voice too obviously affected right now.*

Bern hates the process of typing, but he reluctantly resorts to it, texting Eric.

> sorry
> im sorry
> im sorry im srry fuck i don’t know what that was
> please answer
> where are yoy
> you

He gets a response.
> I’m walking home. It was getting late already, anyway.

> no its not please come back are you far

*I need… I need anyone. Even just to fight. Someone else has to be here.*
> I’m not upset or anything, really. I get why that was a shitty experience. You don’t need to apologize.
> shit the fuck up and get back here i don’t care
> NOW
Bern throws the phone against the wall.
This doesn’t improve anything about his circumstances.

*I don’t even understand… why I’m even here…*

It’s official.

He has begun “yiiking out”.
*What even is— why don’t I get anything? Didn’t Horatius say something about some info? About what this project thing is?*
*I don’t know… I just…*
After several minutes of vague amorphous and continuous psychological anguish, he hears a knock. “Hello? Bern?”
“It’s unlocked!” He yells.

Eric cautiously re-enters. “Hello. Do you need something, or, just want… to hang out, a little longer…?” He seems to have only realized this exact second how uncomfortable this situation is making him.
“Stay. I need you here.” Bern says it as simply as possible. He’s still facing away from the door.
“O… okay, I will, but for what?” Eric asks. He gets no response. “I mean, how long do you want me to… what?”
“I don’t know!” Bern turns to face him. “The whole night, if that turns out to be necessary!” It’s visibly unambiguous that he’s been crying.
“O…okay, just… calm down, alright?” Eric attempts to placate the bodysnatcher.
“I will! I just need… you have to be here. The whole time.”
“The whole… well, I mean… you’re not gonna pull an all-nighter, are you? Not a wise choice.” He mutters.
“I don’t know. I’ll probably fall asleep, yes!” Bern.

“I—” Eric grimaces.

“This is weird. That’s not a good idea. I should go. Just… um, get some rest, alright?”
“*Don’t you dare.*” He runs to block the path from Eric to the door.
“Look, you can’t— you’re not gonna force me to stay. That isn’t happening.” Eric shakes his head.
“Can’t I?! Fine, what if I can’t?! I’ll just convince you, then? What’ll it take? What’s your massive problem with being around me?”
“I… Bern, we’ve spent a bunch of time together these past few weeks. I’m fine being around you. You’re a funny guy, pleasant to talk with. This isn’t about you.”
“No, it isn’t! It’s about her, right?! You’re uncomfortable because you like her. Because of your pride, or whatever. It’s a social faux pas to just casually be with a woman overnight!”
“You — I mean, kind of, yeah. That’s close to part of why.” Eric holds his head.
“I’m not her!!!!” Bern screams.
“I know, I know! Look, it’s just… yes, it’s not just a casual thing to just stay here. It’s uncomfortable. I mean, wouldn’t you also be…”

“No, I wouldn’t! I didn’t have to sleep alone before I came here!” Bern blubbers.

Eric is slightly surprised, staring at him with pity.

“Not a casual… fine. Then don’t be casual about it.”
“Huh?” Eric stares blankly as Bern wipes her eyes.

Bernard Zie moves right into Eric’s personal space, her hand grabbing his shoulder. “That’s what you want, right? This is… this is the problem, Eric. I don’t have any purpose here. I’m just messing around aimlessly. There was a reason to keep going, back home, but I have to question everything here! I don’t know why I’m here, why I’m the way I am or the whole place is… the way it is…”
“This… look, I’m sorry. I agree, you’ve been dealt a shit hand for no good reason. You don’t need to tell me.” Eric reassures.

“Then fix it. Give me a purpose. If there’s a reason I have a female body, a use for it, it’ll just be inevitable and to my benefit. It sickens me, but it’s the only way. I won’t have to think about it, then!” Eric can feel her breath. This is the worst moment of his life.
He stares silently at Bernard Zie. “You…”

“I’m propositioning you! This is what you want! Is it still not enough for you to stay?! I know about love, and you’re obviously—”

Eric Zeety backhands Bernard Zie.

Her body — Voreverl Leocot’s — falls to the ground, unprepared for the blow.
“…Good *night*.” Eric spits out. He turns around.

“Wait. Wait!” Bern clambers upright. “You’re right, yes, you’re right, it would be weird! Messed up! I was just — I was saying stupid, desperate shit. We don’t have to — we shouldn’t do that, that’s my point! You can just be here! Don’t you understand there’s a difference?!”
“You don’t get it.” Eric replies, expressionless.
“I don’t. There’s so much I still don’t. You’re the only thing I have here, Eric. I have to lie to everyone else. They all hate me, they’re all not around. I need…”
“I would’ve said no even if you were her. That’s just not Eric Zeety’s characterization.” Eric heads through the door.
“I— please don’t—” Bern coughs, choking on air, seeing the futility of his pleas. “—I’ll kill her. I’ll kill myself. If you leave.”

This does get his attention. Eric turns around, a mix of a thousand different sentiments.
“No, you won’t. You’re a lot stronger than that.”

He leaves.
“DON’T — *GGGGGGHHIAYAHH!*” The final plea fades out of coherent language. The door closes on Bernard Zie’s tomb.
The irony is that he actually falls asleep pretty quickly after this.
He dreams of pain. An easy physical kind. It’s not the worst sleep he’s ever had.
Nevertheless, life always has to go on.
Bernard Zie wakes up the next day, a Monday. He goes to work. Eric avoids him. They reconcile later that week. Both claim full responsibility for the event. Neither speak of it ever again.

We near the end of this drawn out segment of the story. Just one last stop before we close the book on this critical period of Bernard Zie’s life, leaving much of the specifics shrouded in mystery.

This happens three months in.

Bernard Zie is home alone.

He’s not always alone. As it happens, he’s even reached out to a few people under the name Bernard Zie. Just to spend time with. He’s slowly found a compartmentalization of his life that keeps him the most sane, while maintaining secrecy and even a smooth transition away if a switch can miraculously happen again. In the meantime, he’s worked with Eric on various pursuits to search for whatever information they can find that may be of assistance.

But regardless, on this particular night, he happens to be alone.

The phone rings. It’s not an unknown number, but it’s also not one Bernard Zie has been contacted by before.

Bern sighs. He figured it was inevitable this would happen eventually. He pauses what he was doing, clears his head, and picks up the phone. “Hello?”
“Who are you?” The voice of John Leiblich comes through loud and clear.

“P-I’m sorry? Huh?”

*He… called me, though?*
“I asked who you were. It isn’t complicated. Shouldn’t be, at least.” John Leiblich carries his typical tone of restrained spite.
“…Voreverl Leocot!” He feigns enthusiasm.

“Don’t fuck with me. You’d need to do a better job than that. Not a single ‘gweh’, or a jab at me, or immediate and completely purposeless enthusiasm. You’re someone doing a very bad impression of her. Though perhaps in ‘Voreverl Leocot’s body’.” He enunciates the last three words as if using air quotes.

“…What exactly do you mean by that?” Bern is almost relieved, really. If this man is open to the possibility that he’s someone else, maybe he knows how that would happen. Saves him the trouble of acting, too.

“Voreverl Leocot is in Arctica. *Still*. So that leaves the question of who Meryl is talking about. I have a couple theories. But I wanted to hear you speak.” John Leiblich outlines his reasoning smugly.

“I’m here speaking. Any genius ideas, pal? Or are you just here to allude to things until I give you information you need? If you can’t tell me anything I don’t know, then I have no reason to help you.” Bern is tired. He’s caught between several different desires for how this conversation ends. The strongest of all is perhaps for it to simply end in general.
“This isn’t about *you*.” John sighs. “Clearly an attempt is being made to replicate her, though. I wonder if you’d be made to not realize you were an impostor…? Intriguing.”

“What?”
*What?*

*I thought he might understand that I’m from Arctica. What the fuck does he think is happening?*
John Leiblich is unwise.

“Is it the RN series again? He and his cronies always had an unjustified amount of faith in just one more fix making it feasible. Whatever it is, listen up. I’ll only say it once. This goes to your master. The project head.”

John Leiblich says the name of the Project Head explicitly, so Bernard Zie knows what he’s talking about. Bernard Zie knows this information now, if not the significance of it.

*…He does know SOMETHING. He’s just a little confused about… most things. This project guy… is that the one to blame?*

“I’m… listening. Whatever this is.” Bern is amenable to whatever this is.

“Quiet.” John snaps.

“…Tell him that I’m coming. I’m getting closer and closer to finding him with every day that passes. And they do keep passing. I know what the schedule for The Antarctica Project is. None of the chapters were supposed to last months, that’s for sure. …It failed, didn’t it? At least one person must’ve died. That must be it. It was her.” John chuckles darkly.
“Her… Voreverl?”

“She was quite literally never much of a daughter. Never much of a human, either. Didn’t amount to anything. But she was mine. My responsibility, if unjustly so. An incidental curiosity. If he thinks he can keep taking from me to protect his own skin, that it won’t matter because I already loathe him anyway… let him know he’s more of a fool than I already knew, alright? There is no limit, no bounds to my hatred. He’s always been able to continue digging his own grave. And he has. I’m going to make him beg that I stop at just killing him.”
Bernard Zie doesn’t have anything to say to that.

“That’s all. I will not contact you again. Do not contact my wife again. And pass on that pertinent information. It may contain something to help save him, after all! Ha.”
John hangs up.
*I am not doing whatever this man thinks I am going to do.* Bernard Zie stares at the phone, recovering from the worst conversation he has ever had.
// That should be enough. All the major players here have been covered at least once. And yet the steps in between, the type of effect it had on Bernard Zie, remains highly volatile and unfixed.

// In terms of plot, nothing much happened in this chapter. I could have gone into Bernard Zie becoming aware of relevant figures such as Pope Francis and Mohammad Avdol. Could have shown in more detail him theorizing and investigating with Eric. I could even have addressed the mystery of the name Eric itself — another plot thread that seems to have been left to the side. But in the end, none of it amounted to much. Bernard Zie did not find a way back home. He was just taken back eventually.
// Does that make his efforts a waste? I don’t think it’s my place to say.
// Perhaps I’ll consider revising parts of this later. It definitely plays a unique role in chronicling this person.
// But that will have to be enough, for the time being.
__CHAPTER 5 - END__
*5.5 - ACCOUNTING*

A man known to his neighbors as “Oku” heads into his home, his slow gait causing the process of passing through a doorway to be abnormally drawn out.

He closes the door behind him.

“…Ugh.”
This man’s name is George Tanaka.

He shutters the windows and begins the process of unraveling this asinine farce he’s trapped himself in. The removal of a wide brimmed cap, fake facial hair, loose clothing to make his actual build ambiguous, all the works. He can use a little bit of disguise magic, but due to the fact that sunlight dispels such illusions (that is how it works), he mostly resorts to practical methods which would be familiar to an inhabitant of Earth in order to render himself unrecognizable.

George Tanaka is an accountant. He works for the provincial government of Weath, a subdivision of Arctica primarily known for the presence of farmland. And he has been bureaucratically locked into this shithole.
It’s called Villo. It’s too insignificant to even appear on most maps. But here he is.

He needs to engage in a slight amount of physical labor each day to keep up the pretense of being a farmer, but he’s gotten quite good at managing that and minimizing it. Most of his days leave him with quite a lot of free time to do as he pleases. A blessing or curse, depending on who you ask. His efforts to keep tabs on those under his clerical (Clerical meaning related to paperwork; not the actual role of a Cleric, which is a thing in this genre setting of course) jurisdiction blur the line between obligation and hobby.

He’s a bit of a gossip, surprisingly, is the main takeaway.

“Let’s see…” He walks over and takes a look at his calendar, stretching his arms out half-lazily.

“Ah.”

There was something today, of course.

As one door opens, another closes.

While George is entering his house, his next door neighbor is in the process of exiting hers.
This woman’s name is Diana Fetcher.

Diana is a woman that seems perpetually tired. Not necessarily physically, but spiritually, she certainly was.

She was not like George; there was no explicit obligation for her to be anywhere near here. But she lives here because she has nowhere else. Because living here is cheap. She had failed to make it in a realm of higher education, due to some combination of societal and personal factors. She had lost the favor of her family and never had a particularly stable source of income.

// It seems my “acquaintance” has shied away from ever allowing this to be entirely clear, but I share no such sense of decorum in hiding things the person in question makes no real attempt to hide.

Diana Fetcher went through a variety of endeavors to secure cash, from amateur spelunking to less-than-reputable schemes. But among these actions taken to make money was one that, by the nature of the society she lived in, overwrote all else in the eyes of those who knew.

Though the demographics of this village meant it would never be a consistent enough thing to be all she ever tried as her home barely evaded eviction, Diana worked nights as, to use the least disparaging term possible, a prostitute.

She stares absentmindedly back at her house, and then rolls her eyes as she walks the short distance to her neighbor’s.

Diana only knocks once before entering, not waiting for a response. She meets George’s eyes and nods. George silently walks over to a cabinet in the back of his house. There are no pretenses between them about why she’s here.

George Tanaka withdraws the Arctican board game *Platagon*.
Diana takes a seat. “…You’re kind of a weirdo, you know.”
George begins setting up the game. “In what sense?”

“This. Didn’t want to question it at first, don’t look a gift horse in the mouth, but I’m feeling a little bolder now. You don’t have to pay me for this. I mean, you do. I would stop doing it if you stopped. But this is just the kind of thing people do with each other normally. There’s other guys in this dump who would humor you, I bet.”
George adjusts his glasses. “Come now. Really? I doubt most of the ingrates within walking distance can read.”
Diana smirks. “Good. That’s what I hoped to hear.” The two bond over their shared misanthropy and paradoxical classism.

“I suppose Gats might be able to. Even here, the qualification of a lawyer should certainly mandate that.” He frowns, needing a moment to locate the proper piece in a container left in disarray. He clicks his tongue at the carelessness of his past self.

“He is? Hm.” Diana stares at the board.

She didn’t think she was particularly good, honestly. She had a pretty even amount of wins vs losses in her history with the game. But George Tanaka had noted the existence of someone who could be paid for their time, and was satisfied with someone who had any familiarity with Platagon at all.

“Begin match.” George dramatically proclaims. “AB-CD. …I, George Tanaka, aka Oku, caught him screaming in exasperation about some legal matter. It was pretty amusing, really. That’s how I came to know his profession.”

“BB-AB.” Diana follows the rote opening of this fascinating game involving separate axes of physical maneuvering of pieces on a board as well as stated quadruplets of letters. Had we only the time to elaborate on its beautiful rules. “That’s… funny.”
“You had some odd hesitation in agreeing that the anecdote was humorous.” George coughs. “DA-DA.”
“You’re not gonna be able to stall me out, George. AD-BC.” She scrutinizes the board. “It’s more that I don’t think I find the same part you do funny. It’s the way you described the event.”
“ZZ-ZZ.” One battle forfeited, for the sake of winning the war. “How so?” He asks, expressing an earnest curiosity.
“AA-ZZ. Warrior takes Skeptic.” She laughs mockingly. “It seems unlike you to just say ‘some legal matter’. I would think you’d know.”
“I’m not omniscient.” He crosses his arms.
“Sure, but that’s the sort of area you work with, right?” She makes direct eye contact.
“Not really. It’s… I mean, I highly doubt you’d actually have any interest.”
“I’m full of surprises.” She rests her head on her hands. “Quit stalling and move.”
“Ghrk! …Ugh. …IP-KW.”
The match continues for some time.
As the game approaches the endgame, the conversation between the two only picks up speed.
“HF-GY.” Diana sighs. “I don’t understand why you don’t just quit. Your time and talents are wasted here, and you know I don’t compliment you lightly.”

“Someone has to do it. It may as well be me. There used to be a lot of crime around this area, you know. The government needs to maintain order.” George frowns, staring at a position unfavorable to him. He opts for a sacrifice play. “CC-CD.”
“XK-CD. Skeptic takes nomad. Hate when you give me the obvious moves. And I hate how resigned you are, too. You must know on some level this whole kingdom’s full of shit.”

“I disagree. I won’t argue we exist in a utopia, but society is comprised of those who are well informed doing their best to improve things for everyone.” George initiates his gambit, while continuing the conversation without a beat to attempt to perform a bit of conversational sleight-of-hand. “BT-AB. We really don’t need to retread this debate, though. I’m not going to pretend archaic attitudes about your sex aren’t present in federal legislature, and I apologize for not taking you seriously. But the ends justify the means. If it means avoiding anarchy, we need to tolerate such sluggishness in progress, and some people need accept inconveniences for the greater good. It is necessary, at times, to crawl in the dirt.”
“God, you’re insufferable.” She puts a palm to her face.
“We do have a lot in common.” George lets out a rare smile, even if it’s tinged with antagonism.
“I’m gonna… ugh.” Diana shifts focus to the game. “GA-A…” She sneers. “Oh, no, nonono. No. You’re not going to trick me into a draw, jackass.”
“Hmph. But you already started declaring your move. In such a situation… you’d be disqualified for an invalid maneuver.” George does what can only be described as ‘the anime glasses thing’.
“We’re not playing at a fuckin’ tournament.” She rolls her eyes.
“The rules are the rules. I could pretend you won if it assuaged your ego, of course. But I’m not sure you’d be happy with that…” George Tanaka.
Diana grits her teeth. “Oh, you fucking…. Oh.” She laughs. “Who says I didn’t say my move? You heard it, right? GA-AO.”
“Huh? You… oh. I… see.” George squints, befuddled that his teasing successfully led her to choose one of the worst possible moves to make.
“UO-IC isn’t valid.” Diana can barely hold herself together at her own comical reversal of circumstances. “I’ll let that one slide, though. Go ahead. Take the bait.”

“…” George ponders the situation. Bait, huh? She’s obviously bluffing. This is a free capture for him, leaving no additional material exposed. There’s no other way around it. He’s certain of it. “AB-AO. King takes Mother.”
“Damn.” Diana exhales. As it turns out, George was right. This was a sizable blow.

…But as it turned out, not enough to turn the tides. The two stop the idle chatter from here on out, listing moves in rapid succession with nothing in between. Within minutes, the final move is made.

“Hah. Q-A. Veil takes Watcher. That’s your loss.” Diana tips over the piece with her finger.
“Ah. A decent game. Though perhaps drawn out. I suppose I should have forfeited earlier.” George shrugs.
“No, the parts where I know I’m going to win are the best ones. Thanks for that.”
“I almost had you, though.”
“In the most aggravating way possible, sure.”
“The ends justify the means.” George says with an unreadable amount of irony.
“Good night, George.” She sighs. “I’ll see you… later.”
Diana leaves.
Having nothing else to do, George retires for the night.
The next day is uneventful, with a single exception.

Diana creeps up on him while he’s outside (as Oku, of course), and in a hushed tone, says the following:
“Let’s meet again tonight.”

Then she leaves just as soon as she arrived.
He wipes his brow and heads back inside, judging the day over.
George Tanaka closes the door behind him. He doesn’t lock it, though. There’s nothing to guard, really. …Mostly it’s that he forgot. Even the most meticulous of all slip at times.
He sits at his table, deep in thought.
*Why was she behaving so strangely?*, he thinks. *Diana doesn’t tend to reach out to me… let alone the way she did it.*
*It’s not wise to interact with me while I’m Oku. I suppose that’s why she made it quick. …A little too quick, honestly. I don’t even know when she’s to show.*
George stares at his clock which he has. 10:04.

*Not all too much night left. I wonder…*

His train of thought is interrupted. By himself. Maybe it’s paranoia, but he feels like he heard something unusual.
After a few seconds of focused silence, he hears it again. Some rustling, walking that sounds as if it’s just outside his house.
*Shit. I can’t let any of these fools get a look at me.* He draws the shades, and locks both his front and back door.
*Is this related to earlier today? It wouldn’t be Diana. She’d take a more direct route.*

He hears the clear sound of someone trying to open the back door.

“Go away!” He yells in the voice of his public persona.

George peers out the back window. It’s not the best angle, but he’s quite confident he’s never seen this man before. It also looks like the old man is holding something. Not a bag or briefcase of some kind. More of an… oblong object. Like a weapon.

George frowns.
*Is this an official of some kind…? There shouldn’t be any reason anyone higher up would directly contact me around this time.*

He’s aware of the potential danger to himself, of course. If whoever this is gets impatient. 
*I should retrieve my arms.*, he thinks to himself. A logical precaution. Unfortunately, at that moment, the man breaks down the door.

“Ooooovan, who are you?! What’s the meaning of this!?”
George can confidently assess the man as someone he has never met before.
*That, at least, is good. No upended secrecy. More likely a transient issue to handle.*

The man doesn’t respond. The item in his hand, now clearly identifiable as a blade, begins to glow as he approaches George.

*Shit.*

“Don’t take another step.” He holds out a palm to the man, as though about to cast something.
*I don’t actually know how to do anything that could help… but he might not know that.*

The man stops.
“…Magic?” He mutters.
“Y-!! …That’s… the idea.” George is a little surprised he broke the man’s silence.

“Hmph.” The man grunts dissatisfied. He can’t afford to delay; he’s a little unclear on how things work, but the longer he stays here, the longer people have to cover for his absence back home. Still, as far as he knows, this man could vaporize him in an instant. He stays put for the moment.
“Who are you?” George barks. “Are you here on some sort of official business?” *At this point? The answer has to be no, obviously. But still, anything to keep him talking.*
“You could say that.” He chuckles, and then squints uncertainly. “You’re… George Tanaka? Right?”
“That… depends on who’s asking.” George steadies the aim of his fraudulent threat as he provides this technically correct answer.

“You asking for an introduction?” He gives a bemused smile, as if considering the very idea absurd.

George stares at him without answering. The tables have turned, at the moment.
The old man waves. “Joe. Name’s Joe.”
“A common given name. I demand you answer more specifically.” George scowls.
Joe rolls his eyes. “Joseph Robinette Biden Jr., in the flesh. That precise enough, bean counter?”
“I’ve never heard of you.” George responds.
“It’s refreshing to hear that, honestly.” The forty-sixth president of the United States of America smiles with ambiguous sincerity.
“The implied purpose of my asking was to know why you are *in my house*.” George Tanaka stares at him, unshaken by the revelation of his full name.
“Ah, well…” Joe sighs. “Y’know, it’s like, the, sort of—a political thing, uh…” His penchant for stuttering combines with an actual uncertainty on how to respond.
“Did you intend to kill me?” George makes an educated guess on the aims of an armed man who breaks into his house.

“….Yeah.” He shrugs, no longer willing to hide this. His enhanced reflexes give him the confidence that he at least won’t be taken out in one cheap shot. But he still hesitates from initiating a confrontation as things are now.
“I see. Can I ask why?” An observer would find George’s reaction incredibly unusual. But understanding the true nature of this event is his top priority. His only, really, at this exact moment.
“I dunno, *can* you?” Biden snarkily retorts. “It’s a bil—little bit arbitrary. Can’t pretend even I’m not tempted to feel bad for ya, despite everything.”

“So you merely need to kill *someone*?”
*An unconventional bargain, but if it can work… hm. Would that be acceptable? It depends. There are certainly those less worthy of life than I. I’m not conceited enough to inflate that number, but they exist.*
“Huh? No, no, I… what the heck? What, you think I just kill people because I’m insane?”
“It would not surprise me.” George Tanaka honestly confirms the idea’s perceived plausibility.
“It has… had, to be you, when I was gonna do it.” Biden feigns having abandoned his mission.
“Then it’s not arbitrary at all.”
“I guess? I just, man, I meant it wasn’t anything personal. Not my choice.”
George nods. “Then you’re acting under the orders of someone else?” *Perhaps this has to do with the criminal operation formerly headquartered around here.*
“No, not… I mean, sorta. I’m more the guy who gives orders, kid.” Biden once again dissonantly smiles.
“I am not a child.” George takes offense.
“You ain’t a real boy, so to speak.” Biden grows impatient.
“What the hell does that mean?” George notes the unusual intonation of the last remark.
“Getting kinda sick of the Q&A session.” Biden takes one step forward. George flinches.

“Too bad. I’m not satisfied. My name is George Tanaka. You at least knew that. But you’re an imbecile if you think the man by that name can stand to leave this unresolved. My duty is to pursue the truth.”
“The truth, huh? That’s a noble cause. But what if that truth ends up being a total fabrification?” Joe tilts his head, pretending to actually care.
“It’s ‘fabrication’.” George corrects the record.

“Whatever. Is your refusal to leave things unresolved why you haven’t struck me down?” Biden smirks. “Among other issues, feels like that doesn’t give me much reason to remove what’s keepin’ me alive.”
“I will of course recognize if you’re a lost cause who will never provide anything of use. Your only recourse for preserving your own life is to cooperate.” George sweats nervously.
“Sure, I’ll play a—uh, along a bit.” He shrugs. “We’re not too different, Jack.” Biden misidentifies the man he himself confirmed the name of. “The guys who really ‘chose’ you… I hate ‘em too.”
“What do you mean by that? Your account of who commands you has been entirely inconsistent.”
“It’s called The Antarctica Project. I dunno if there’s a lottery or some logic whoever went through, but you got picked to be part of it. Tough luck.” He clicks his tongue.
“What does that entail?” *The name sounds suspicious… but I’m uncertain as to if he’s lying.*

“Honestly, it isn’t worth getting into. Whole convoluted thing. One way or another, you won’t figure out. Or will.” Biden confusingly rambles through this. “What’s important is that your government’s gonna try using you and some other saps as a weapon against my people. I got a responsibility to them… and, normally there’d be a whole army on your plate to deal with, but it seems round here if you want something done right, you gotta do it, and personally. I can respect that, at least.”

“I see. Then you’re an enemy by definition, attempting to destroy far more than me alone. A saboteur antagonistic to Arctica. I imagine you intend to slaughter these others…? I’m certainly not going to allow that.” George Tanaka is suddenly very invested now that he knows the Arctican government is involved.
“Little too late for that. Dagte’s a goner.” Biden shakes his head, mourning the loss less than seriously.
“Who? …Whatever.” *That’s an odd name. I can probably find them later.*
“Can’t help but notice you’re not even going and firing warning shots, or whatever.” Biden smirks.

“Tch…!” George grunts. “Fine. Okay… but hear me out!” He holds up his hands defensively.

Biden, intrigued by this, acquiesces. He’s aware Tanaka could be attempting some sort of trick, but his curiosity overwhelms him. In truth, he likely knows less about the full situation than George at this point. Compounding on that is the fact that he’s in no way a trained killer. Not when it comes to directly taking lives, at least.
“Go ahead. Talk your talk.” He spits out what may or may not be a real phrase.
“Are you certain you aren’t being deceived?” George Tanaka asks after a significant period of silence.
“…In what sense?” Biden prods George further on something he had partially suspected himself at times.
“For instance, I hold a significant government position. Is it not unlikely I was chosen completely randomly and arbitrarily?”
Biden shakes his head. “That ain’t enough. I’ve got no idea how these people were sel—chosen. Maybe it’s for being important… somehow.”

“Well…”. George considers swallowing his pride to instead argue he *isn’t* significant by virtue of his position, but reconsiders. It probably wouldn’t help.

“Who are the others? I’d know a pattern better than you. It shouldn’t matter if you plan to kill me anyway, right? At least let me understand more of the situation first.”

Biden, again, pauses for some time. “Ah, what the hell.” He lists a set of six names we would be familiar with; though with ‘Kyle Groverfield’ in place of ‘Intuition Overdrive’. The aliases of ‘Mister Big Man Junior’ and ‘Horatius Kyodu’ are as we would expect. “Honestly at a bit of a loss for doing some of this… my intel ain’t exactly spotless.”
“What, the wrestler?” George Tanaka mutters. “And… Groverfield… they’re up in the north. Are you planning to teleport there?”
“No idea. That’s a thing?” Biden shrugs. “I’m kind of winging this.”
“I find planning things in advance makes them go much better.” George clicks his tongue, chiding this carelessness.
“Well, again, info wasn’t exactly, sort of the, easy to come, to pass by, situation…” Joseph makes various excuses.
“Hang on… if Dextrum’s closer to the capital with that last name… if the wrestler is also where I’d expect… there might be a pattern.” Tanaka puts his hand to his chin.
“Well, what is it?” Biden seems earnestly curious.
“I’d need to check a map to be sure. I have one in my study, if you’d let me get it.” George explains.
“Well… alright. But don’t try anything.”

George nods, and begins walking to the room in question.

*Good, that buys me some time… maybe a writing implement or something would be sharp enough to jab in his eye and run to call for help? I might be able to—*

As he walks through the hall, George feels a sharp pain in his torso, followed by seeing the sharp image of it being pierced right through.

“Eh. Sorry, kid.” Biden coughs. “But you seem pretty clever. Sure you think you can come up with something with enough time, some big old strategy. Maybe you’re right. And I’m not, gonna… with this risk. So…”

“…checkmate, I guess.”

*What the hell does checkmate mean?* 

These are the last living thoughts of one George Tanaka.
**6. Point 2: On New Frontiers**
// Let's get back into it.

Bernard Zie is sitting in his room, or the room that is technically not his, doing nothing in particular. He is not working today. Eric informed him to set aside his schedule in case something vague he was planning ended up working out.

He receives a text. He checks it. Eric indicates he's just outside, and thus Bern heads there. All very straightforward, but this kind of interaction needs to be gone through explicitly.

Technically, this would be slightly before the start of 6, based on travel times. But this is the grouping that makes more sense.

The two meet up. Eric is standing next to a taxi.

"So..." Bern asks, expectantly. "It worked, then?"
// …I suppose you’re not interested in “playing” him.
// Not this time, at least.
// Makes sense. I can relay it accurately. I was always better at this sort of logistical thing than you, anyway.
“Yeah.” Eric Zeety says this.
“Cool. Cool.” Bern nods. “What worked, exactly? Something about… Avdol?”

“Yeah. We have a way in. And he won’t know we’re coming. Which was what *you* asked for, so I’m not sure how you’re unclear on what this is. At least pay attention to something that was *your* idea.” Eric rolls his eyes.

“Ohhhh. That. It’s not like I was spearheading some operation! I gave a suggestion any reasonable guy woulda come up with.” Bern stares at the taxi, whose driver is getting impatient. The two both enter the vehicle. It’s one of those varieties which have a divider between the driver and passengers, so they don’t feel a need to be discreet about their conversation. Which is convenient.
“Obviously he’s gonna let on to more if he doesn’t have prep time. Basic inference.”
“Maybe. If he’s going to actively try to hide things, though, I don’t think it matters how ready he is. We’re looking for cooperation, not a fight.” Eric stares out the window.
“Well… *is* he going to try to hide things?” Bern stares at Eric, not meeting his gaze because of his aforementioned staring.
“…I don’t know.” Eric lies.
“You seemed pretty aware of what kind of man he was the other day.”

“I know *about* him, that’s different from being personally acquainted. He probably knows something, because of a connection with John Leiblich, the United Nations, and the history of software engineering.” Eric says this completely reasonable sentence. “But that’s different from like, *knowing* the guy.”
“Okay, but if you had to guess?”
Eric turns back to meet Bern’s gaze. “I don’t do intuition.”
That ends the conversation for a little bit.
Bern breaks the silence. "So... what's this way in, then? You can't blame me for not knowing when you're the one who was so cagey about the details."
"Uhhh..." Eric ponders how much detail he wants to go into. "There's a few different parts to it."
"Okay." Bern says.
"Tell me them." Bern says.
"Well, the first is the annoying, tedious process of heading to his physical location manually." Eric says this slightly unusual sentence.

"Sure." *That's a slightly unsual way to put it.*

The vehicle parks. Eric exits, and Bern trails after him.

"Then... secondly, and this'll be a little awkward, so don't say anything stupid, there's..." Eric looks around. They've reached a harbor. "...her."

He heads over to the woman he's arranged a rendezvous with.
"Hello! It's been a bit. I didn't know you'd be here, Jane." Meryl Leiblich smiles.

"Um. Yeah. Ehehe." Bern says this, suddenly exponentially more uncomfortable. *I don't... these are not two people who should be in the same place at the same time. That's not how this goes. Urrrgh.* "Hi. ...Mom."

Meryl nods.

Eric interrupts this wholesome pseudo-familial bonding by continuing to explain the plot. "In addition to making up for my... lacking amount of funds currently -- thank you again, Mrs. Leiblich -- she already has a connection to leverage with Avdol."
"Yes, it's no problem. I understand this is important to you, and I agree with the sentiment of stopping TAP." Meryl.
"You... a connection with... the leader of a country?" Bern sizes her up, feeling as if he's just met this woman for the first time again.
"I did have a *life* before I was a mother, Jane." She chuckles good-naturedly, before realizing that kind of comes off as mean in this context, and shutting herself up.
"We should board." Eric gets straight to the point, determined to prevent any extended meaningful interaction from happening.

They do so. There's honestly no point dwelling on it. Transit by boat between Italy and Tunisia takes nearly a full day, and that's the amount of time that passes. Bern attempts to avoid the others for this period, anyway. He mostly keeps to himself.

*Am I a bad person for this...?*

*It's not like I chose it.*

*But I'm lying to a (probably) innocent old woman.*

*Does she count as old? Hm.*

*Would it be crueler to tell the truth?*

Bern doesn't really know. He's tangential to the themes elsewhere in this story, of malicious truths and gentle lies. He hasn't really thought much about it.

*She deserves to know.* He decides.

*But it's too late for that, isn't it?*

*I hope I can leave these people alone soon.*

It's mostly a lot of fragments like this. Bern isn't exactly the type to do extended monologues, which is why he is such an effective protagonist in this context.
"This is it, Zeety." Bern says dramatically.
"What?" Eric asks.
"What do you mean, what?" Bern.
"This is what? What... is this? Why did you say that?"
"Why did you call him by his last name? You don't do that, generally." Meryl chimes in.

"I--I don't know! I just thought it was a cool sort of... look, we're here! This is what we came here for." Inexplicably embarassed, Bern charges ahead. Eric swiftly overtakes Bern, knowing that the man has no actual clue where to go.

They surpass security, as planned, and head up to a door. Eric stops. "*This* is it, Bern." 

Bern rolls his eyes.

They enter the room. 

Mohammad Avdol is there, as expected. But also present is Horatius Kyodu.
"What the hell is this?" Mohammad Avdol rises from his chair.
"Horatius?" Bern asks.

Everything proceeds as already documented.

Horatius hesitates for a moment, seemingly putting things together. "Grey hair, and a suit…" Their eyes widen. "Bern? Is that you…?"

Eric says "I told you." It's unclear what he meant by this, or why he would say this, or who he is saying it to. Perhaps it refers to some conversation that happened during a period we skipped over. Maybe he means one of his paranoid ramblings about how something is going to line up incredibly conveniently because of 'the plot'. Who can say?

"Haha, yes!" Bern rushes over and hugs Horatius. "What the hell are you doing here??"

Horatius tightly hugs Bern back. They start crying, and fail to speak several times in succession.

"Who is Bern?" Meryl asks this, smiling.

"It's... not worth explaining." Eric grabs his hat idly, exasperated at how quickly things are falling apart.

Mohammad Avdol stands there uncomfortably, unsure if he should call for anyone here to be detained.

"S-Sorry." Horatius sniffs. "Honestly, I probably barely know any more about what's going on than you. Recently, it's felt like everything has just been happening at me, and I've just been along for the ride... so I'm really glad to have you here."

*Um.* Bern is taken aback by this response. *I should... we should probably clarify the state of things, sorta...* "Yeah, I know it's-- it's kinda wild. Uh, you've been in Arctica, then? Like back where my body is still?"

They exchange more information that really doesn't matter for Bern's personal existence enough to be reiterated here.

"I am sorry to interrupt, but who exactly are all of you? This is not a building you can casually waltz into." Mohammad Avdol stares, preparing himself to rush out of the room at any moment and deal with the situation. He needs to keep the person he thinks is here safe.

"Calm down. I got us all the way in here, it's not like we're doing a coup or something." Eric Zeety wonders if he should remind Bern why they're actually here. But he regains focus on his own, luckily.

Bern turns to Avdol. "I'm Bernard Zie! It's nice to meet you, sir. Big fan." He extends his hand, which Avdol just stares at.

Eric groans. "Bern, don't fucking--"

Meryl shakes her head. "It's fine. I'm not that clueless. You're not my daughter, right? This is what happened with the project. It was nice to think she had friends, though. Let's all clear the air, okay? I'm Meryl Leiblich. I just followed where this young man said we should go."

"Eric." Eric mumbles.

"Ohh, YOU'RE Eric." Horatius correctly identifies Eric. "Voreverl's mentioned you before, nice to meet you." They turn to Meryl. "And you're her mom, right? It's nice to meet you too. Sorry about the whole, uh..." They gesture at Bern.

"I don't know what's going on." Meryl nods.
This is his resolution, for the record. This is how Bern decides to clear the air. By pretending he doesn't know he's doing it. Amazing.

Bern ignores some of the surrounding conversation for a bit. He stares at his friend, the one he hasn't seen in half a year. They look... exactly the same.

*Funny. The one time I'd expect to not recognize or understand you...*
Bern breathes deeply, on the verge of being overwhelmed by a large amount of intersecting social interactions wholly unfamiliar to him.

He turns to Avdol, the reason he nominally came here, and walks over. Some conversation occurs between him and Meryl Leiblich, relating to the set of loosely connected individuals with an absurd name for themselves dedicated to furthering the existence of Earth. It is all information we already know. The parts Bernard Zie hears, at least. Bern nods throughout while not contributing at all to this. He is amazed by how little he can care about something, and returns to the other two.

He stumbles into them mid-conversation, and decides to introduce his new associate to the old one. "Eric's a funny guy. Been very understanding of all this crazy stuff, and I'm grateful for that." He leaves out some of the exceptions to that summary.

"That's good to hear," Horatius nods, visibly avoiding looking at Eric. "At the very least, I'm glad things seem to have worked out more or less for you in this world. Good to hear that you had people on your side even when I couldn't be there."

"Yeah. It's weird how routine things are around here." Bern yawns. "It's annoying how much stuff I have to do in-between progress to make it back home. I mean it was a crazy new situation the first time, and the second started out just as wild, but after the first week I was basically just bored."

"I know, right?! Even though that one Antarctica Project guy dropped me here to try to explore and get some kind of value out of this 'Earth' place, I've barely felt like what I've done here has meant anything." Horatius ignores internalizing the implicit revelation that months have passed for Bern during a day for them in favor of complaining about The Antarctica Project. This is not entirely unreasonable. "It's like, what point is there to being thrust into a world you have no reason to care about?"

"...I think we should talk alone sometime soon as well. There's a lot more we have to catch up on, but I wouldn't say they're for all ears." Horatius eventually says.

*What?* "Oh, ahm, okay." Bern, incredibly confused, accepts this.

"So, what's our goal here? Do you guys have any leads on the whole, uh, 'get our partners their bodies back' thing?" Horatius uses an incredibly loaded term. "I've been… unfortunately preoccupied with a lot of things, so I haven't had much time to investigate any possible solutions."

Eric swaggers up. "Bern knows some of the gist of it. This is going to keep happening until we stop or take control of The Antarctica Project. We've got a lot of powerful people who are opposed to it, but still no solid proof about who's in charge. Lot of shell companies and misdirection involved. Vatican's working on pushing through all that to find their guy. As for our role, it was mainly about meeting up with you."

*...What?* Bern stares at Eric. *He knew? Or... did 'you' mean Avdol? But he wasn't looking at Avdol. How could he have known Horatius was there?*
Eric narrows his eyes. I do that.

messages.content:
As soon as the two of them are outside, Horatius starts to look down in embarrassment. 
"There's… something I've been meaning to tell you for a while." They sigh. "My life so far, well, it's had its ups and downs. I mean, the same goes for all of us Gadflies, and this shitstorm of a situation we're both in right now is no doubt a prime example. And… that's exactly why I need to tell you this."
They clear their throat and take a deep breath.
"Bernard Zie, I'm in love with you. Ever since you've come into my life, you've done nothing but make it brighter, even if you didn't notice. You're one of the most compassionate, entertaining, level-headed, and attractive people I've ever met." They start blushing at their own words. "You have no idea how much light you've shone into my life, especially now, when things have been more uncertain than ever. So I don't want to leave any more of that up to chance." 
Finally, Horatius looks up into Bern's eyes and smiles, presuming this interaction will actually mean something long-term. "Do you feel the same?"
*What the FUCK.* Bernard Zie sits quietly through all of this, with his internal monologue mainly being this repeated multiple times.

"Wow." Bern smiles, and looks down at the ground. *I don't want... I mean, I'm not just going to be a jerk to her about this--them, it's...*
"I mean, it'd be swell if I could give you a fairy tale resolution, jump into your arms sayin' yes, of course!! But truth be told I never thought about that sorta thing?"
*Why would I have ever thought about this...? I mean, with... You're... you.*

He fiddles with her hair with an uncomfortable expression. "I mean, especially not what I expected from you. I'm flattered, but you're like -- it's like, a sort of stoic presence, of..." He nods. "Course I'm flattered. But can that even be a thing? To happen? I mean there's all of this, but also, I'm a boy, and you... hrm. Well..."
*I don't think I...*
He goes through a lot of complex rationalizations. It's probably more efficient to put them in words that aren't the ones he has himself.

The thing about Bernard Zie is that he has an incoherent perception of both himself and his comrade Horatius, and the contradictory aspects move in lockstep. He alternatively thinks of himself as needing to live up to a masculine ideal of strength while also putting active effort into feminizing the way he presents himself. And similarly, he believes Horatius is actually a girl, presumably due to some vague hunch or default heteronormativity relating to the attention they attract from a mutual male friend, while also implicitly perceiving them as male by default.

Bern isn't actually unaware that gay people exist, obviously. At this point, having someone in this story who is would be the biggest contrivance of all. But he still frames relationships in some bizarre structure of power, the same way many on Earth society do. See the prototypical concepts of a "top" and a "bottom". This means that it is difficult for him to conceive of entering a romantic arrangement with Horatius Kyodu when he so frequently is implicitly coding both of them as male in his mind.
That's the 'joke'.

He sort of comes to recognize this, though, after a lengthy bit of scattered self-absorbed mental argument. And he can't deny he doesn't really understand what Horatius is, even if he definitely understands what he is, completely. It would be rude of him to reject a friend, and it would be just another boneheaded Bern blunder, the classic idiot of the group, to jump to conclusions and make assumptions about what is possible.

"Man, what the hell am I talking about? We're rebels! No rules mean a thing. I do like you, Horatius. And not really the same way I like everyone else in the squad, when you press me on it. You've always had some of the most clever ideas out of all of us. So I can trust you here, and trust that I've trusted your feelings by intuiting them before you told me and felt the same way. Or somethin'."
He nods and smiles. "My answer is yes. Whatever the question was."

"I'm really glad." The two stare at each other silently for a while.

It's uncomfortable? Maybe? My understanding is that this is the sort of situation that would normally be categorized as an uncomfortable one. But perhaps the rules of 'love' are different, if it is legitimately present here.

"Hey... can I... kiss you?" Horatius asks.

"Uh, alright."

Dude.
