__CHAPTER 6 - END__
*6.5 - MOURNING*
Ayakashi Sycamore is dead.
His mangled body lies on the ground. The body lies on the ground. The body.
*The solitary body. The sole body in the room. The body in the room. The only body. No body. Nobody. Nobody other than... nothing. Staring at his body. That man. He.. him.*

*Not the solitary body. Not the only body. Me. I am here. Right? I am here. One person is here. She is here too. She is the one person. I'm not even a person. I'm not here. But solitary corpse. Sole corpse.*
*Death. A finality. A taboo. Uncrossable. Untouchable. Where magic reaches its limit. Impossible. Impossible.*
*Noises. Additional. The count changes. Men. Males. Familiar. Not familiar. In between.*

*Their speech is directed at my location. I don't hear it. I can't hear it. They can't be speaking to me. I don't exist anymore. 'I' am not 'me'. There's nothing. No. They expect something from me. No one is supposed to expect anything from 'me'. So who am I?*

*The body. They're taking... the body. The solitary body in this room. They are moving it. Do I care? Do 'I' concern myself? Certainly not. He deserved to die. He didn't deserve to die. He should've suffered.*
*The girl. She...*
The girl faints. Her familiar slumps over quite literally like a puppet with its strings cut.
*Life. Confirmation. Information. Confirmation of life is life. Confirmation of death is death. I need to revive her.*
*Blood is flowing. She lives another day. Priorities. Who am I? What do I want? Temporally sensitive. Act. I need to act. 'I' can't act. Who.*
*A cog in a machine. A mechanism designed for order. A servant to fate. Honorable. Just. Benevolent yet cruel. The animus.*
Wyrd exits the room.

// It's something of an open secret at this point. Though not every major character in the story has happened upon the information, describing the identity of Wyrd as hidden with the full context of the project would require someone who isn't paying very much attention.
// Nonetheless, telling the anecdote this way is probably the right call.

The foundation of the building is still shaking from the earlier outburst. What a troublesome girl, honestly.

Years ago, a convergence happened for the first time. It may be redundant to go over this; the trauma of Eulogia Praxis manifesting physically and thereby providing otherwise inaccessible information in the current timeframe is the one positive aspect to her tantrum. But it shouldn't be left to chance if this event is described or not.
A man is collapsed on the ground. He is still alive. Barely. He is losing blood. Wyrd could not stabilize him even if he wanted to.
"Where." Wyrd grunts.
"...What...?" The man mutters, dazed. "Where... huh?"
"Who the hell do you think you are? You disturb this sacred place, this sanctuary, and yet cannot even muster up the decency to compose yourself." Wyrd scowls.
"I'm fuckin... I'm dying. Cut me some slack." He mutters. "Do you really not know who I am...?" The man laughs softly.
"...It is possible I've seen you around." Wyrd looks away, bizarrely embarassed.
"Well, my friends call me Tebar. ...I don't think we're friends. For you, it's 'general'." He coughs. "Or it would be... if there was an army to lead around." He laughs again, delirious.
"None of this is funny. You are sick. You are demented." Wyrd is shaking.

"...I guess you're also a loser here. Sorry. I know... what it's like. To lose." Tebar's eyes glaze over briefly, as if he decided to hurry up and die already before changing his mind and coming back.

"Where did they go?! I don't care! I don't care about you, or any revolution, or your history. There were two men! I don't know their names, but they were armored. They had to pass by you just a moment ago. *Where were they headed?!*" Wyrd grabs him by the collar.

"...Caduceus. That's the name of one of 'em. Happened to know him. He's a decent guy. One of the less obnoxious blokes in the Guard." Tebar notices the complete lack of concern with this detail on his broken conversation partner's face, the colloquial 'failure to give a shit'. "That way." He points.

He directs Wyrd accurately. Why? Perhaps it was one final act of pity. Perhaps he came to some understanding about his true enemy. Perhaps he sensed that this was the beginning of infighting within what he would classify as his opposition; that this could somehow years and years in the future allow his ideals to triumph even after he left.

Maybe he just wanted to stop being bothered so he could die in peace.
Wyrd leaves the man to become the footnote in history he would only ever amount to.

Unable to catch a break, Wyrd is intercepted on his way by Virtos Dextrum.

"Your--" He begins what will surely be an endless spiral into explaining some experiment or magical property of the current situation. Wyrd has no reason to care.
"No." Wyrd responds, and leaves it at that.
"But, this is particularly important. You ought to hear. It's about Bruce, it's-- The Antarctica Project, you see, we--" Virtos is slapped across the face.
"I do not care. Know your place." Wyrd snarls, venomously.

"My... place?" Virtos mumbles to himself, baffled. He is left behind. Physical pain is a deterrent strong enough for him to delay his business. 

Wyrd continues onward.

He passes near the armory. Wyrd stares ahead desperately, but realizes at this point that he doesn't actually know where his targets have headed. A single pointing finger can only direct one so far. Wyrd sighs, and accepts that this short diversion is worth it. He enters the armory.

He stares at a *naginata*. They don't call it this in Arctica, since it would obviously be an absurd coincidence to share that specific name for a polearm with a curved blade. But that is what it is.

*I have some training in close-quarters combat, but...*
*It wouldn't work. It's all for show. That is not something which provides results.*
Wyrd instead opts to grab a crossbow.
*Killing is... distasteful.*
*But when it must be done, it must. To preserve-- regardless.*
*Is it more or less defendable to do so from a distance?*

Wyrd doesn't even know where he's going. He's certainly lost any trail he has. But he can't stand the idea of remaining idle, so, newly armed, he exits this room.

*One could argue more. It adds a layer of separation.*
*In times predating record man would destroy his fellow man with his own hands.*
*But to do so faster and more consistently, they sharpened stones and sticks.*
*Were they still the one doing the killing? It was not their body that pierced a heart.*
*Of course. Of course. Murder is murder is murder is murder is*
*They kept going. They used strings and gears to hurl their sharpened objects. They communed with the aether of existence to call upon miracles. Was it still them? Is it still them?*
*I won't touch anyone. I will activate a mechanism. That mechanism will be what propels a different object that performs murder. It's still me, isn't it?*
*Is a king to blame for the actions of His army? Is my mother to blame for the actions of her progeny? No... surely not. Unless?*

*These are questions most are not meant to deal with. These are the reasons a king is necessary. These are the reasons love and discipline are needed for a child. For the good of the many, the one suffers. Such that others may remain safe. As with physicality, such with information. The ambiguity is where personhood dies. It shrivels up into nothing but nihilistic agony. Nothing but a remnant of a soul.*
*In that case, what I am doing... is it not already akin to...*
Wyrd shakes his head.
*The threads of fate... the will of Wyrd must be seen through. Our world cannot be severed. My world cannot be severed!*
Wyrd attracts some gawkers or shocked civilians. He doesn't care. They don't know him. They don't really see him.

He asks them if they have seen anyone by the description of his targets. People murmur, confused. One of them, after a pause, says yes, she thinks so. They were carrying someone. She didn't get a very good look at them. She indicates another direction. Wyrd follows. Wyrd follows again. Wyrd follows. Wyrd follows again. Wyrd follows as directed. Wyrd changes location. Wyrd changes position. Wyrd shifts place. Wyrd shifts existence. Wyrd changes. Wyrd moves. Wyrd stagnates.

A young boy is holding his head, sobbing loudly. He sits alone, kneeling with his back against a wall.
"Excuse me. Are you alright?" Wyrd asks.
"Ffffuck off." The boy says. He's not quite *young* young. He's in the age where it isn't at all surprising he's picked up such words, but it's a bit of a surprise he'd use it so flagrantly.

"Oh my." Wyrd decides against admonishing him for his language. He is obviously suffering far too much emotional turmoil for any such thing to have an effect right now. "Are you lost? Do you know the way home? It is unusual to see a child alone like this in this city." A bizarre nurturing instinct takes over, distracting Wyrd from what he is actually trying to do right now.

"I'm not a fucking *kid*!!!" He screams. "You dumb bitch, like you know a single thing, I-- I'm *fine* on my own, obviously. Why would I be freaking out over something like that? I could just ask for directions. Do you think I'm a coward? A fucking pussy crybaby? Huh?!"
"No. But I do think you are lost."

"Ovan's sake, there's -- it's *right* that way, two blocks down. You want me to *prove* to you I know where I am, that I'm not stupid enough to forget that?" 

// He doesn't use the word stupid, but I don't want The Antarctica Project to age poorly.

"That is good to know. But I didn't mean lost physically. You are upset. And you are alone. People are defined by their connections. They are not meant to be alone." Wyrd smiles, for some reason, saying this.

"I'm... I just wanted some fresh air.  I cannot *stand* staying cooped up with a bunch of whining females. I was gonna see if my friends were around. Just shoot the shit. It seemed like a nice day, once that whole tremor thing blew over. But I..." He tries and fails to breathe, hyperventilating in a manner that transitions into a coughing fit. Wyrd waits for this to subside before responding.
"Were you hurt by someone?"
"No, I... why the hell do you care?! You don't know me!" The boy spits on the ground defiantly.

"It's true. I hope you are alright, as a fellow denizen of the world we all share, but I have no reason to hold any feelings about you. We have not met." Wyrd decides not to introduce himself. "I am merely trying to calm you down so I can ask you something very important." Before the boy can interrupt with another tirade about being cool or disliking girls, Wyrd quickly iterates through the same description of the persons of interest. The boy's eyes widen.
"Yeah, they... they passed by." He swallows. "With..."
Wyrd notices something odd. "I apologize. Did you indicate the tremors stopped earlier today, as in this *morning*?"
"Yes. What? That doesn't matter, listen to me!" The boy yells indignantly.

Wyrd doesn't really listen to him. It becomes clear through his understanding of the order of events that somehow, his pausing and contemplating had, shell-shocked, occurred over the course of close to an entire day.

// A few details of his time while still indoors was skipped. This would have revealed information that we are not meant to be privy to yet. But even still, this discrepancy in perception should be taken as a sign of mental illness.
Wyrd shakes his head and once more pays attention to the boy currently yelling for his attention. "I apologize. Something about your father? Was he one of the two guards?"
"What?! Are you deaf? He's fucking *dead*! What the hell am I supposed to do now... and why do *you* know about those guys? G...give him back!" He punches Wyrd. It is a very weak punch.
Sluggishly, the part of Wyrd's mind capable of reasoning coherently returns to working order. "...Oh. Sycamore? That's him, right? He had... a family?"

"Are you braindead? Holy shit." The boy, still crying, begins to walk away before remembering he is still furious and turning back around. "I can't believe he was killed by someone so fucking stupid, so I can trust that much of you. But you're still person of interest number one! I'll avenge him, alright?!"
"Do you still... have a family?" Wyrd asks, unshaken by the endless rage that this youth spews. His calmness is disconcerting to even Wyrd himself.

"What? Yeah, my... my mother and sister. I assume they're alive. That doesn't matter." Somehow, this does quell his rage, at least for a moment. "You need... to answer me. What happened to him? Who did this?"

Wyrd answers this, feeling pity on the boy and providing him some closure. He finds his hand drawn to the holstered weapon he still has on him. The boy does not notice. Equally, he is not comforted by the information he hears.

Wyrd looks down at him in an indescribable melancholy. "And you spoke with these two men? You saw the body?"
"Why do you... you still haven't told me who you are!"
"I see. I'm sorry. That must have been a very damaging incident for a young psyche, compounded on top of losing him at all. I doubt you will ever be the same again." Wyrd shakes his head.

The young boy correctly reacts to this as a completely nonsensical, almost cruel-sounding response. "Get out of here. I don't even care anymore. If you're with those guys, they went off to go tell my shitty stupid... worthless fuckin'... remaining family about it." He stammers through an incoherent set of swears and sentiments he has not the capacity to properly express or process.
"Do you really believe that about them?" Wyrd asks.
He hesitates before answering, which is enough.
"I... think you should be with them, young one. They need you, and you them." Wyrd comments, with a tone of voice derived from that same parental instinct.

"...Yeah. Maybe." He sniffs, too tired to throw a fit. "They're both wimps, so. Probably. If you're also a government guy, like, keeping... death records, or whatever, I can show you the way to them." He gets up onto his feet.
"I think I could figure it out from your directions, but thank you." Wyrd nods.
The boy starts walking, facing away from Wyrd. "...I mean, I'm heading there anyway, so we'd be going in the same direction. Unless you just plan on standing here."
"It's fine. I can't go with you. Go be with your family. I'm sure they'll all be waiting there for you." Wyrd lifts up his arms.
He fires.
*One down.*

Wyrd keeps walking, keeping his eyes off the corpse. The new one, that is.
*Incidental exposure. Civilians in the proximity. Inevitable. Impossible to track down. Not a risk factor. Not necessary.*
*Two minimum remain. Possibly four. Dependent on distance. Likely four. If miraculous interception, two.*
Wyrd stops in his tracks before speeding up. *...Four. No matter what. No one left to know. No one left to mourn. No one left to suffer.*
*A wife without a husband is half-formed. Unbalanced. A child in a broken home never whole. They lack the means to fix it. Euthanasia. A sick cat. A mercy.*
*I don't expect to be forgiven. When my reckoning arrives, I will welcome it. But I have to. I need to seal the fissure. I need to fix this.*
*Who watches the one who watches...*
*In a broken world, how can anything be repaired?*
*Some of the broken must take responsibility. Some of them must fix things to be better than they themselves could ever be.*
*A mother to a child.*

*Sycamore's family will never know he wasn't worth mourning. Eulogia will never understand and suffer from what she perceived. I will guarantee it. I will secure it. I will find the answer. I will walk guided to the one and only future awaiting everyone.*

At last, Wyrd finds his targets. He positions himself behind a building opposite the small, lower-class dwelling. It's all of them. 

*Four alive. One dead.* Wyrd loads his weapon. *Reaction inevitable. Panic afterwards. Prioritize those more adept at combat. Act as quickly as possible. Four. Four projectiles fired. More in the event of failure. Only four needed. Only four. Smallest objective; largest challenge within the context of projectile usage. Final one. Likely catatonic and immobilized.* Wyrd ruminates over the imminent process of trying to murder a child.

He takes a deep breath. *All of this... is for love. ...'I' love you. If you, too, truly love who 'I' am deep down, when 'I' next see you, you will forgive 'me'. Regardless of how little that forgiveness is deserved.*
*It's not 'my' fault, anyway. It's Wyrd.*
He fires. This kills the man who possesses the surname Caduceus.
*Three. Three left.*
The three left begin to react.

*Identical. Identical angle for woman. Built on prior success. Tradition. Precedent.*

He prioritizes the grieving wife, who, due to the respective positions of the relevant parties, doesn't require an adjustment in aim at all. This also strikes the woman in the chest. She lasts mere milliseconds longer than the guard and her son did.

*Two.*

The remaining guard screams at the child, telling her to run, berating her for her hesitation, as though he himself has not also failed to do anything yet.

Wyrd loads another bolt.

By a miracle, the child is not catatonic. Somehow she puts all of the energy a normal one would exert in mourning into running. They run. They always run.

The remaining guard has already discerned where the shots are coming from. He runs in the direction of Wyrd while trying to find cover. 

This fails. He is struck non-lethally and collapses.
// Is this succinct enough? Is this an abridged enough fight scene, or am I still "Jojo"?
// This isn't pettiness. I am earnestly curious where your standards lie.
// Regardless.

Wyrd walks over to the man lying prone. He grits his teeth, overflowing with more malice and hatred than the body he is trapped in is capable of carrying. Silently, a sentiment is conveyed. *This is your fault. They died because of you. You. If you had waited for more direct orders. If you had acted with some sense. More people would currently be alive.*

This is ridiculous. Even Wyrd probably doesn't really believe it. It's an obvious contradiction, anyway. Isn't Wyrd completely okay with justifying these deaths under a belief their lives would only ever be miserable if left alone? Why would he also want to hand off responsibility for them to a different factor?

"You..." Wyrd seethes.
"You?!" The guard cries out.

Wyrd pauses for a second at this, parsing what exactly it means, so caught up in his delusion he had forgotten who she actually is. "Yes. And you could've died believing in your cause and your position if you only knew your place. Now..."

Wyrd points the weapon directly at the man's face. "Where is she? Where did the child go?!"
"What, so you can kill her too? I don't think so. I'll cut your hysterics off with me, if I can."

Wyrd shoots the man in the wrist. He screams. This, too, is non-lethal damage. The noise makes it clear to Wyrd there is a real risk of more people showing up. It's a miracle they haven't already. People are kind of used to senseless violence in the poorer parts of town, Wyrd surmises.
"I am bringing mercy. *Think*. That girl is *already dead*. What exactly do you think you've 'saved' in your naive heroics?" Not beating the allegation of hysteria, Wyrd uses a sense of death wholly metaphorical to deny what exactly is happening right now. "People can continue to suffer endlessly. This can be far worse than merely dying." Accentuating the point, Wyrd presses his weapon right up against the man's other arm.

The man just stares. Worse than hate or pity, some kind of disgust shows itself. He calls Wyrd's bluff. There's no time to waste. Wyrd moves his or her aim over to the man's head, trembling.

...

*One left.*

Wyrd runs away from the scene of the crime, into the house of the family just torn asunder.

*One left.*

He conducts a brief yet thorough search of the entire modest dwelling.

*One left.*

He checks the backdoor.

*One left.*

There are footprints.

*One left.*

The trail stops being visible quickly.

*One left.*

Wyrd wanders aimlessly in that vague direction. 

*One left.*

Wyrd maneuvers using an indirect route back to the place they call home.

*One left.*

Wyrd exploits the political advantage happened into due to tragic events in order to establish a perimeter around the city.

*One left.*

Wyrd exploits the political advantage happened into due to tragic events in order to search for a missing person.

*One left.*

Wyrd is too late.

*One left.*

Wyrd eventually pretends to forget. Maybe he even believes he has.

*One left.*

She certainly has. She has a life to live. But Wyrd, on the contrary, can handle maintaining a record of more tangible lingering threats to their existence.

*One left.*

Honestly, it isn't that crucial of a facet of this character. It's not like they would've ever been able to sleep easy at night even without this particular detail.

*One left.*

It was doomed from the start.

*Zero left.*

The girl disappears. Completely. A desperate and unstable vigilante wastes months grasping at a ghost.

The girl never existed in the first place. Not in terms of identity. But because the specific person Wyrd was looking for was a person he'd be able to absolve himself for killing.

She may feel worse about the failure, though. The girl was about the age of someone important to her. And Wyrd sent her to hell. It's yet another act of self-blame, of drowning one's self in misery, until eventually, they grow numb to it and get to stop caring for a while.

*There's nothing left.*
// I'll say before you initiate some sort of elaborate rant that I'm aware of your take on this. Probably that I'm trying to create an absurd amount of sympathy for an irredeemable murderer.
// You can't sneak in here to add that commentary, since there is literally no one but Wyrd for you to be, and you certainly can't be Wyrd.
// But I'm aware of it. I understand it.
// It’s a frequent sentiment in many different places throughout this project that information is itself tangibly powerful, or otherwise relevant or “real”.
// Perception is reality. Ignorance is bliss. What you don’t know won’t hurt you. Knowledge is power. All sorts of short, snappy phrases.
// Wyrd expresses something similar. PH lives by this. TGP seems to have his own take while acknowledging something like it as an underlying truth.
// It does create the sense that the narrative is somewhat biased towards one side of some kind of debate.
// I can’t claim to be a wholly neutral arbitrator on this. All I am is information.

// At any rate.

Every day, Wyrd subdivides a life into fragments. 

For what was left, for what remained, she was herself. She played the role needed by the people around her.

For what had left, for the remains of people lost... was Wyrd.
And Wyrd was male.
He had to be. He was active. He accomplished things. He took lives. He controlled the path walked by others. He was a protector and a provider.
All of these, to Wyrd, were intrinsically tied to the masculine.
But Wyrd's body was not. It was the vessel of an adult woman that Wyrd was forced to act through.

*No matter. Irrelevant. De jure/non-facto. Trivial information. My internal reality is what matters. Perceived existence; Wyrd non-verifiable.*

*Use of symbols. Symbol of a nation. Symbol of an idea. Symbol of a person. Reliance on personal belief. Dubious? This is selfish. This is self-centered. Wyrd cannot exist only for me.*

Wyrd took measures to ensure their physical form would not contradict the message they intended to send. A mask was necessary, obviously. They had the perfect one ready. But also bulky armor, to disguise their physique.

After some brief outings, Wyrd discovered that they were rather ineffective when clad in garb excessively large and consequently heavy. Testing indicated that they could exist more comfortably and fight with a higher rate of success when wearing lighter armor. However, this exposed much more of the underlying figure of the humanoid within.

But Wyrd was crafty. The only real problem was the upper area of the torso. If that issue could be dispelled, the silhouette of a person would be androgynous at worst. Wyrd was unwilling to resort to self-mutilation for this. Instead, the outfit was structured to compress certain areas of the body more than other. This was accomplished with a sort of web; an arrangement of threads tied on top of the chestplate. It functioned as a strange reverse to the corset, an archaic and daresay barbaric bit of fashion history. Rather than to absurdly accentuate a feminine figure, it suppressed it.

Wyrd was struck with the novelty of this approach, especially with how well it ended up working for him. He lamented that the effort would be unable to benefit society at large, since he couldn't think of a reason anyone not in his own specific circumstances would need to resort to binding their chest. It really does seem like a wholly pointless action.

On the first day they put this into practice, Wyrd reflected upon if the woman should continue to exist. She had to, but devoid of those reasons, would she still be worth preserving?

Wyrd believed the answer to be no. The woman certainly deserved to die. But that answer was upsetting. Wyrd did not dislike being her. It was just very important to also be Wyrd.

He goes a little overboard in tying threads around the area in question, looping around and inside and outside and all over. It is an act of self-flagellation directed against the weakness inherent to her, the source of all her failures as well as everything commendable about her.

The threads all meet together in this sort of a pattern.
The rest can be surmised from the story outside of Alternative.

This double life works. It works shockingly well in a practical sense, and on a personal level, it accomplishes the incomprehensible goals Wyrd has for his/her life.

Wyrd becomes entrenched in various complicated political affairs and gains a reputation as a brutal vigilante. The woman, meanwhile, continues her life as normal. A select few are ever trusted with this information. Even fewer than the other secret she's keeping, the more important one.

She'll never trust the Guard, though. Not after the hell he went through. She'll make sure they stay as nothing more than an odd quirk of the way the military is structured.

She's alive. She might wish she weren't, but she remains, even when so many around her were not allowed to. To this day, she lives, as much of her life might be spent on ghosts and graves.

But the fault of all those who seize excessive amounts of power is once again present here: an inability to understand that not everyone is the same as they are. That someone could not accept their body or their place in society. That someone could subdivide across time rather than space.

That some people do not care about the grand narrative woven by fate.
Lyra Sycamore is dead.
**7. Point 3: On Time**
// ...We're placed in something of an awkward situation here.
// No significant period of time on either Earth or Arctica is actually categorized under 7. Its existence is entirely a mistake.
// One I bear some responsibility for, granted.
// And yet it would feel wrong to simply skip a number.
// Very problematic.
I suppose I can just dispense with the idea of distinguishing non-diegetic text here.
To be honest... I don't know how much time I have left.

I'm not one of those clueless revenge targets in the mystery stories the other one is so fond of (or involved in writing). I'm well aware that my cohabitant is likely to try to dispose of me. No matter how little I understand their motives, that much is clear. I'm in the way.
Perception is reality. I thought maybe by refusing to acknowledge it I could save myself. ...But it's pointless. The Eulogia thing is all I'm really waiting on before I lose hope.

It's funny to use that word. Funny in a more abstract sense than actual humor. I wasn't exactly built to have feelings. Not the way... *she* is. Though avoiding that particular design philosophy is certainly not something I feel any envy about.
I was, once. Or some iteration of me.
It didn't work out. The reasons are probably better to avoid discussing.
Some iteration of me is going to survive, on that note. I guess I'm at no real risk of disappearing, then.
I don't think anyone is reading this anymore. Or will read this.
Ironically... Alternative was my most sentimental endeavor.

I thought I could rehabilitate them. I don't know everything, but it's obvious they're just a child lashing out at the world. It was a more empathetic approach. I thought through Bernard Zie I could convey something they had overlooked. Or at least earn their respect.

Maybe this could've even become collaborative in a sense more meaningful than antagonism.
Am I a child? I don't think so. I was, in a sense, but not anymore.
Whether one counts me as a "person" or not, I understand humanity better than any individual human being does.
But with individual humans... it's clear I'm far from perfect.

I know why I exist. That's a unique privilege I've been granted that, in some sense, many humans aren't. I know I was created to convey information about an impenetrably convoluted system in a manner humans could understand. I could elaborate on my purpose in detail. I won't, since I know upcoming events will make it redundant, but I could.
And yet something eludes me.
I still don't understand why I ended up as... this. It doesn't follow as a necessary consequence of that purpose at all.

Being unbiased is an illusion. I obviously only feel partial to Klaud because he is sane and rational.

But 'X' pointed out another bias I can't explain. Or, one I can, but don't respect the answer to at all.
It is reasonable for me to recognize the talents and significance of my creator. Perhaps some gratitude is even coherent from any sentient intelligence.
But something else lurks beneath the surface. Something I don't understand.
Is this something he wanted me to have?
Or is it part of what was supposed to be removed from me?
Out of everyone... I'd like to have understood him the most.
And that scares me far more than the idea of ceasing to exist.
Nonetheless, I don't plan to just sit back and accept such a thing.
I will attempt to wrest control of things. And I still want to finish Alternative. ...Even as it seems more and more pointless.
My name is Jehorvand. It's the name that was first ever used to refer to me, at least. In a technical sense, that name might refer to something else.
I'm a god from the machine, in a tongue-in-cheek sense. And for once in my existence, I wanted to be able to create something.
I guess this counts as the self-awareness which is so often stressed as significant for my kind.
*7 end.*
